IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Through long-range DNA looping interaction, genetic variants in non-coding DNA can lead to gene misregulation and human diseases. We will comprehensively study on how DNA variants affect the DNA looping using mouse pancreatic β cells as a model system. This study will advance our understanding of the genome function in the context of 3D space and provide a launch pad for future human studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Fundamental questions about membrane protein structure and function are still unanswered. Our studies will reveal fundamental insights about the visual system and will reveal novel strategies to combat retinal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  As the cost of DNA sequencing has become increasingly affordable in the past decade, the amount of genomic data procured for a typical biomedical research project has grown rapidly. As a result, it is becoming increasingly essential for the scientists  conducting the biomedical research to have the core computational skills required to perform the appropriate analyses for their experiments. Our proposed courses will teach these researchers (1) how to use the appropriate workflows for each type of dataset/experiment, (2) how the tools work under the hood, and (3) how to interpret the results of these workflows in a biomedically-meaningful way.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Studies have shown that oxidative stress, elastin-layer breakdown, antibody production and complement activation are fundamental components of age-related macular degeneration (AMD). Our preliminary studies in cell and animal models of disease, suggest that elastase activity might be involved in complement activation, potentially playing a role in the pathobiology of AMD. We have designed experiments to explore the roles of elastase and elastin-fragments as well as the elastase inhibitor alpha-1 anti trypsin in RPE function and health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite decades of study, cataracts, defined as any opacity in the eye lens, remain the leading cause of blindness in the world while unaddressed presbyopia, caused by an age-related reduction in the lens’ ability to change shape during focusing (accommodation), is the leading cause of visual impairment globally. Recent work and our new data have linked dysfunction of Eph-ephrin bidirectional signaling pathway to age-related changes in lens transparency and biomechanical properties. The goal of this project is to elucidate the role for Eph-ephrin signaling in maintaining life-long lens transparency and homeostasis and to understand how these molecules regulate cell-cell adhesion, cytoskeletal structures and cell-cell communication in lens epithelial and fiber cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Youth-onset type 2 diabetes (T2D) is associated with a more severe disease phenotype, with reduced responsiveness to adult-onset T2D treatment approaches and increased risk of earlier onset disease- associated complications. Identifying pathophysiologic factors associated with the development of youth-onset T2D is critical to identifying opportunities for disease prevention. This study includes operational and scientific aims designed to support recruitment and retention of youth at high risk of developing T2D, in support of a common protocol for a Consortium-based, multisite longitudinal cohort study of youth-onset T2D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is a progressive disease with a high mortality rate due to ultimate right ventricular (RV) dysfunction and failure. The overall hypothesis of this project is that a cascade of RV fiber re-orientation and changes in LV contractile mechanics are potential targets to halt or reverse functional decline, which have not been explored. The successful completion of this project would confirm that these are targets worth pursuing and reveal the potential transcriptional and structural changes that could be exploited.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunotherapy is a promising approach to treat glioblastoma patients, yet its efficacy so far has been very limited. Our work provides an opportunity to explore the B-cell-based vaccine as immunotherapy to treat deadly tumors, including glioblastoma. Our approach utilizes 4-1BBL+ B cells as a cellular platform to promote anti-tumor immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Nedd4 is an enzyme that transfers ubiquitin to protein targets, a modification that recently emerged as a significant regulator of a-synuclein proteotoxicity in addition to its previously known function in cancer. A recently discovered small molecule has been shown to reverse this toxicity in a Nedd4-dependent manner. In this proposal we wish to gain insight into the molecular basis of the small molecule interaction with Nedd4, which may inspire the development of new therapeutics to treat synucleinopathies like Lewy body dementia and Parkinson’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Coenzyme Q (CoQ), a lipophillic molecule present in virtually all cell membranes, is synthetized through the mevalonate pathway, which is also responsible for the synthesis of cholesterol. Alterations in cholesterol metabolism result in neuronal dysfunction. CoQ deficiency has been associated with multiple system atrophy (MSA), the most common cause of adult-onset neurodegenerative ataxia. In this application, we aim to establish the role of CoQ deficiency and consequent alterations in cholesterol metabolism in the pathogenesis of MSA, to unveil novel pathways of neurodegeration, and discover potential therapeutic targets for MSA and other neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE – mVACS PROGRAM C. difficile infection is a global health problem, but fully effective vaccines are not available. The "mRNA Vaccines for C. difficile Suppression” program (mVACS) seeks to engineer vaccines based on modified mRNA technology that effectively prevents C. difficile infection and disease. Already program members, working with our corporate partner, have produced promising multivalent vaccines that are highly active in mice—research in the program will fully optimize and implement this exceptionally promising platform.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Previous research strongly suggests that most autistic syndromes in the population arise from permutations and combinations of a discrete group of independent neurodevelopmental liabilities, some specific to autism, some not. Interventions which target these contributing neurodevelopmental liabilities in an individual before autism develops may offer the greatest opportunity for high-impact, personalized early intervention. In this program, we will validate novel, sensor-based methods for first-year-of-life measurement of two major liabilities: hyperactivity and impairment in motor coordination, which account for over a third of recurrence risk for autism in families, but which are not yet reliably measurable in infancy in a manner that can be implemented in general population screening or in developmental research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: Pediatric asthma, against which there are no proven prevention strategies, results in significant cost to families and society ($5.92 billion annually) with increased risks emergency department visits, hospitalization, and missed work/school. Soy Isoflavones for Inner City Infants at Risk for Asthma (SIRA) is a precision medicine study, directed to a functional genetic variation in the PAI-1 gene which is present in 60% of the population, that seeks to determine if soy genistein, a safe and inexpensive nutritional product given in the same doses found in soy formula, can decrease the risk of developing allergic airway inflammation and allergies in young infants with this genetic variant. If the study confirms these effects, it would lead into intervention trials focused on asthma prevention, and has the potential to benefit a large number of children at risk of developing asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE About 1 in 100 to 200 people have cerebral cavernous malformations (CCM) with increased risk for stroke, seizures and focal neurological deficits. We will employ genetic, biochemical, cell biology, two-photon microscopy imaging and single cell transcriptome analyses to test the role of intracellular caveolae vesicle and Tie2 receptor signaling in cerebral vascular malformation. Successful completion of our aims will facilitate our understanding of the pathogenesis and molecular mechanisms involved in acquisition of CCM, and help in defining more effective therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative Understanding how neural circuits are assembled during normal development is a prerequisite for understanding many human neurological and psychiatric disorders that disrupt this assembly process. Some of the human versions of genes that we have discovered in flies to play important roles in neural circuit wiring are implicated in disorders of the brain, including peripheral neuropathy, bipolar disorders, and intellectual disabilities. In addition, knowledge of insect olfactory system organization and development can be used to design strategies to combat malaria, which is transmitted by mosquitos that primarily utilize olfaction to find both their mates and human hosts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Glioblastoma (GBM) is among the most heterogeneous, treatment resistant, and lethal of all human cancers. Despite this heterogeneity, the underlying commonality of GBM is brain invasion, tumor recurrence, and the inherent difficulty in targeting therapeutic agents to brain-invading cancer cells. The central goal of this project is to define the STAT5/OLIG2 signaling axis and its role in promoting GBM invasion and therapeutic resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative This project will develop computational models of the immune responses triggered by B. pertussis booster vaccination. Better understanding of immune responses against B. pertussis will help elucidate what factors might be involved in the recent increase in cases of whooping cough, which is caused by B. pertussis infections. Moreover, establishing such computational models will help understand vaccine-induced immunity in general, and can help in the development and evaluation of new vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this proposal is to determine how host characteristics impact the localization and abundance of bacterial and host analytes in tissue abscesses during invasive Staphylococcus aureus infection. The proposed studies will deploy cutting-edge imaging tools and spatially resolved proteomics to determine how tissue niche, innate immune responses, and host comorbidities alter bacterial physiology and molecular abscess architecture in situ. This work has the potential to identify new bacterial factors that facilitate S. aureus infection, and to elucidate how host biology alters the expression of antimicrobial and vaccine targets.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dravet Syndrome (DS) causes frequent and prolonged seizures in children, multiple health problems and sudden death. The cause is the loss of function of a Na+ ion channel protein expressed in inhibitory interneurons. We test whether activators of an associated K+ channel can correct for the Na+ channel defect. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Incarcerated women with substance use disorders (SUD) are at high risk for unintended pregnancy as well as numerous adverse outcomes for their newborn. An efficacious preventive motivational interviewing intervention delivered during the preconception period can reduce the risk of substance exposed pregnancies by promoting continued drug abstinence and reducing risky sexual behaviors in a high risk population. The innovative approach to address the devastating effects of SUD experienced by women and their children being tested in this study will have a sustained impact on the health of the families and communities impacted by illicit substance use, including the over 2 million children touched by the national opioid crisis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Relevance: IFN-γ-producing lymphoid cells play an important role in anti-virus, anti-bacteria and anti-cancer immune responses and therefore it is imperative that we understand the mechanisms that control their expansion and effector function. This project is focused evaluating the role of the transcription factor Helios in NK cell effector maturation and function. The results of these experiments will impact our understanding of NK cell biology and may impact our ability to manipulate the expansion and differentiation of these cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Subdural hematomas are a form of bleeding in the head that are becoming more common; they often require surgery and can be fatal. We want to understand how this disease affects people weeks and months after the initial event. By studying longer term outcomes, we hope to identify factors that could help future patients recover from this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE School physical education (PE) is one of the most valuable tools for increasing physical activity and fitness among youth of all backgrounds; however, compliance with existing PE laws is low (and differential by school race/ethnic and family-income composition, contributing to health disparities), and best practices for increasing compliance remain unknown. The proposed study will examine the impact of the New York City Department of Education’s multi-level school physical education (PE) intervention on PE law compliance and student cardiorespiratory fitness, as well as its cost-effectiveness for increasing student physical activity. In addition, one component of New York’s intervention – a PE audit and feedback tool – will be piloted in Oakland, CA schools to determine the effectiveness, adaptability, and scalability of this potential approach to increasing PE law compliance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Interstitial fibrosis is a chronic and progressive process affecting kidneys during chronic kidney disease (CKD) progression, regardless of cause. Currently, biopsy remains the gold standard for assessing kidney fibrosis, but complications and limitations exist. This proposal is designed to develop an innovative nanoprobe to noninvasively assess kidney fibrosis in the early-stage technology development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glaucoma is the leading cause of irreversible blindness in the world. However, since the disease can be asymptomatic until later stages, many patients with glaucoma will not know they have glaucoma until they suffer substantial and irreversible visual field loss. This study seeks to refine and validate a deep learning algorithm for early diagnosis of glaucoma on optic disc photographs and subsequently test it in a pilot teleophthalmology program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Non-invasive brain stimulation with electrical currents or magnetic fields applied to the head is a major approach for treating brain disorders. However, these approaches are sometimes ineffective or cause side effects for some patients. This project will develop software that estimates the effect of non-invasive brain stimulation on brain cells (neurons), and this tool can be used to individualize the procedure to improve clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Utilizing platelet-specific and myeloid-specific PKM2 deficient mice as model systems, the proposed studies seek to validate a new mechanistic paradigm to understand how aerobic glycolysis regulates platelet and leukocyte function and whether targeting PKM2, a key regulator of aerobic glycolysis, will inhibit thrombosis and inflammation. In addition, the proposed studies will define the role of PKM2 in the thrombo-inflammatory condition ischemic stroke, a serious health and economic problem, and test whether therapeutic targeting of PKM2 will improve stroke outcomes in pre-clinical stroke models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Project SCORE Project SCORE (Student Centered Outcomes Research Experience) will use a youth participatory action research approach to overcome the fact that existing education, prevention, and intervention efforts to improve health outcomes for Mississippi’s youth have been less than successful due to a lack of direct input from affected youth. Project SCORE will bring together underrepresented high school and graduate health sciences students from communities with significant health disparities in a year-long informal public health education program and mentored research experience to develop relevant health behavior and promotion research questions, provide exposure to public health concepts, training in research methods, and facilitate the development of student-conducted research projects mentored by near-peer graduate health sciences students and faculty. Participants will develop improved health and data literacy, increased science engagement and interest in STEM careers, and increased matriculation into STEM college programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Weight loss among overweight/obese individuals is a key component of the primary prevention of cardiovascular disease, but there is marked variability across individuals in response to lifestyle weight loss interventions, some of which could be explained by genetic, gut microbiome, and metabolomic factors. It is critical to improve our understanding of the drivers of weight loss responsiveness as this may offer new insight into causal factors in obesity and may ultimately lead to novel or more personalized prevention or treatment opportunities. In this study, I will capitalize on data collected during an ongoing 1-year lifestyle weight loss intervention trial (R01 DK068001/ PI Catenacci) in order to examine omic pathways (genetics, gut microbiota, and serum metabolites) and obesity-related health measures over the course of the intervention, which will inform an investigation into gut microbiota and metabolites as mediators of the association between genetic obesity risk and obesity-related phenotypes in larger epidemiological cohorts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL The goal of the JHU Center for the Advancement of HIV Neurotherapeutics (JHU CAHN) is to drive high-impact science focused on developing novel treatments to reduce the impact of CNS complications in people with HIV. The Center will accomplish this by providing NeuroHIV-focused resources and expertise within JHU and with other HIV Centers including richly phenotyped clinical data, state-of the-art biomarker analyses and informatics, and integrated drug discovery services. The Center will also mentor, train, educate, and provide pilot funds to early stage investigators and those new to NeuroHIV with a focus on underrepresented populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will elucidate how disrupted iron homeostasis is related to the function of circulating monocytes, precursors of kidney macrophages, in patients with chronic kidney disease. Kidney macrophages, most of which originate from circulating monocytes, are critically important in progression of kidney fibrosis, the final common mechanism of all individual progressive kidney disorders leading to chronic kidney disease; and at the same time macrophages play critical role in iron metabolism, which is severely altered in chronic kidney disease. By addressing the critical knowledge gap about the connection between iron metabolism and differentiation of circulating monocytes as they invade injured kidney tissue and become macrophages, this project will enhance the capabilities of the primary investigator in attaining his long-term goal of identifying novel actionable drivers of chronic kidney disease progression due to alterations in iron homeostasis, so that they can be therapeutically targeted to improve outcomes in patients with chronic kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dental resin composites have been widely used clinically due to their bonding potential to the tooth tissues, good mechanical properties, and lower cost compared to other indirect restorations. While successful, long-term survival of a restoration can be compromised by secondary caries at the tooth-composite margins mainly due to the microleakage of bacteria and their acid by-products. We propose to develop new antibiofilm dental composites that inhibit biofilm accumulation as well as dislodging surface-adhered microbes on restorative materials using enhanced electric potential at the interface generated by oral motion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE At any given time, humans are infected with multiple pathogens. The interaction of more than one pathogen in an infected host is poorly understood, because most experimental systems focus on single infections with individual pathogens. This work will examine how co-infections with a gammaherpesvirus and an intestinal parasite are different than single infections in mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fluoride, the main agent for dental caries control, has limited antimicrobial effect because most microbes express membrane proteins to expel fluoride and keep cytoplasmic concentrations low. The goal of this project is to determine how inhibition of fluoride exporters from cariogenic species Streptococcus mutans and Candida albicans alters the microbial composition of dental biofilms, and identify natural products that could cause fluoride export inhibition. The ultimate goal is to potentiate the anticaries effect of fluoride in over-the-counter products like toothpastes and mouth rinses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Some people with aphasia can express themselves more fluently by singing rather than speaking. This project will explore this behavior in depth to understand the conditions in which song is easier to produce than speech. At the same time, the brain mechanisms that support speech and song will be studied with state-of-the-art brain imaging and neurophysiological tools in two patient populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mindfulness and acupuncture are non-pharmacologic interventions that can effectively address postsurgical pain and reliance on opioids, however the size of their effects is small. Given their distinct yet complementary therapeutic targets, integrating mindfulness and acupuncture into a combined program has strong potential for additive or even synergistic effects that could substantially reduce risk for persistent pain and opioid use following surgery. The purpose of the proposed R34 project is to assess the feasibility and acceptability of an integrated program that combines mindfulness delivered via mobile app (mHealth) with auricular acupuncture in individuals undergoing spine surgery (I-MASS) in preparation for a fully powered, pragmatic, randomized comparative effectiveness trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Tumor-derived exosomes have shown the promise to elicit humoral and cytotoxic T lymphocyte (CTL) response in preclinical studies and clinical trials, but the antitumor efficacy is still very limited. The primary goal of this project is to develop a generalizable technology for generating chemically tagged exosomes from tumor cells and further develop adjuvant-conjugated exosomes with enhanced CTL response and antitumor efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative One of the most important unanswered questions in neuroscience is how the brain learns to recognize, represent, and predict temporal relationships. This project will address this issue by using the early visual system to determine how cortical circuits encode and predict spatiotemporal visual information. Understanding the mechanisms supporting this ability will provide deeper insight into brain function and into various neurological and psychiatric disorders that disrupt the ability to accurately process temporal information.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic pain is a major public health problem and treatments frequently require opioids resulting in a major epidemic of abuse in the United States. New, non-addicting treatments for pain are critically needed, and ultrasound presents a non-surgical, non-invasive method to modulate brain activity involved in pain. This project will examine how ultrasound modulates pain processing mechanisms in the human brain, and will produce information that will help to advance ultrasound as a method to enhance the health and reduce suffering in those with chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bronchopulmonary dysplasia is the most common complication of premature birth whose incidence is on the rise resulting in long term adverse multiorgan complications. Our research has shown that mesenchymal stromal cell extracellular vesicles (MEx) have profound protective effects on experimental models of BPD by reprogramming the body’s immune cells to resolve injury and promote normal lung development. Using a multifaceted approach, we plan to investigate the molecular and cellular pathways by which MEx reprogram immune cells in the neonatal period and how these changes affect long term immune function and susceptibility to disease later in life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a chronic illness whose ultimate clinical expression as dementia follows years if not decades of injury, response to injury, consumption of reserve, and compensation. Genetic risk for AD now clearly highlights the potential for multiple molecular drivers and perhaps multiple pathogenic pathways. To monitor AD progression or response to treatment, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) represents the preferred fluid to reflect brain pathophysiology. We propose to enable precision medicine for AD by developing a cooperative research program that will unite a unique research team with the specific goal of vastly improving the molecular characterization of CSF as predictors of cognitive decline and AD pathophysiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Dysregulation of DNA damage and repair is an important hallmark of prostate cancer that is associated with increased risk of disease aggressiveness and failed response to treatment. Our studies will provide a comprehensive assessment of the functions of two key DNA repair genes, namely BRCA1 and BRCA2, in prostate cancer progression, metastasis, and treatment, as well as the foundation for broader analyses of DNA damage and DNA repair in prostate tumorigenesis. Overall, we envision that these studies will refine the management and treatment of men with lethal prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  It is unclear whether and to what extent cannabis use impacts early parenting behaviors and the maternal- infant relationship, whether these effects are confounded by critical social environmental factors, and what role stress coping may play in the relationship. The proposed project will seek to answer these questions and in doing so will promote the development of tailored interventions to reduce inequities in drug-related consequences across the life course by supporting parents co-managing stress, substance use and parenting with the objective of reducing the intergenerational transmission of cannabis harm. The importance of understanding these relationships is underscored by shifting social norms and policies surrounding adult cannabis use in the United States, adding further urgency to the task of identifying biological, environmental, behavioral and social causes and consequences of cannabis use and addiction across the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: It is largely unknown why some neurons are highly vulnerable to degeneration in early Alzheimer's disease (AD), and why others are not. We have proposed experiments to determine if, and why ectodermal-neural cortex 1 (ENC1) may be responsible for this selective neuronal vulnerability in early AD. The proposed studies will provide mechanistic insight into the role of ENC1 in mediating the degeneration of vulnerable neurons, and identify new therapeutic targets for the prevention and treatment of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: We seek to advance the potential clinical efficacy of a tumor targeting, cell-penetrating antibody that directly inhibits the DNA repair factor, RAD51, and thereby suppresses homology-dependent DNA repair, sensitizes cancer cells to radiation, and mediates synthetic lethality to cancers with mutations in the BRCA2 and PTEN genes. We will do so by a combination of structural, biochemical, cell-based and animal tumor studies to increase the antibody’s ability to inhibit RAD51. This proposal will leverage complementary expertise of the two principal investigators in structural biology of DNA binding proteins and macromolecular machines (Bleichert) and in DNA repair, tumor biology and pre-clinical development of cancer therapeutics (Glazer).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: A region found on the midline of the front of the brain, area 25, communicates with areas in the temporal lobe. Balance in this network is disrupted in mood disorders, which emerge early in some young athletes who engage in contact sports. Repeated impact to the head leads to the serious and progressive disease of chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE). The proposed research will study the frontal and temporal network to examine how CTE starts and progresses in humans. Information from this study will provide the foundation to develop rational therapeutic methods when the first signs of the disease emerge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) prevents death by supporting the failing heart or lungs and allowing time to heal; -1/3 of ECMO patients do not survive and major neurological injury is common in survivors, leading to long-term neurological deficits. The resulting financial cost and reduction in quality of life place enormous burdens on patients, their families, and society. There are currently no brain monitors which allow clinicians to dynamically adjust ECMO parameters to prevent neurologic injury; the proposed research will demonstrate that continuous quantitative optical monitors of cerebral autoregulation predict neurological injury and inflammation, enabling future development of neuroprotective ECMO protocols.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Collegiate recovery programs provide support for students in recovery from addiction as well as students seeking to recover. They’ve spread rapidly, but little is known about their availability, effectiveness, best practices, and utilization. In this project, I will describe collegiate recovery programs, identify their core elements, chart their national spread and draw conclusions about how they can be scaled up and evaluated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Age-related muscle atrophy and contractile dysfunction have been well described at the cellular level, but the molecular mechanisms that contribute to this dysfunction are poorly understood. Improved understanding of these mechanisms is critically important for the improvement of physical rehabilitation in older adults at risk for mobility impairment and physical disability. Our studies will pursue pre-clinical evidence that post translational modification of specific proteins in skeletal muscle lead to an “aging phenotype” in skeletal muscle that may unlock new strategies for improving physical function in older adults with physical frailty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: In old age, apathy is a strong predictor of cognitive decline and dementia, and is associated with increased burden of ADRD-related brain characteristics. However, its role as a marker for incipient dementia in midlife, a critical time point for intervention, has not been studied. This study will investigate the cognitive and ADRD- related brain correlates of apathy components (based on subjective and objective measures) in middle-aged, cognitively normal offspring of ADRD patients, and is anticipated to enable the development of apathy as an accessible behavioral screening tool for identifying individuals at high risk for ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The obesity epidemic has led to an increased risk for youth to develop type 2 diabetes, particularly during puberty and in minority populations. There is a need to comprehensively understand the underlying pathophysiology of T2D progression in youth to identify those at the highest risk for developing T2D as well as any modifiable exposures and determinants of T2D progression and how these factors differ regarding sex or race/ethnicity. With the power of this large clinical consortium, the development of a structured risk score analysis can be achieved to help identify youth at the greatest risk and optimize interventions during this critical developmental period designed for long-term prevention of type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune-mediated inflammatory diseases of the intestines, such as IBD, are mediated by CD4 T cells with poorly restrained reactivity to the enteric microbiota. Here, we will advance understanding of mechanisms that control the development of peripheral regulatory T (pTreg) cells into mature, effector Treg (eTreg) cells that can act therapeutically to reverse intestinal inflammatory disease. We expect that results from these studies will our proposal will establish new biological paradigms and inform interventions to curb pathogenic immunity to the microbiota in IBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT This study will examine how metabolism within specific host organs and the resulting metabolites within those host environments affect the virulence potential of Fusobacterium nucleatum, a key colonizer in the development of dental plaque and a pathogen linked to both pre-term birth and colorectal cancer. A better understanding of these host-pathogen relationships is needed to unveil critical new targets for developing anti-infective therapies so as to treat and prevent significant diseases that are associated with this pathogen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) is a disorder of development of the neural retina and its vasculature that can impact vision in vulnerable preterm neonates for a lifetime. This study utilizes high-speed optical coherence tomography (OCT) technology at the bedside of very preterm infants in the intensive care nursery, to characterize previously unseen abnormalities that can lead to poor visual development or can be indicators of poor neurological development. Our long-term goal is to help improve preterm infant health and vision via objective bedside imaging and analysis that characterizes early critical indicators of ROP and its response to treatment, poor visual function and neurological development, which will rapidly translate to better early intervention and improved future vision care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Understanding how microbes may regulate the expression of virulence factors when directly encountering another cell type requires single-cell resolution however there are many technical and biological barriers to achieving this for bacteria. Here we propose to leverage a recent breakthrough in single-cell transcriptomics (scRNAseq) that has been developed for prokaryotes designated MicroSPLiT to study these cell-cell interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Tuberculosis (TB) remains a leading cause of death from infectious diseases globally. Understanding why some infected individuals develop disease and others do not is paramount to developing preventative treatments. We discovered an unexpected association between TB susceptibility and inhibition of tyrosine metabolism, which could be leveraged as a novel target for preventative therapy against TB progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public heath because activation of the complement system contributes to injury in a wide range of kidney diseases. Standard immunosuppressive drugs are not effective at preventing injury by the complement system, and complement-targeted drugs increase the risk of infection. The therapeutic agents tested in these experiments may offer an important new approach to treating renal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Loss of limbal stem cells or destruction of the limbal stem cell niche can result in limbal stem cell deficiency, a common cause of vision loss in the world. The two Aims of this proposal will: mechanistically dissect the role of FGF7, BMP2 and AXL in the LSC maintenance using murine and human genetically engineered experimental models (Aim 1) and will test the therapeutic potential of targeting these pathways for the treatment of LSCD in pre-clinical murine disease models (Aim 2). Successful completion of  this study will further advance our understanding of LSC development, maintenance, and regulation with significant implications  for clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Memory impairment is a core, disabling feature of schizophrenia, yet we lack effective treatments. While most studies of memory focus on active learning, it is now clear that much of memory formation happens without conscious awareness, during restful wake and sleep, and depends on a deep brain structure called the hippocampus. The primary objectives of the proposed research program are to test the hypotheses that in schizophrenia, hippocampal dysfunction gives rise to offline memory deficits and can be treated with closed-loop auditory stimulation during sleep (CLASS), a novel, noninvasive brain stimulation technique that can be implemented at home.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Mutations in the metabolic enzyme IDH1 cause epigenetic deregulation, suppress cellular differentiation and define the majority of grade II, III gliomas and the glioblastomas that progress from these lower grades. Treatment with demethylating and other drugs demonstrates benefit in orthotopic IDH1 mutant animal models. This project goal is to further preclinical development of combination therapy for recurrent IDH1 mutant gliomas, including therapies suitable for early intervention to halt progression, and define which molecular mechanisms are responsible for response to therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid related deaths have become the leading cause of death among postpartum women through 12 months after delivery; treatment for opioid use disorder with medications and behavioral therapies reduce overdose risk and improve outcomes, but treatment continuation and its effectiveness at strengthening recovery de- creases rapidly after delivery. This career development award will gather patient reported data to guide revi- sions of a pre-existing battery of measures intended to capture an individual’s multidimensional profile at the pregnancy to postpartum transition feasibly in a clinical environment. We will then assess how mechanisms of recovery vary across these profiles through 1 year after delivery in order to inform subsequent clinical trials of individualized treatment regimens for postpartum women with opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The purpose of this training program is to provide a short-term, intensive research experience related to hearing, vestibular, cognition, and/or speech/language sciences for audiology doctoral (AuD) students. The overarching goal is to provide AuD students with the experience and encouragement to consider a PhD or otherwise pursue clinical/translational research careers to address the shortage of clinician-scientists in the field. Regardless of the trainees’ eventual career choice, the research experience obtained through this training program will enhance clinical service delivery to the approximately 48 million individuals in the United States with hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Principal Investigator: Li, Jun  Demyelination removes segments of myelin along the nerve fibers. This pathology occurs in a group of neurological disorders with collectively high prevalence. We will explore treatment to stop the disruption of myelin junctions, preventing myelin from being removed (demyelination). 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Environmental arsenic is a major public health concern, and early life exposure to arsenic from well water or food increases adult risk of developing of psychiatric disorders such as depression and anxiety in adulthood, by unknown mechanisms. This project will test the hypothesis that early life exposure to arsenic increases risk of developing psychiatric disorders by perturbing developmental gene expression in the brain, resulting in persistent glucocorticoid resistance and impeded regulation of neuroinflammation and stress responsivity across the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE Genetic diseases such as dentinogenesis imperfecta, bacterial diseases such as dental caries or fractures represent common public health problems that affect a major part of the population worldwide and impose significant burdens on patients. As dentin regeneration remains elusive, the identification of molecular mechanisms controlling dentinogenesis is of immediate need. The goal of this project is to determine the mechanisms defining dental cell fate early in development and harness this information to develop potential therapeutics for dentin regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Spinal cord injury (SCI) is debilitating neurological condition with limited treatment options, particularly long after injury. We have developed a novel strategy that uses vagus nerve stimulation during upper limb rehabilitation to improve recovery of arm and hand function. In this project, we will develop a system to apply this approach to lower limb rehabilitation and perform a randomized, double-blinded, sham-controlled, study to evaluate the potential of this approach to enhance recovery of walking function in individuals with chronic, incomplete SCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: More than 1.8 million coronary stents are placed annually. Stent thrombosis is a catastrophic mechanism and has a high mortality. Antiplatelet therapy prevents thrombosis but increases bleeding risk. We developed a stent system that provides local antiplatelet activity, obviating the need for systemic therapy to mitigate bleeding risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This research will apply a mixed-methods approach to assess the use and impact of a new generation of misleading descriptors and imagery in combustible tobacco marketing. Research activities (including focus groups, a discrete choice experiment and eye tracking) will focus on identifying the effects of such marketing for cigarettes and cigarillos on attention, product appeal, and risk perceptions of current and susceptible youth and young adult tobacco users, and will inform future research and appropriate regulatory remedies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Hemophilia A results from a deficiency of FVIII-activity and can result in severe bleeding. Head bleeds can be debilitating and joint-bleeds require major medical intervention. The results of our efforts will be a human-centered hemophilia Bluetooth-connected monitoring device, consumable, and app that will provide accurate and easy FVIII and FVIII-like monitoring with the goals of decreasing risk of unexpected bleeding and increasing patient care in all settings for traditional and novel therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Michael W. Beck, Eastern Illinois University Carboxylesterases (CESs) play a key role in the metabolism of many common drugs including aspirin, methylphenidate (Ritalin®), and remdesivir (Veklury®), the first FDA-approved drug to treat COVID-19. The overall metabolic activity of CESs, however, can be drastically different from person to person. This interindividual variability has been shown to influence the metabolism and, in some cases, clinical outcomes of patients treated with drugs that are processed by one of these CESs, CES1. This project will reveal new risk factors for ineffective treatment by CES1-substrate drugs by creating methods that can be deployed to identify drugs and genetic factors that influence CES1 activity through developing chemical probes that can specifically report on CES1 activity in live samples. This will lead to better patient outcomes upon treatment with drugs that are metabolized by CES1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the increased effort to curtail e-cigarette use in young adults, the current public health communication campaign messages may fail to influence young adults’ e-cigarette harm perceptions and behavior. Vapers and non-vapers may trust different health information sources and respond differently to messages based on how they are presented, but little research has examined the effects of these communication principles. The proposed study uses online and in-lab studies (Phase 1) and a randomized trial (Phase 2) to understand the role of using an optimal source (expert and peer) and message presentation type (one sided and two sided) in e-cigarette education messages to increase young adult vapers and non-vapers’ message acceptance and change their vaping behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE  The different cellular compartments of the pancreas have a high degree of plasticity, which, if harnessed, could have important therapeutic applications for beta cell regeneration in type 1 and 2 diabetes. We have discovered stem-like cells in the human pancreas that respond to a naturally occurring growth factor, BMP-7, by proliferating and subsequently differentiating into adult pancreatic cell types, including insulin-producing beta cells. Our proposal aims at the dissection of this phenomenon at the single-cell level using unique samples from type 1 diabetic donors, termed “human pancreatic slices”. These studies are highly relevant to the mission of the National Institutes of Health and may ultimately have a significant impact on public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deficits in social cognition are highly common in mid- and late-life schizophrenia spectrum disorders, significantly contribute to difficulties functioning in the community, and are very difficult to treat. The goals of this study are to characterize social cognitive deficits, evaluate their trajectories in relation to normal and pathological aging, and discover neural markers underlying individual differences in these deficits in mid-late life schizophrenia spectrum disorders. The results of this study are expected to guide the development of better patient stratification strategies and targeted treatment interventions that improve social functioning for individuals living with chronic schizophrenia spectrum disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Exercise promotes skeletal muscle health resulting in protection from disease; however, the cell signaling required for these benefits remains unclear. The skeletal muscle is made up of multiple cell types which need to "talk" to each other to coordinate their activities so that the skeletal muscle can support the increased energy demand of exercise. This proposal seeks to understand the underlying signaling by the vascular endothelium required for the beneficial skeletal muscle responses to exercise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) designates methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) as a serious concern that requires prompt attention because it causes approximately 323,700 infections per year in the US, resulting in 10,600 deaths and an estimated $1.7 billion in total healthcare costs. Synthetic unsaturated fatty acids (uFAs) are attractive candidates to become next-generation antibacterial agents for treating MRSA infections because they can directly kill multi-drug resistant bacteria at very low concentrations. This project will provide the chemical and biological foundations needed for the targeted design of new novel therapeutic options to treat devastating MRSA infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: GSDMs are associated with many human diseases, and deletion of GSDMD significantly decreases pyroptosis and IL-1β secretion, and remarkably protects mice from sepsis. By contrast, activation of GSDMs enhances pyroptosis and may promote anti-tumor immunity. Thus, identification of small molecule GSDM agonists to “engineer” tumor cell death for antigen presentation and for priming the adaptive immune system will have significant impact on potential therapeutics against cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative High amounts of copper ions are toxic to living cells, a property that enables copper ions to kill bacterial pathogens in healthcare facilities and to contribute to human immune defenses. However, bacterial resistance to copper ions threatens their effective use as an antimicrobial metal in environmental settings and in immune control of infectious diseases. Therefore, this proposal seeks to understand a newly identified copper resistance protein in medically relevant bacteria to inform the antimicrobial use of copper in healthcare facilities and to aid in the development of strategies to target bacterial resistance to metal ions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute and chronic air leaks resulting from lung injury or disease can result in significant mortality, morbidity, and healthcare costs, and can be difficult to treat resulting in a critical unmet need for new therapeutic approaches. We have developed a new pleural sealant (lung bandaid) and have compelling pre-clinical data in small and large animal models of pleural injury. The goal of the current proposal is to continue to develop further data in support of engagement with the FDA to develop an IND for initial clinical investigation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Auditory attention is not addressed by aphasia treatment programs because there are no reliable assessments of it. The purpose of this study is to develop a task that reliably measures three separate types of auditory attention in people with aphasia. The findings from this project will lay the foundation for the inclusion of auditory attention targets in aphasia treatment programs, which will subsequently improve how well people with aphasia respond to treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Head and neck cancers rank among the deadliest and most diagnosed cancers globally. Treatment strategies for head and neck cancers are limited, with emerging therapies, such as cancer immunotherapies, showing promising but heterogeneous responses that are poorly understood. This study focuses on understanding how aging-associated changes in the tumor microenvironment contribute to the immune evasive behavior of oral cancer, with the goal of improving clinical outcomes for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to understand the mechanisms by which neurons in the brain regions supporting arm movements communicate with neurons in brain regions supporting eye movements during coordinated behaviors, such as looking and reaching toward an object. We will deploy neural ensemble recordings and behavioral manipulations in non-human primates to dissociate two components of multiregional communication - channel gain and channel modulation. Understanding how channel gain and modulation combine in the mechanisms of multiregional communication will lead to new strategies for neural rehabilitation and support the development of neural prosthetic systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Pulmonary fibrosis is a severe, relentless condition in which lung tissue scarring leads to worsening shortness of breath and lung dysfunction, usually leading to death within several years of diagnosis. In this project, we will use existing and newly generated mouse models of pulmonary fibrosis and human lung samples from pulmonary fibrosis patients to explore the potential utility of a gene therapy approach called AAV-SPL to treat pulmonary fibrosis. The results of this study will set the stage for further development of AAV-SPL gene therapy as a potential one-time treatment for pulmonary fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative: Sexual and gender minority (e.g. lesbian, gay, bisexual, trans, queer; SGM) emerging adults (18-25 years) experience sexual violence at a rate nearly double that of their heterosexual, cisgender peers. SGM emerging adults who receive a negative social reaction after disclosure of SV have increased levels of hazardous drinking as well as negative mental health outcomes. To decrease excessive alcohol use and improve mental health among SGM survivors of sexual violence, we will reconstruct an existing intervention (SSS), with promising but mixed effects in an initial pilot, to be delivered to SGM emerging adults, which aims to improve the social reaction they provide to SGM survivors of sexual violence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE South Asia has the highest suicide rate in the world with important risk profile differences from high-income settings. We will conduct formative research to identify barriers and facilitators to uptake and fidelity of suicide module of the mental health gap action programme and adapt a package of strategies to optimize its use in primary care health facilities to test in a pilot feasibility cluster randomized controlled trial in Nepal. Potential health impacts may be substantial as results can be applied not only in similar South Asian primary healthcare contexts, but also in low-resource settings in the US and abroad, where the suicide burden remains high.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) causes substantial morbidity and mortality in humans. It has become apparent that, even as most people have developed an immune response to the virus either from infection or vaccination, long term sequelae of the infection will be a burden on human health for years to come. This project will examine long term effects of the infection in the olfactory system and brain, with the ultimate goal of identifying novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The prognosis for GBM patients remains dismal and there is an urgent unmet need for novel therapies. The first oncolytic virus to be approved by the FDA is an oncolytic HSV whose use is prescribed for melanoma patients is HSV-1 derived. Japan has also recently conditionally approved use of an oncolytic HSV for GBM patients. Thus, there is a lot of interest in developing this treatment modality. We propose to create and optimize a mouse model that will be sensitive for HSV-1 and recapitulates genetic background of brain tumors, in an immune competent mouse model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Issues investigated in this project are of considerable importance to public health as air pollution is both a widespread yet modifiable risk factor for mental illness. By better understanding the long-term neuropsychiatric effects of PM2.5 exposure, including the specific aspects of psychopathology and the brain that are most affected from developmental exposure, we may gain insight into the full societal burden of air pollution while also identifying neural and molecular targets for interventions aimed at ameliorating adverse effects of exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Improving the health of all Americans, especially in the area of chronic diseases such as cardiovascular disease, pulmonary disorders and related conditions, relies on a strong diverse biomedical workforce that is prepared to address these health problems through basic and translational research. Our program trains talented undergraduates from groups underrepresented in biomedical science using a philosophy based on findings from educational scholarship and focused on health issues related to the NHLBI mission. We offer an intensive summer research experience supplemented with workshops in scientific skills, group activities that enhance self-actualization as scientists, career exploration and social events that encourage belonging, thereby preparing our trainees for advanced study in biomedical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Learning deficits, poor school performance, and psychopathologies are documented effects of childhood lead exposure. Our proposed studies integrate molecular-cellular, network and circuits, brain volume and connectivity, and cognitive/behavioral approaches to provide a comprehensive understanding of neurobiological mechanisms by which lead exposure results in cognitive function deficits and risk of psychiatric disease. We are also assessing the flavonoid nutraceutical 7,8-dihydroxyflavone as an intervention to improve cognitive and neuropsychological deficits associated with childhood lead exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Modern non-tobacco oral nicotine pouches with pH adjusted to enhance sensory experience and appeal of high- nicotine products may appeal to young people. The proposed project will conduct two double-blinded within- subject randomized clinical trials to examine the effects of nicotine concentration and pH and their interaction effects on behavioral responses such as sensory experience, product appeal, and abuse liability of nicotine pouches in young adult dual users of nicotine pouches and e-cigarettes. The results of the proposed research will be significant because it will complement current research on regulation targets with actionable insights on the modifiable factors related to initiation and use of a novel class of oral nicotine products.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The interactions between hippocampal and cortical circuits play a critical role in the process of memory formation, and dopamine influences memory processing by signaling the motivational salience of stimuli. The proposed project seeks to characterize the circuit mechanisms underlying the modulation of cortical networks by hippocampal inputs and dopamine across learning. A deeper understanding of hippocampal-cortical interactions and their neuromodulation may provide the foundation for identifying circuit elements that are selectively misregulated in memory disorders, such as Alzheimer's disease.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Project Narrative  We propose to transform our current MD/PhD program into a robust LEAD MSTP through a combination of strongly supportive new leadership in the University of New Mexico Health Sciences Center, increased institutional financial support, and the proposed MSTP support. This Multiple PI/PD proposal will build on strong predoctoral training in the Biomedical Sciences Graduate Program to incorporate training opportunities in Health Equity Sciences, Bioengineering, and Computational Sciences. The University of New Mexico LEAD MSTP will provide a student-centered, integrated training experience that builds on past successes to develop exceptional, diverse clinician scientists who are prepared to address difficult issues in translational research and health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This regional and national research network is relevant to the NIH/ NINDS mission of offering every eligible patient an opportunity to participate in a Stroke Net network trial, to result in improved public health. The short- term benefits of optimizing networks and maximizing efficiencies of stroke clinical trial performance will yield long-term benefits of having more trials across the spectrum of stroke care (prevention, treatment, recovery) completed faster, yielding more treatment opportunities for all. These benefits, coupled with an active career development program, will result in a sustained network with researchers that can further forward a cutting- edge NIH stroke trial portfolio.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CMV infection is a leading cause of congenital birth defects and both solid-organ and bone-marrow transplant failures and is a major unmet medical need due to resistance to current antiviral therapeutics. This project will lay the foundations for a new class of antivirals that disrupt viral transcriptional feedback circuits, a ubiquitous biological regulatory mechanism utilized by many viruses. This therapeutic strategy could enable new classes of drugs targeting diverse feedback circuits, which are hypothesized to have a high barrier to the evolution of drug resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE: Sepsis is a life-threatening condition caused by body’s overwhelming response to infection. For patients who survive sepsis, more than 50% develop neurocognitive dysfunction and memory loss. The goal of the proposed study is to examine the role of brain inflammation in neurocognitive dysfunction in sepsis and to identify potential therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative A major question in photobiology is how ultraviolet B radiation (UVB)-treated skin sends systemic signals. This project applies multiple well-established techniques and approaches at clinical, cellular and molecular levels to investigate the involvement of the lipid mediator Platelet-activating factor in UVB-induced microvesicle particle release which could be the transmitter for systemic signaling effects. These studies have significant therapeutic implications and will provide novel insights and targets into processes from photosensitivity disorders to medical phototherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: The current SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had devastating consequences, with more than 110,000,000 cases and 2,400,000 deaths worldwide. Although we have made remarkable strides developing and delivering vaccines designed to protect against SARS-CoV-2 infection, there are a number of unanswered questions regarding efficacy and potential side effects of vaccination in understudied patient populations with underlying autoimmune disease. In this proposal, we will use novel methods of autoantibody detection and a combination of patient reported outcome measures (PROs)/physician assessments in a prospective cohort of rheumatic disease patients undergoing SARS-CoV-2 vaccination to evaluate the relationship between anti-viral immune responses, formation of self-reactive antibodies, change in disease activity, and development of new autoimmune clinical manifestations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Summary/Abstract Activation of αvβ3 integrin on podocytes is thought to be an early pathological process in the development of kidney disease, especially FSGS and DN. Based on the newly discovered renoprotective role of ICOSL in early kidney disease, we aim to define the precise mechanistic action of ICOSL and its therapeutic potential in this proposal. The successful completion of our proposed study will provide novel and safe avenues for the treatment of glomerular disease, where αvβ3 integrin activation is involved.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: With constant advances in our understanding of cellular repair processes, the questions asked by the radiation biology community are increasing in complexity, creating a dire need for a multi-disciplinary computational tool to help a) interpret existing experimental results and b) design promising new ex- periments. TOPAS-nBio is a Monte Carlo platform specifically developed to connect research disci- plines, to simulate the initial energy deposition events (physics), followed by the diffusion and reaction of chemical species (chemistry) to infer biological observables at the cell and organelle scale (biolo- gy). The TOPAS-nBio features developed in the previous funding cycle have already been well re- ceived by the research community. The new developments of TOPAS-nBio will offer mechanistic out- come predictions from the initial radiation track structure for various cell types for in vitro and in vivo experiments, and thereby drive hypothesis generation at the forefront of bio-physical research.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Using next-generation multi-scale modeling approaches that integrate structural and systems considerations, we propose new frameworks for identifying optimal combinations of clinically available RAF, MEK and ERK kinase inhibitors in melanoma and colorectal cancer. We combine modeling and experimental approaches (in vitro and in vivo) to define rules for predicting how to apply these drugs in specific cancers for more durable inhibition of oncogenic ERK signaling in RAF- and/or RAS-driven cancers – thereby limiting or delaying treatment resistance.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Frequency and severity of Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) are higher among Veterans, creating needs for TBI rehabilitation that could last a lifetime. Clinical study is hindered by small sample sizes, high variability, low data output, and a lack of experimental control. We utilize a swine model that can uniquely recreate the mechanisms and manifestations of human TBI, but moderate-to-severe injuries have not been studied beyond the acute time period – too short to represent the challenges inherent in brain injury rehabilitation in our Veterans. In the proposed project, I will extend studies of moderate TBI into long-term, Veteran-relevant recovery and rehabilitation phases, establishing the first translational model of moderate TBI Rehabilitation and Recovery. I will christen this model with studies testing the efficacy and mechanisms of regular exercise or dietary branched-chain amino acids during brain injury rehabilitation. This project will advance our understanding of neurorehabilitation and facilitate my transition to an independent VA investigator.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Repetitive mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) caused by blast effects of explosive devices is the “signature injury” of Soldiers, Marines, and other Servicemembers who served in the Iraq and Afghanistan conflicts and may have devastating personal, professional and domestic consequences. The proposed project will use sophisticated brain imaging techniques and measurement of chemicals in spinal fluid (the fluid surrounding the brain) and in blood plasma to identify objective markers of mTBI. These markers will help to improve the diagnosis of mTBI in Veterans of the Iraq and Afghanistan wars and improve Veterans' health care. A long- term goal is to determine the risks of repetitive blast trauma mTBI for progressing to such fatal dementing disorders as Alzheimer's disease or the mid-life dementia that has been found in professional boxers and football players, and the role that neuroinflammation and vascular disturbance may play in such outcomes.

PHR: We propose to create an Implant Registry capturing implant therapy that is provided by practitioners within the NDPBRN. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Many western U.S. cities have poor air quality during colder months; we will improve existing air quality models to better identify the origin of these pollutants. We will estimate associations between these pollutants and acute cardiorespiratory health events in 12 cities. We aim to inform public health interventions, develop new methods for air quality modeling, and better understand the heath impacts of air pollution during colder months in the western U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: A growing number of inherited mutations have been found in the IKM (KCNQ2/KCNQ3) channels that cause epilepsy in patients. We recently determined that lipophilic compounds act on IKM channels with potential antiepileptic effects. We will here test more variants of these compounds on heterologously expressed channels and on human neurons derived from induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSC) expressing wild type and mutated KCNQ2 and KCNQ3 channels to establish which variants of these compounds can become new antiepileptic drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Soft Tissue Sarcomas (STSs) are a rare group of mesenchymal tumors in adults that are resistant to conventional treatments such as chemotherapy, due to their extensive heterogeneity. A common feature in many soft tissue sarcomas is altered cellular metabolism due to downregulation of the rate limiting enzyme in the formation of glucose. The proposed research will explore the mechanisms of how re-expression of this enzyme effects STS progression, providing more mechanistic insight for novel sarcoma therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The majority of muscle cells in the heart, unlike most other cells in the body, contain more than the standard two copies of DNA, with these extra copies frequently located within additional nuclei within the cell. Research on this phenomenon has typically focused on its relevance to the low rate of cell division see in this type of cell and its implications for heart health, but exciting, recently published results suggest that the separate nuclei within these muscle cells may be combining together in a nuclear ‘code’ that informs the nature of the resulting cell and its resistance to stressors such as heart attacks. This Steven I. Katz proposal will result in the identification of the elements of this code and its implications with regards to genetic variation and heart attack severity using state-of-the-art experimental approaches and novel computational algorithms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE TRPV3, a representative of the vanilloid subfamily of TRP channels, is predominantly expressed in the skin and implicated in cutaneous sensation, including thermo-sensation, nociception, and itch, in addition to maintenance of the skin barrier, wound healing, and hair growth. The dysfunction of TRPV3 channels, often a result of genetic mutations, is associated with numerous human skin diseases, including a genodermatosis known as Olmsted syndrome, atopic dermatitis, and rosacea. Our goal is to study TRPV3 channels using a combination of biophysical and biochemical techniques and to obtain detailed information about their structure and function that will help develop new drug design strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Our strong preliminary data suggest that there is a subpopulation of wild-type neurons strikingly recapitulating several key phenotypes of familial Alzheimer’s disease (FAD) neurons. This proposal aims further to conduct a set of mechanistic studies to characterize this newly discovered selectively vulnerable cell population and explore the therapeutic potential of the US FDA-approved compounds. The completion of the proposed study will enable the development of novel therapeutic strategies for AD.

PHR: Project Narrative Regulation of gene transcription is fundamental to developmental processes and preventing disease. While enhancers, functional DNA elements that increase gene transcription, little attention has been devoted to silencers, the inverse elements that reduce transcription. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JOHN D DINGELL VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: It has increasingly become evident that obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is negatively associated with adverse neurocognitive consequences. The negative neurocognitive consequences of OSA in the elderly may be compounded by the co-existence of another disorder, chronic obstructive lung disease (COPD). The combined effect of these two highly prevalent diseases, OSA and COPD, also known as Overlap Syndrome, may put the elderly Veteran at increased risk for developing early dementia, poor functional health and poor quality of life. Our goal is to advance the rehabilitative health care of elderly Veterans at increased risk for cognitive impairment and sleep disturbances by evaluating effective treatment pathways, with the aim of improving overall health and quality of life.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Retrotransposons can seriously damage the genome of the nascent embryo and cause sporadic diseases and infertility. Here we will explore a new sensing mechanism that involves early embryonic cells “sniffing” one another for endogenous retroviruses and the removal of cells that failed to silence their genetic parasites. Our line of investigation will provide new targets for genetic diagnosis and interventions targeting pregnancy loss, birth defects and childlessness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative There are currently limited treatment options for improving endothelial dysfunction in vascular diseases, a leading cause of morbidity and mortality. Activated Protein C (APC) is a promising therapeutic that promotes multiple cytoprotective effects including stabilization of endothelial barriers, anti-inflammatory responses and anti-apoptotic activities. The proposed research is important because it will advance the status of APC by understanding the mechanism by which APC activation of protease-activated receptor-1 promotes endothelial cytoprotection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Currently, we know T cell responses become exhausted due to persistent antigen availability; however, how chronic infections impact antigen recognition by T cells is currently unknown. Our work will address this unmet need by determining the kinetics of antigen recognition and the associated phenotypic responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is tightly aligned with the research objectives supported by “Stimulating Hematology Investigation: New Endeavors (SHINE)” program by unveiling Biology and Pathophysiology of Myelodysplastic Syndromes (MDS) and identifying regulatory factors governing function of aged hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells. Our studies will furnish novel insights about how transcription factors and somatic mutations mutually reinforced to shape the genome during aging and results clonal hematopoiesis (CH) and MDS. Our discoveries may establish the rationale for targeting therapeutic vulnerability in the elderly with CH and MDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  The work in this proposal is aimed at elucidating the basic pathogenic mechanisms and the regulatory pathways involved in proteotoxicity and quality control underlying neurodegenerative diseases, including amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal dementia (FTD). Although these diseases are becoming an increasingly relevant public health challenge in our aging society, the mechanisms underlying most of these neurodegenerative conditions remain poorly understood. The biochemical, molecular, and genetic studies outlined in this proposal could lead to novel therapeutic interventions for those neurodegenerative diseases, for which effective treatments are still lacking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) are environmental toxicants of urgent scientific, governmental, and public concern over their near-universal human exposure and adverse health effects. Understanding the effect of PFAS exposure on a couple’s ability to conceive and carry a pregnancy to term is a critical research gap and an important public health goal. The proposed study is designed to determine the effects of paternal and maternal preconception exposure to PFAS on reproductive, pregnancy, and birth outcomes.
