IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Apicomplexan parasites are the causative agents of a number of important human diseases including malaria, cryptosporidiosis, and toxoplasmosis. Our immediate goal is to determine the mechanism by which a parasite-specific molecule regulates the biogenesis and development of the vacuole in which the parasite Toxoplasma gondii survives and replicates. Our long-term goal is to produce fundamental knowledge with the potential to uncover new therapeutic targets for the future treatment of multiple parasitic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Skeletal muscle injuries, in particular irrecoverable volumetric muscle loss (VML) traumas that often damage surrounding nervous and connective tissue, are devastating to a range of civilian and military patients. New tissue engineering approaches are needed to promote both muscle innervation to enable force generation and connective tissue integration at the muscle-tendon junction to allow efficient force transfer and locomotion. This proposal will apply a collagen scaffold mimicking the alignment and electrical excitability of muscle to drive innervated regeneration of complex VML injuries occurring near muscle-tendon junctions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Narrative Glioblastomas (GBM) are lethal brain tumors for which ionizing radiation (IR) remains the mainstay of therapy; however, these tumors inevitably recur, and the recurrent tumors are highly therapy resistant. Using PDX and syngeneic mouse models and human GBM specimens we aim to mechanistically understand how IR promotes GBM recurrence and radioresistance via genetic changes to the tumor cells and senescence-associated changes to the brain microenvironment. We propose to test elimination of senescent cells with “senolytics” as a novel strategy to improve GBM therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) accounts for greater than 50% of all heart failure (HF) cases nationwide, and the prevalence of this form of HF relative to heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) is growing by approximately 10% per decade. The proposed project seeks to determine the regulation and functional consequences of sympathetic nervous system (SNS) overactivity in patients with HFpEF. Findings from this study may provide new information that translates directly into an improved ability to perform activities of daily living, which is likely to lead to improved quality of life and a better prognosis in this patient group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative. Ovarian cancer is the most lethal gynecologic malignancy and the survival rate of women with epithelial ovarian cancer has changed little in the last 30 years. There is an urgent need for new innovative therapeutic strategies. Studies described in our proposal will investigate engineered natural killer cells used in combination with antibody therapies for universal tumor antigen targeting to treat ovarian cancer and other malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A number of differences exist between men and women in adipose tissue development and function, which leads to sex differences in risk, prevalence, and treatment of metabolic diseases. My studies will determine the role of genetic differences between female (XX) and male (XY) animals and cells as a contributor to sex differences in adipose tissue accumulation and function. The physiological impact of these genetic mechanisms will be further investigated to understand how adipose tissue differences drive increased metabolic disease risk in postmenopausal women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE Young adults experience a confluence of major risk factors for alcohol use disorder, including exposure to stressful life events, insufficient sleep, and late sleep timing. This research will use biobehavioral approaches to generate understanding about the linkages between stressful life events, sleep duration and timing, and alcohol use in young adults, with a long-term aim of developing effective preventative interventions for alcohol use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cocoa products, containing high concentrations of flavanols, are widely used and their health benefits have received increasing attention in the medical literature. Promising results from preclinical and clinical studies show beneficial effects of flavanols on muscle and physical performance, but no large, randomized controlled trials have tested effects of supplemental cocoa flavanols on clinically meaningful outcomes among aging adults. This study will determine whether supplemental cocoa flavanols slow age-related declines in physical performance and decrease falls and fall-related fractures (broken bones) that are major public health problems in older women and men in the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will examine the role of circulating microparticles and glymphatic functional changes seen associated with carbon monoxide neuropathology. Studies involve a murine model and a survey of blood samples obtained from patients who are suffering acute carbon monoxide poisoning.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator: LaGrone, Lacey N. Project Narrative The Design for Implementation: The Future of Trauma Research and Clinical Guidance conference series will facilitate alignment of stakeholders in the definition, and early execution, of next steps toward an ideal future state for the evidence-based care of the injured patient. The burden of injury is high, and the current variability in outcomes unacceptable: 47% of deaths among Americans ages 1-46 are due to injury, and a patient is twice as likely to die at the worst performing U.S. trauma center as compared to the best. This dissemination and implementation science initiative, in collaboration with the Coalition for National Trauma Research (CNTR), will increase the rapidity, equity, and effectiveness with which healthcare interventions and guidance inform excellence without exception in the care of the injured patient. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Acute lung injury (ALI) has high mortality because of edema resulting from pulmonary vascular endothelium dysfunction and currently there is no specific treatment for this disease. Healthy endothelial cells prevent edema formation through expression of receptor tyrosine kinase Tie2 and vascular endothelial (VE)-cadherin (VE-cad) to maintain blood vessel barrier integrity. The present investigation will determine how expression of the transcription factor Elf2 in endothelial cells induces the expression of Tie2 and VE-cad needed to repair the injured blood vessel endothelial barrier.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative One of the major challenges in vaccine development is access to adjuvants that promote long lived pathogen specific CD4+ and CD8+ T cell responses and provide protective cell mediated immunity. Our previous studies identified a molecular adjuvant that uses CD40 and TLR agonists that induces protective long lived T cell populations in mice and primates but why this approach is so effective is unclear. Our preliminary data indicate that dendritic cell production of IL-27 activates metabolic changes in recently primed T cells that result in sustained cMyc activation required for this long-lived response. This project will will use intravital imaging of T– DC interactions and the manipulation of IL-27, DC functions and c-Myc pathways to understand the mechanistic determinants that determine the efficacy of combined CD40L/TLR adjuvant. These data sets will be integrated into a stochastic agent-based mathematical model to predict and validate the key events involved in long lived T cell memory formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioids are commonly prescribed analgesics with high addictive potential, but we do not fully understand the signaling pathways that cause analgesia versus addiction. Here, I propose to (1) investigate the spatiotemporal dynamics of one opioid-induced intracellular signaling pathway and (2) define this pathway’s role in analgesia. By identifying key brain regions and cell types in which this signaling occurs and the direct functional consequence of this signaling, this work will extend our understanding of opioid modulation of pain circuitry.

PHR: Project Narrative  Experiencing early life stress or trauma increases the likelihood of developing chronic pain and mood disorders later in life. This is in part due to structural, neurochemical, and epigenetic changes within the brain that regulate the response to stress and the perception of pain. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Restoration of upper extremity function following damage to the central nervous system is a challenge faced by many people, particularly those who have survived a stroke. The proposed research will determine mechanisms controlling bimanual coordination and muscle activation patterns of goal-directed reaching while exoskeleton and virtual reality systems provide an environment that promotes paretic limb use in stroke survivors. The knowledge gained from this work will provide clinicians and researchers technological solutions to therapeutic challenges.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The ability to treat and prevent illness and improve human health requires not only a detailed understanding of the complex interplay of biological systems contributing to disease processes but also the mechanisms underlying the influence of social complexity on biological systems. The systems science approach provides methods uniquely suited to elucidate the mechanisms by which social systems influence health. The proposed research adopts this approach by modeling the short- and long-term effects of social interventions on the multiscale and multilayer networks and their effects on biomarkers of individual health in a well- established nonhuman primate model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative  The average human genome contains ~100 active Long INterspersed Element-1 (LINE-1 or L1) sequences that can mobilize to new genomic locations by a process known as retrotransposition. L1 retrotransposition events in the germ line, during early development, or in somatic cells generate inter- and intra-individual genetic diversity and are implicated in a myriad of sporadic genetic diseases, including Hemophilia A, Duchenne muscular dystrophy, and certain cancers. The goal of this R01 proposal is to use a cultured cell retrotransposition assay in conjunction with an integrative strategy that involves genetic, molecular biological, biochemical, multi- omic, and computational approaches to: (i) elucidate how L1s move to new genomic locations; and (ii) determine how host factors act to restrict or facilitate L1 retrotransposition. This knowledge will provide insights into how L1 retrotransposition contributes to human disease, human genetic variation, and human genome evolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) modulate neuronal activity and synaptic transmission in response to a variety of neuromodulators that regulate learning and memory, cognition, mood, and many other neural processes. However, little is known about how GPCRs integrate different neuromodulatory signals to activate distinct downstream signaling patterns in vivo. Therefore, the proposed experiments will use genetically encoded Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET) -based sensors and optical imaging techniques to monitor cellular and subcellular signaling pathways during the induction of long-term synaptic plasticity and during learned behaviors in ex vivo and in vivo experiments, respectively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Distinct anatomical subregions of the striatum are known to make unique contributions to different aspects of sensor-motor learning, and region-specific striatum dysfunction has been attributed to a range of symptoms in neurological disorders. How cell-type specific striatum dynamics evolve during learning to support adaptive learning is poorly understood. This proposal will advance new optical approaches to determine how distinct output signals evolve across the entire striatum during learning and how they are shaped by ongoing neuromodulatory input, providing fundamental insight into circuit level mechanisms of normal behavior and potential targeted therapeutics for disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent advances in microbial DNA sequencing have identified highly diverse microbial communities in the systemic circulation (a.k.a. circulating microbiome) among patients with chronic inflammatory diseases even without overt infection; however, the characteristics and roles of circulating microbiome in patients with end- stage renal disease (ESRD) remains largely unknown. Our proposed studies aim to determine the levels, composition, and temporal changes of the circulating microbiome and their associations with clinical characteristics and outcomes in ESRD patients. This research will have the potential to discover novel pathophysiologic roles of the circulating microbiome in ESRD, leading to the development of new diagnostic and prognostic biomarkers and target-driven therapeutic strategies to reduce excess mortality risk in ESRD patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: In the US, approximately 90,000 amputations are performed annually as a result of diabetic foot ulceration and the VA currently cares for more than half million Veterans at high risk for amputation. The current standard for prevention of plantar foot ulcers in those individuals is specialty diabetic shoes and custom insoles. The purpose of the custom insole is to cushion the feet, evenly distribute pressures, and to selectively offload areas of increased pressure. Advances in 3D printing, materials, and software have enabled new 3D printed metamaterials whose properties are derived not only from the base material but also from lattice microstructures within the metamaterial. We are proposing to redesign diabetic insoles to use 3D printing with patient specific stiffness and structural behavior. The purpose of this grant is to determine if the 3D printed insoles are better at reducing plantar pressures than the traditional insoles. The results of this study can help reduce annual rates of lower limb loss within our Veteran population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cutting-edge research in Vision Science is increasingly interdisciplinary, and traditional discipline-based Ph.D. programs strain to accommodate this development. The Interdisciplinary Training in Vision Science (ITVS) program at Washington University in Saint Louis provides an integrative model for training 21st century Vision Scientists with a unique set of basic science, translational, and professional skills that effectively position them to produce transformative breakthroughs to understand, preserve, and restore vision. This training grant will support six predoctoral trainees.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Living kidney donors remain a critical source of organs for their loved ones; yet LDKT has decreased substantially since 2004 particularly in the southeastern US. Existing organ donation educational programs have focused primarily on addressing transplant-candidate factors by separating the advocacy role from the candidates; however, these programs have failed to address potential donor concerns regarding comfort with the evaluation process and have relied on resource intense education aides, which are often not readily available in many under resourced, often rural, areas of the southeastern US. It is critical to develop programs that will ensure sustainable increases in living donation independent of geography.

PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The benefit of multipurpose prophylaxis to women with high risk of HIV/STIs infection is significant. Ultra-long- acting injectable formulations providing steady release over several months of antiretroviral drugs in combination with a contraceptive drug can potentially increase compliance to STIs and unplanned pregnancy prophylactic regimen and transform the HIV prevention landscape. The overarching goal of this proposal is to develop and evaluate a first-in-line injectable multipurpose formulation that can contribute to curb the HIV epidemic.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The United States Department of Veterans Affairs spends an estimated $1.5 billion a year on healthcare for patients with diabetes. The prevalence and complications of diabetes increase with age. Therefore, with the aging of the US and Veteran populations, there is an expectation of increased healthcare costs associated with treating diabetes and the associated complications of this disorder. One common complication is the diabetic foot ulcer. Diabetic foot ulcers are expensive to treat, can take a long time to heal and result in a decrease in patient quality of life. Patients remain susceptible to developing more foot ulcers over time. The goal of this project is to reduce the time it takes to heal a diabetic foot ulcer, increase the time between episodes of ulceration and improve the quality of life for diabetic foot ulcer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Young transgender women are at exceptionally high risk for HIV infection and need innovative HIV prevention interventions that to reduce HIV incidence within this group. LifeSkills Mobile is an mHealth intervention to promote biobehavioral HIV prevention strategies based on empowerment theory and was developed using a community-based participatory research approach. We previously demonstrated the efficacy of Project LifeSkills (the only “best evidence” HIV risk reduction intervention for YTW included among the CDC’s compendium of evidence-based interventions), a group based, face-to-face delivered HIV prevention interventions for YTW, and the adapted it to an online-delivered, mobile app platform (containing 4 online modules). We propose to test the efficacy of LifeSkills Mobile in the current application; given inherent limitations to widespread dissemination of face-to-face, group-based interventions, LifeSkills Mobile extends the potential reach of the intervention via the development of a mobile version, and provides content on, and access to, current biobehavioral prevention technologies (e.g., PrEP).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative  Cross-linking mass spectrometry (CLMS), a powerful technique for determining protein conformational structures, lacks capability for absolute quantitation of cross-links (i.e., cross- linked peptides). This proposal aims to develop a novel absolute quantitative cross-linking mass spectrometry (aqCLMS) based on the combination of CLMS with coulometric mass spectrometry (CMS). We also propose to apply aqCLMS, coupled with advanced molecular dynamics (MD) simulation, to study dynamic conformations of PROTAC-mediated ternary complexes for improved accuracy for their structural determination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Molecular and cellular mechamisms that regulate the formation and maintenance of vascular lumen, or tubulogenesis, are poorly understood. The proposed study will investigate the functional role of an evolutionarily conserved novel adaptor protein Src homology 2 domain containing E (She) and its interaction with Abelson (Abl) kinase signaling pathway in regulating vascular lumen size in zebrafish embryos and human vascular endothelial cells. We will further explore the potential application of SHE as a tool to normalize vascular lumen size in human venous malformation. The acquired knowledge will promote development of new strategies aimed at treating vascular malformations as well as bioengineering new vessels for regenerative therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Protein kinase inhibitors are prominent components in the treatment of cancer and inflammatory diseases. Using unbiased functional genomic screening and unique genetic mouse models, we have found that kinase inhibitor mediated off-target inhibition of heme biosynthesis enzyme ferrochelatase contributes to toxicity in normal tissues. Our proposed studies aim to elucidate the molecular mechanisms that drive kinase inhibitor linked toxicities and could result in identification of potential mitigating strategies, which has high translational significance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Organisms adapted to extreme environmental conditions hold natural solutions to many human diseases. The long-term goal of this project is to understand the cellular adaptations sustaining life in the absence of oxygen. This work will lend insight into cellular manipulations that may extend human life during heart attack, stroke, and organ transplantation, as well as in the face of neurodegenerative diseases and diseases associated with mitochondrial mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Overall Component This application would initiate a Center of Biomedical Research Excellence (COBRE) at Boys Town National Research Hospital in Omaha, Nebraska, with a focus on pediatric neuroscience, developmental neuroimaging, and brain health. The Center for Pediatric Brain Health would include an Administrative Core that oversees a series of integrated support programs, an advanced Neural Quantification & Imaging Core Facility, a Supervisory & Mentoring Committee, four COBRE research project leaders, and an established cohort of senior investigators. The Center would leverage major recent growth in staff and facilities through Boys Town’s pediatric neuroscience initiative, and continue the organization’s mission to change the way America cares for children and families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding human mental health disorders requires a basic understanding of the nervous system. It is critical to understand how neuronal connections are built during development and how neural circuits function in the adult. This study seeks to understand at a molecular-genetic level how the potential for behavior is built into the nervous system. These studies will proceed with analyses in a multi-cellular organism, so we can interrogate the role of genes, proteins and neural circuits in a functionally relevant context to gain insight in how a circuit for a complex behavior is built and functions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Enhancers are regulatory DNA sequences that underly a wide variety of human diseases when misregulated because they determine when and where a target gene will be expressed. Because these sequences are critical for driving proper spaciotemporal target gene expression during development and cellular transitions, they are maintained in an inaccessible and inactive state until the precise context for gene activation is reached. This study aims to characterize how enhancers are made accessible and active by DNA-binding proteins during embryonic development, which will provide mechanistic insight into how cells regulate enhancer activity to control their gene expression programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Blood vessels play an important role in the regulation of arterial blood pressure and precise blood pressure regulation requires coordination between vasodilator and vasoconstrictor signals in the endothelium and smooth muscle. Our data support the concept that PPARγ acts as a sensor in endothelium to regulate redox state, and through this, bioavailability of nitric oxide, and regulates the responsiveness of the smooth muscle to nitric oxide by independently controlling a RhoA/Rho kinase (ROCK) activity that promotes constriction, and production and stability of cyclic GMP (cGMP), a critical mediator of vasodilation. This proposal will delineate a vision for the next seven years of research elucidating molecular and physiological mechanisms controlling vasomotor function, arterial stiffness and BP by PPARγ and Cullin-3.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Donor organ shortage in transplantation can be greatly mitigated by a clear mechanistic understanding of early allograft inflammation that restricts our ability to utilize donor kidneys with prolonged cold ischemia and our ability to effectively induce transplant tolerance. Our preliminary studies suggest that the donor kidney resident macrophage population is a critical mediator of this process. The overall goal of this proposal is to mechanistically define the role of donor kidney resident macrophages in this process, and to design clinically feasible therapies targeting this population for enhancing short-term kidney allograft function and long-term kidney allograft survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma is the most common and aggressive primary brain tumor in adult which is defined by a hypoxic niche that drives resistance to therapies and promotes tumor growth. Our data indicates this niche is fueled by creatine delivered by infiltrating immune cells. In this proposal we seek to understand the role of creatine in promoting GBM growth and if creatine metabolic inhibition is a useful strategy by which we can hinder GBM growth and recurrence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Keratinocyte carcinoma afflicts approximately 3 million Americans annually, and its treatment is among the costliest of all cancers. Keratinocyte carcinomas derive from epidermal keratinocytes, but diverge along two distinct oncogenic pathways, giving rise to two distinct phenotypic tumors, basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma. This project will identify genetic loci that affect the risk of keratinocyte carcinoma, examine how environmental risk factors influence genetic risk, and determine whether these loci act to influence the risk of basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, or both.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Obesity affects more than one-third of the US population generating a need for novel interdisciplinary strategies to resolve growing obesity related negative health outcomes. Advanced mathematical methods play a critical role on numerous fronts in obesity research, from evaluating the effect of population-wide obesity prevention policy measures to monitoring participants during lifestyle intervention studies. The proposed course will develop connections between mathematical scientists and obesity researchers to address research challenges with novel quantitative approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will examine the vestibular receptor morphology, neural physiology, and VOR response behavior in blast exposed animals during a long period of recovery. We wish to understand if/how low levels of single blast exposure result in vestibular damage and how such damage contributes to vestibular behavioral dysfunction. We believe these studies are significant, timely, and will help to provide key insights into blast related vestibular injury that produces problems with balance, visual stability, and dizziness in people.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative This project will provide the first systematic and population-based documentation of primary care inequities faced by sexual minority people of color, an understudied population that experiences significant and persistent health disadvantages. Findings will contribute to the understanding of unique barriers to care among specific socially disadvantaged groups and the improvement of their access, quality, and equity of care. The project will inform evidence-based interventions in clinical practices and public health measures to reduce health care and health inequities at the intersection of sexual orientation and race/ethnicity.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Understanding primary care utilization and barriers to care among sexual and racial/ethnic minority populations

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Recent studies have highlighted defects in insulin processing and granule maturation that are linked to all major forms of diabetes; however significant conceptual gaps remain in our fundamental understanding of the causes of beta-cell dysfunction. We hypothesize that Phosphatidylinositol transfer protein alpha (PITPNA) is a key regulatory node that is required to maintain proper insulin production, granule formation and secretion and that restoring PITPNA levels in islets of T2D subjects will reverse beta-cell dysfunction including impaired insulin secretion and ER stress. These studies aim to highlight restoration of PI4-P between intracellular membranes as an innovative approach for increasing granule maturation and secretion as well as reversing beta-cell failure in major forms of diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes significant mortality and morbidity in immunocompromised populations including transplant and AIDS patients and the fetus in utero. Congenital CMV infection causes mental retardation, vision impairment and deafness in surviving newborn and there is no vaccine or intervention strategy. The research will evaluate the correlates of immunity/protection against cCMV by various vaccines strategies and utilize a novel gene knockout animal to determine the significance of type III IFN response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative The goal of this grant is to understand the mechanisms of conversion of 'repaired' wounds (fibrotic) into regenerative wounds in mammalian wound healing models and to understand the sometimes divergent regenerative capability of mice vs humans. This proposal is based upon our remarkable finding that ectopic Sonic Hedgehog signaling in 'repaired' hairless murine wounds can induce de novo hair follicle regeneration. The resulting proposal based on this finding has profound implications for understanding the regenerative and developmental biology of hair follicles as well as in defining future directions for skin regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative: Current therapies for glomerular diseases including diabetic kidney disease are non-targeted and offer limited therapeutic benefit, which has created a tremendous unmet clinical need. In the current proposal, we show that enhancing levels of Rap1 activation in specific kidney cells, called podocytes, protects them from injury and mitigates disease progression. As a novel therapeutic approach, we have developed Rap1 agonist compounds that specifically target podocyte-enriched upstream Rap1 regulatory elements, allowing for potent Rap1 activation in podocytes but avoiding potential off-target effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) and its aggressive subtype, metaplastic carcinoma (mBrCA), are over 4-fold more frequent in African Americans, and have high metastatic potential. This grant will address a novel mechanism of breast cancer metastasis by investigating how cytoplasmic phosphorylated EZH2 induces dissemination. Our studies, including work with unique tissue samples, may discover prognostic and diagnostic biomarkers of metastasis and reduce health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE In this study we will compare short- and long-term harm reduction and abuse liability potential (i.e., withdrawal, craving, dependence) of a NSPS EC in African American exclusive EC, dual cig-EC, and exclusive cig users, characterize factors that predict who switches fully, partially, or not at all, and examine if harm reduction can be further enhanced by treating dual users with varenicline to eliminate cigarette smoking. Findings have the potential to support EC as a harm reduction strategy among a disparate group that arguably stands to benefit from it the most, contribute to the overall goal of reducing tobacco-related morbidity and mortality, and narrow the health disparity gap for AA smokers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: This project aims to delineate a novel regulatory loop of small RNA molecules, called microRNA that can impose regulation on gene expression, on B cells that are found in adipose tissue during obesity. Our team will test the idea that this circuit of regulation between microRNA and B cells in fat tissue is a major mechanism that controls the damaging inflammation. We postulate that understanding this process will lead to important therapeutic opportunities to treat metabolic disease that result from obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The cholecystokinin-B (CCK-BR) receptor becomes over-expressed in chronic pancreatitis, a condition that increases the risk for pancreatic cancer 8-fold. Strategies to reprogram the ‘at-risk’ pancreas and its microenvironment after pancreatitis to a normal phenotype may prevent the development of pancreatic cancer. This investigation will examine the mechanisms by which blockade of the CCK-BR with an antagonist, proglumide, affects 3 separate compartments involved pancreatic carcinogenesis including the epithelial cells, the stellate of fibroblasts, and the immune cells to render the pancreas less oncogenic and resume a normal phenotype.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study will encompass a comprehensive investigation of the cardiometabolic in utero environment and its association with cardiovascular health (CVH) and arterial injury in young-adult offspring. Findings will give insights into 1) the burden of poor CVH and arterial injury at this critical time of life when cardiovascular disease risk may progress and interventions may slow further progression, 2) timing for future interventional studies in pregnancy and markers to follow to assess effectiveness and 3) novel mechanisms of the passage of cardiometabolic risk from mothers to their children, allowing for potential new targets for intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Telomeres shorten with age in most human somatic cells, and while their initial length pre-determines cellular lifespan, the exact nature of factors establishing telomere length set point remains elusive. We will elucidate the genetic and epigenetic architecture of telomere length control and uncover novel pathways modulating natural telomere length polymorphism using the unique biological, genomic and epigenetic resources in the genetically facile plant Arabidopsis thaliana. Because modes of telomere regulation are highly conserved between eukaryotes, our data may provide important insights into the molecular basis for variation in the predisposition to telomere-associated stem cell, cancer and age-related diseases among different individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: The proper regulation of gene expression is essential for the development and health of all organisms. Our work advances the study of how DNA, found as chromatin, plays an integral part in gene regulation (transcription initiation and gene splicing. This knowledge will help guide the development of diagnostic and therapeutic tools, e.g., built upon knowledge of alternative splicing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Species are diverse, and the genetic basis of this diversity and how it is encoded in the genome is important to understanding many aspects of biology. The investigation will identify and characterize genes that cause yeast species to survive and grow at different temperatures. Doing so will provide general insight into complex adaptive differences between species and specific insight into the evolution of thermotolerance, a characteristic relevant to many human pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Our recent cross-sectional findings suggest that chronic pain is associated with multiple biological aging biomarkers where a greater pain burden is associated with accelerated aging processes. Thus, the goal of the proposed study is to determine the brain and bodily aging mechanisms whereby pain prospectively impacts function in aging and whether these are different across racial/ethnic groups. Findings will contribute towards increased understanding of pain and biological aging processes, with the potential to reduce race/ethnic group disparities and improve pain-related health outcomes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescents may experience manic symptoms that may or may not progress into bipolar disorder. This proposed longitudinal study would be the first of its kind and could shed light on the neural and behavioral markers of disease progression in high-risk adolescents with manic symptoms. Identifying such markers for bipolar disorder has important clinical implications such as improving early detection of illness and informing treatment planning and personalized interventions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The best predictor of whether an obese adolescent will develop type 2 diabetes is Insulin Resistance, however its pathogenesis remains elusive. Our previous studies clearly established the link between the impaired accumulation of fat in abdominal subcutaneous depot, fatty liver and peripheral insulin resistance in obese adolescents and, we found a greater release of fatty acids from the subcutaneous depots which is strongly linked with fatty liver. Herein, we will focus on determining what might cause the lack of insulin to suppress the release of free fatty acids, causing a perfect storm of insulin resistance to develop in obese adolescents.

PHR: Project Narrative Fibrotic liver diseases induced by chronic viral infection and metabolic disorders cause significant death annually, yet we lack even one approved anti-fibrotic therapy. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The prevalence of severe obesity continues to rise and is strongly linked to many forms of cardiovascular disease; unfortunately, cardiovascular imaging is challenging in these patients as their large size limits accessibility to some imaging modalities, and leads to poor image quality in others, reducing diagnostic accuracy. The use of cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is currently limited by the narrow bore and table weight limits of standard MRI machines operating at 1.5T and 3.0T. In this project, we will develop cardiac MRI techniques for a new, low-field, 0.55T MRI machine with an ultra-wide 80 cm patient bore and 700 lb. table weight limit to provide a robust diagnostic cardiovascular imaging option for severely obese patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infants experience acute physiologic and hormonal responses to pain leading to increased neurologic complications and death, effects which are mitigated by opioid-derived medication. However, opioid use during infancy is also associated with impaired brain development and prolonged hospitalization. In this research, our goals are to identify how variations in pain management strategies impact neurocognitive development and healthcare utilization for critically ill hospitalized infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE At Stanford over the last decade, the Gurtner group has used NIDDK funding to identify the best treatment plans to improve blood flow, decrease blood glucose, and enhance the body's ability to heal wounds and prevent amputations. With Dr. Gurtner recently assuming the position of Chair of Surgery at the University of Arizona (UArizona) College of Medicine-Tucson, the entire team has moved and worked tirelessly to seamlessly transfer all the existing Diabetic Foot Consortium (DFC) studies to UArizona. In this proposal, we will continue these important studies at UArizona to collect a large range of samples from a diverse patient population to improve biomarker identification and standard of care efforts for DFUs, as well as demonstrate our potential for the addition of various satellite sites throughout the Southwest.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Expanding access to medications for opioid use disorder, including buprenorphine for opioid use disorder treatment and naloxone for overdose reversal, is a critical piece in a comprehensive plan for addressing the opioid epidemic. The proposed research will contribute knowledge about existing barriers to integrating evidence-based opioid use disorder treatment in the hospital setting and aims to expand access to buprenorphine and naloxone for hospitalized patients with opioid use disorder. The proposal closely aligns with NIDA’s strategic goal to “to help people with addiction achieve a meaningful recovery”.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The growth plate (or physis) is a cartilage region at the end of all long bones in children that provides signals for bones to lengthen during development; when injured, bony tissue can form in the growth plate, resulting in a “bony bar” that can cause deformities or even completely halt bone growth. This project aims to investigate the development of biomaterial systems that are capable of blocking the angiogenic processes that contribute to the formation of the bony bar. The impact of the extracellular matrix environment on this process will be investigated through the modification of the biomaterial delivery systems with anti-angiogenic peptides and extracellular matrix molecules.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Back pain is frequently associated with degeneration of the intervertebral discs of the spine and places a significant social and economic burden on active duty military, veterans and the general public. Current treatments for disc degeneration, such as spinal fusion, are limited in that they do not restore healthy disc structure or function. The objective of this proposal is to further advance our tissue engineered intervertebral disc replacement technology towards clinical use. This will be achieved via long term studies in a large animal model under clinically relevant conditions, and by in vitro studies utilizing translatable human cell sources for engineered disc fabrication and culture. Overall, the results from this work will drive clinical translation of our tissue engineered disc technology, significantly improving treatment options for veterans suffering from disc degeneration and back pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Infection with influenza virus poses a major global public health concern, as it causes significant morbidity and mortality during annual epidemics and has instigated pandemics by strains to which the human population is naive. Currently licensed influenza vaccines induce suboptimal strain-specific immune responses, requiring yearly reformulation and administration due to antigenic drift and short duration of protection. In this proposal we compare vaccination strategies using a rationally designed mucosal combination adjuvant, consisting of a nano emulsion and synthetic RNA, with established adjuvants to identify if a multi-season as well as a universal influenza vaccine candidate can benefit from the synergistic effects of simultaneous activation of innate immune pathways as measured by improved vaccine efficacy, duration, and breadth in the context of pre-existing immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Staphylococcus aureus persistently colonizes humans which represents the key risk factor for community- and hospital-acquired infections with poor clinical outcomes. We propose that upper respiratory tract clearance of S. aureus is key to curbing invasive disease and will capitalize our investigations by exploiting a mouse model of colonization, and prototype vaccines that neutralize the immune evasion attributes of Staphylococcal protein A and block factors of colonization. We expect to gain insights into B cell responses in mucosal-associated lymphoid tissues and decipher the mechanisms whereby serum and luminal antibodies may promote colonization clearance.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The continued high rate of suicide among Veterans, variable successes with currently available suicide prevention screening methods and interventions, and limited use of precision medicine methods in prior suicide prevention research suggests that the field is overdue for a precision medicine approach to suicide prevention. This agenda will require suicide prevention researchers to be trained in precision medicine methods and have the resources needed to conduct much more sophisticated studies than in the past. The immediate goal of this proposal is to advance this agenda by establishing a VA Suicide Prevention Clinical Resource Center with an explicit focus on promoting precision medicine for suicide prevention. In so doing, we seek to improve individual suicide prevention outcomes, address unsatisfactory response rates for standardized treatments, promote the incorporation of diverse patient presentations, characteristics, and needs into treatment plans, improve system and population-level outcomes, and increase efficient use of finite resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Jumonji histone demethylases are enzymes that drive cancer’s uncontrolled growth and allow cancer cells to adapt to therapeutic toxic stress, surviving it. Here we propose to define how a key Jumonji enzyme in lung cancer gets activated when DNA is damaged with radiation therapy and to find ways to block the activity of this enzyme in order to sensitize non-small cell lung cancers to radiation, overcoming radiation resistance. Our goal is to make lung tumors exquisitely responsive to radiation therapy locally, without any damage to normal tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than one-third of children with epilepsy do not respond to medications and are therefore candidates for epilepsy surgery. Developing a robust tool to identify abnormal brain areas for surgical intervention would be a groundbreaking advancement in treating children with epilepsy. This project aims to investigate promising spatial neurophysiological biomarkers of the epileptic brain known as high-frequency oscillations through a novel deep learning-based approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Emerging data indicate that exposure to relatively low levels of contaminants during pregnancy may adversely affect placental and fetal development. This project will extend our rural U.S. pregnancy cohort to investigate the effects of toxicants in our drinking water and diet on placental features and birth size and generate the necessary knowledge to inform policies and clinical practices geared at improving the health and well-being of women and children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Strategies that can simultaneously improve the function and health of pancreatic beta cells, which produce all of the insulin needed for the body, may be effective against beta cell dysfunction and demise in diabetes. The studies proposed in this application will characterize metabolic mechanisms that render beta cells resilient to stress caused by inflammation, glucotoxicity and oxidative stress. By revealing how beta cell stress response and adaptation is controlled, these studies can help improve strategies to improve the health of beta cells in diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Improved prevention and treatment of major psychiatric disorders in youth is a national priority. This R25 targets the critical transition of postdoctoral fellows and junior faculty without research grant funding to successfully funded researcher through a one-week Research Institute and subsequent year-long mentoring process. Our career development approach is based on the model of other successful Summer Research Institutes that target researchers studying adults and geriatric populations but modified to give greater emphasis on grant design and writing and greater time to small-group and one-on-one mentoring with many of the most senior researchers in this field.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The vast majority of genetic diseases underlying non-immune hydrops fetalis (NIHF) are missed with standard testing, resulting in an undirected approach to care and substantial risk of morbidity and mortality for the fetus, neonate, and pregnant woman. We propose a prospective, multicenter study applying whole genome sequencing, RNA sequencing, and comprehensive pre- and postnatal phenotyping to identify underlying genetic diseases, expand the perinatal phenotypes of those genetic diseases, improve prenatal diagnostic accuracy, and enable targeted clinical management to optimize outcomes during pregnancy and after delivery. Only with this precision approach will we improve the course for fetuses and families encountering NIHF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed activities of the Northeast Node of the National Drug Abuse Treatment Clinical Trials Network (CTN) embrace advances in scientific discovery and research innovations that offer great promise for increasing the reach and effectiveness of treatments for substance use disorders (SUD). These activities reflect a vision for the next iteration of the CTN in the next 5 years. This work will advance translational science in SUD research and markedly reduce the gap between SUD research and clinical practice -- with a focus on scaling-up and sustaining best practices.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative How and which brain neural circuits are modulated by female hormones and consequently regulate emotion and behavior across the hormonal cycle are not well understand. In this project, we propose to examine circuit mechanisms whereby a neural pathway whose connectivity changes with the female hormonal cycle regulates social behaviors. Neural circuit dysfunction is at the heart of common neurodegenerative conditions as well as mental illnesses, and our findings will reveal circuit mechanisms underlying behavioral changes across the female hormonal cycle, and they may have the potential to suggest new avenues for research and interventions in common neuro-psychiatric disorders that are regulated by female hormones.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Social connection during pregnancy is a well-established buffer for prenatal stress known to predict better infant and maternal health in the postpartum period. This study examines how social disruption, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic, affects expectant parents and their subsequent mental health, birth outcomes, and infant development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (OVERALL)  The Vision of the Seattle Tuberculosis (TB) Research Advancement Center (SEA-TRAC) is to facilitate a decrease in the global burden of TB through training and multi-disciplinary research. SEA-TRAC will accomplish this by catalyzing new avenues of research and training a cadre of new investigators that will make a meaningful impact on the TB epidemic. By the end of the funding period, we expect that SEA-TRAC will have achieved several quantifiable objectives and established itself as a flagship TRAC program, leading new initiatives through interactions with other TRACs and the NIH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Relevance/Narrative It has long been established that DPSCs have a high regeneration capacity. Dentin regeneration is the key factor for maintaining tooth preservation following infection or injury. Understanding the biological mechanisms of the odontogenesis/dentinogenesis and the role of inflammation in this process are required for successful DPSC engineering strategies. The scientific knowledge obtained from this project will provide a foundation for creating therapeutic tools that target DPSC during dentin-pulp complex regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Proper regulation of gene expression is essential to the development and health of all organisms. The DNA in each eukaryotic cell, found as chromatin, plays an integral part in this gene regulation (transcription initiation and how genes are spliced to form different protein isoforms). Furthermore, knowing how chromatin structure controls gene regulation in normal development and in response to environmental insults would be helpful for new diagnostic and therapeutic tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stem-like cancer cells are the “roots” of aggressive tumors, as they seed metastasis and recurrence; devising a way to kill this population of cells or prevent them from being generated remains a significant clinical challenge. We identified Oncostatin M as a key driver and maintenance factor for these stem-like cells and as a suppressor of the immune system. Here, we’ll define novel signaling effectors activated by the Oncostatin M Receptor, providing us with an extraordinary opportunity to develop combination therapies aimed at suppressing the generation and maintenance of invasive, drug tolerant cancer cells and activating the immune system to improve current therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Peptide hormones are signaling molecules that are packaged into secretory granules for secretion into the bloodstream by endocrine cells. Intracellular degradation of peptide hormones occurs when secretory granules merge with degradative organelles called lysosomes. This work will analyze a tethering factor called Munc13-4 that directs the merge of secretory granules with lysosomes, which will be relevant for understanding lysosomal storage diseases such as mucolipidosis type IV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance The proposed postdoctoral training program in vision and rehabilitation research will have a positive and direct impact on public health. The program is designed to train fellows to gain a deep understanding of vision and visual impairment to develop novel models of visual function that provide insights into disease prevention, monitoring and treatment, interventions for binocular vision disorders, rehabilitation techniques and assistive devices. Postdoctoral fellows emerging from the program will be able to launch their own independent research careers. Because research at Smith-Kettlewell is motivated by clinical problems, it is highly likely that our fellows will make significant contributions to vision health during and after their training.

PROJECT_TITLE: Postdoctoral Training in Vision Research

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Self-renewal of the intestinal lining continuously generates two major cell types: absorptive and secretory. While the emergence of absorptive enterocytes from intestinal stem cells is increasingly well understood, mechanisms behind the precise designation of diverse secretory cells remain largely unknown. We will use state-of-the-art genetic and molecular tools to investigate how the intestinal lining maintains a proper census of the myriad secretory cell types that serve vital physiologic functions and are often disturbed in inflammatory and other intestinal disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To survive in a changing environment, all cells and organisms must be able to adapt while preserving both metabolic homeostasis and genome integrity. Whether perturbations in genome integrity is sensed by cells to regulate growth factor signaling or DNA repair is not well-understood. Using a powerful viral model system, cutting-edge microscopy, and genomics/proteomics, we will address this current knowledge gap to understand fundamental DNA damage response processes as it relates to genome integrity in different cell types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Drugs are responsible for roughly one-quarter of acute kidney injury (AKI) cases, and antibiotics are implicated in approximately half of these events. Broad spectrum antibiotics are frequently used in hospitalized patients with vancomycin plus piperacillin/tazobactam being one of the most commonly prescribed combinations. Over 20% of patients treated with this combination develop AKI with mechanism postulated to be related to oxidative stress. Targeting the nuclear factor erythroid 2–related factor 2 transcriptional pathway has great potential to up-regulate antioxidant responses and restore mitochondrial membrane potential. This study will evaluate whether melatonin, a hormonal dietary supplement, decreases AKI in a human clinical trial and verify its mechanism in vitro and in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The protein kinase Aurora A binds to and stabilizes the oncogenic transcription factors c-Myc and N-Myc that are key drivers in a large subset of human cancers. This project aims to understand how Aurora A binds to c- Myc and N-Myc and how to disrupt these interactions with Aurora A inhibitors that trigger structural changes to block binding and promote c-Myc and N-Myc degradation in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Healthy cells maintain their DNA within intact chromosomes but in some circumstances such as aging, cells release small linear extrachromosomal DNA fragments that are toxic. Extrachromosomal DNA may result in inflammation and severe diseases and it can be pasted into chromosomal breaks leading to gene inactivation. We aim to understand currently undefined mechanisms of how cells generate small extrachromosomal DNA fragments, an essential step toward designing therapeutic approaches in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Postpartum depression is one of the most common complications of childbirth and is associated with poor maternal/child outcomes. The underlying pathophysiology of postpartum depression is largely unknown, creating an obstacle to developing improved treatments. This study will determine the relationships between sex steroids, brain chemistry and brain circuitry in women with postpartum depression, healthy postpartum women and healthy women during the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle to better understand what causes postpartum depression so that novel treatments may be developed and tested.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed clinical research aims to validate the use of dynamic contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (DCE-MRI) parameters as FDA BEST-defined monitoring biomarkers to monitor the natural history of radiation-associated bone and soft tissue injury and subsequent long-term oral morbidity due to radiation- associated damage (e.g., dry mouth, swallowing difficulty, and jawbone injury/fracture). The work is relevant to public health because of (1) the epidemic rise in HPV-associated oral malignancies, and because this represents (2) the development of the first FDA BEST-defined monitoring biomarker of any kind for oral sequelae of cancer therapy, generally, and the first-ever validated FDA BEST-defined monitoring imaging biomarker of any dental disease process. The innovative research described in this proposal can drive significant change in clinical practice for head and neck cancer by improving survivorship through normal tissue sparing and prevention of long-term toxicity, while maintaining excellent disease control, which always represents a major healthcare challenge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current diagnostic strategies can fail to accurately detect and classify clinically significant prostate cancer, leading to detrimental overtreatment and undertreatment. This research project aims to jointly develop and integrate innovative quantitative magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) techniques and artificial intelligence algorithms to achieve significantly improved accuracy for detection and classification of clinically significant prostate cancer. The new MRI- based artificial intelligence will be a transformative technology to reduce unnecessary prostate biopsies and enhance decision making for patient management to avoid overtreatment and undertreatment of prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative: The overall goal of our research is to uncover the molecular and cellular mechanisms by which mTOR signaling is spatially regulated and to elucidate the contribution of subcellular mTORC1 signaling to tumorigenesis and cancer therapy resistance. Persistent activation of the PI3K/mTOR signaling circuitry is the most frequent dysregulated signaling mechanism in oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC), a disease that results in ~300,000 deaths each year worldwide, with 5-year survival estimates of approximately 60%, despite aggressive multimodality therapies. Unravelling the function and regulation of subcellular mTORC1 signaling should offer a path toward selective targeting of pathway components, yielding therapies with reduced toxicity and resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The purpose of the program is to introduce optometry students to basic, translational, and clinical optometric and vision science research by participating full-time for ten weeks in a summer research project. This experience is aimed at providing a pathway for the most motivated students to continue research in the OD-MS or OD-PhD towards a career as a clinician-scientist. It will also providing the next generation of optometrists the knowledge and skillset to provide the latest and most optimal vision treatment and care to their patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The goal of this proposal is to evaluate the ability of intravital multiphoton microscopy (MPM) imaging to identify and distinguish immune cell populations in human skin, based on label-free molecular contrast. We will utilize a fast, large area multiphoton exoscope (FLAME), an imaging platform recently designed and developed by our group to have unique performance features optimized for clinical skin imaging: macroscopic (mm-scale) scanning area, high speed, subcellular resolution, label-free molecular specificity. Completion of this study will establish the practical utility and value of FLAME as a non-invasive bedside imaging tool to detect early immune reactions, to understand the mechanisms initiating skin autoimmune diseases and to monitor the immune response to skin therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative. In older adults with musculoskeletal pain, both joint pathology and pain have been associated with mobility decline, but the relationship between joint pathology and pain and their unique contributions to mobility decline is more complex, because pain is shaped by a combination of central and peripheral factors. The proposed study goes beyond the characterization of an individual mechanism and integrates multiple fields of study using a biopsychosocial approach to identify the factors that contribute to functional trajectories of mobility decline in aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute lung injury (ALI) and its more severe form referred to as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) are common severe complications of an influenza infection. This complication is a result of the immune system becoming hyper-active and attacking the lung. The research in this proposal will help us understand why in some patients the immune system becomes too active and how one can present severe complications of an influenza infection by targeting the excessive immune response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Over 90% of the cells in the human body are microbes, the majority of which reside in the large intestine, where they provide benefit to the host by providing niche protection against colonization with potentially harmful bacteria, a property known as colonization resistance. Antibiotic therapy is accompanied by a microbial imbalance that leads to a loss of colonization resistance. Here we will study the underlying mechanism by which antibiotic treatment increases susceptibility to potentially harmful bacteria and approaches to restore colonization resistance, which will usher in important conceptual advances that have a strong potential to exert a high impact on this field of science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: Project narrative Overall The Center for Pre-Clinical Cancer Research (Cancer COBRE) aims to identify clinically relevant mechanisms of human cancer disease using models that closely reflect the disease state in the context of the tumor microenvironment. The four PJI projects feature osteosarcoma, breast cancer, liver cancer, and prostate cancer as diseases that would benefit from pre-clinical models that are more predictive of mechanistic efficacy in humans. All of the PJI projects will use specialized in vivo cancer mouse models and/or in vitro 3D spheroids to identify relevant mechanisms of tumorigenesis or for evaluation of novel therapeutic strategies. The Center will promote a unified and coordinated approach by establishing new specialized core facilities 1) Pre-Clinical Evaluation Core (PCEC) to provide scientific expertise and technical support for the pre-clinical evaluation and Molecular Biology and Immunopatholgy Core (MBIPC) to provide access to state-of-the-art equipment and expertise in Molecular Biology and Immunopathology for the PJI projects.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammation contributes to many diseases including autoimmunity and acute liver injury. These diseases involve unique forms of inflammation regulated by RIPK1, which can promote or inhibit inflammation in a context and cell type specific manner. The goal of this proposal is to determine how RIPK1 kinase mediates inflammation that drives human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The Cox regression is the important method for assessing the effects of different factors on the time-to-event outcomes. The project will propose novel approaches to improve the Cox regression estimation. The computing tools based on the proposed methods will improve the scientific rigor and the reporting of findings for clinical studies with time-to-event outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Delirium is a serious, yet understudied, cognitive disorder that affects millions of elder Americans, and is closely related to Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD). The NIA-supported (2015-2020) Network for Investigation of Delirium Unifying Scientists (NIDUS), a collaborative international network of delirium investigators, developed a successful, annual “NIDUS Bootcamp” conference, laying the foundation for this proposal. The new Delirium Bootcamp (DBC) will convene junior investigators and senior faculty in an annual conference with innovations including: 1) a new thematic focus each year, with the 2021 theme highlighting ADRD; 2) focus on high-impact, state-of-the-art methodologies to advance the field in new directions; 3) finding optimal methods to address the unique challenges of delirium research, and 4) developing collaborative interdisciplinary papers to be initiated at the DBC and completed in ongoing groups; thus, fostering the training, career development and success of the next generation of delirium investigators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative One in eight women will develop breast cancer over the course of her lifetime, and half of those women will succumb to the disease. Genetic predispositions, like mutations in the BRCA1 gene, increase the risk of developing breast cancer by over 50%, but it is largely unclear what determines whether cancer will in fact develop in a particular patient. Our previous work identified a role for epigenetic alterations in modulating to breast cancer, and we now aim to determine how alterations to the epigenome affect the development of Brca1-deficient mammary tumors, a strategy that will help to identify molecular pathways as potential strategies to block development of BRCA1-deficient breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Structural racism– the totality of ways by which society fosters racial discrimination through mutually reinforcing inequitable systems in housing, education, employment, health care, criminal justice and other domains-- affects minority groups in the U.S. disproportionately, including Black women. The present proposal will assess whether and how various forms of structural racism influence the incidence of Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias in Black women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Osteoarthritis (OA) is a common disease causing degeneration of the joints. It is complex with patients presenting with variable clinical indications. However, treatment strategies are limited to helping of only some symptoms such as pain, but not changing the course of the underlying disease. We propose an analysis extracellular RNA signatures that contribute to OA clinical subtypes and progression pattern unique to an individual. Using clinical phenotype clustering and plasma extracellular RNA expression signatures, our study may suggest novel molecular contributors to the disease and options for targeted therapeutics. Such functional biomarker identification can then be widely applied across OA phenotypes and populations to bring precision diagnosis and potential therapies to a broad section of those suffering from this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Most diseases are due to inflammation that is maladaptive—damaging host tissues. The vast majority of the damage takes place after white blood cells cross blood vessels (transendothelial migration) to enter the inflamed tissues. We are studying how this process is regulated and how it contributes to disease progression and resolution, so that we can design better anti-inflammatory therapies to control it.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: RELEVANCE Positron-emission tomography (PET) provides the best method to probe the dynamic status of receptors and other targets in the living brain to understand the brain in health, disease, and aging. Though many targets can already be imaged today, there is a continuous need to improve the performance of existing assays, to develop probes for newly discovered targets, or to label probes with new isotopes (e.g. F-18 instead of C-11). This project aims to develop new high-throughput tools that will dramatically accelerate these new probe development efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Significance of modulating neutrophil extracellular trap (NET) formation, a relative newly discovered aspect of neutrophil activation in respiratory and inflammatory disease conditions is now well recognized. Our proposed studies elucidate a novel autophagy-mediated, ROS independent NET formation pathway activated by Tamoxifen, a breast cancer drug, in ROS-deficient neutrophils and its implications in pulmonary infections in Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD). Validation of this drug and its target pathway will have significant impact on therapeutic measures to correct the neutrophil dysfunction in airway diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The incidence of acute kidney injury (AKI) is increasing worldwide, and is associated with high mortality, morbidity, and risk of chronic kidney disease. As a consequence of gaps in our understanding of the pathophysiology of AKI, adverse effects of pharmacological agents, and a lack of data using good animal models, effective treatment for AKI remains elusive and no approved pharmacological agents exist for the prevention or treatment of AKI. This proposal aims to evaluate the effect of enhancing removal of dying cells on AKI and assess the therapeutic potential of targeting efferocytosis for kidney injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to develop a research collaboration with individuals with craniofacial microsomia, their caregivers, craniofacial healthcare providers, and advocacy group leaders to evaluate the psychological health status and healthcare experiences of individuals with CFM and their caregivers. In a large international population affected by CFM, we will examine the extent to which current healthcare provision addresses the areas of health and psychological concern, identify of predictors of psychological distress, and identify opportunties for future interventions. The results of this study will enable further research on the healthcare outcomes and opportunties to perform targeted interventions to improve health in patients with craniofacial conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Existing large data sets consisting of multi-platform genomic summaries of patient tumors contain rich information that may be useful for personalizing therapy to each individual's cancer, but there is a need for new analytical methods to fully extract the knowledge contained in these data. We will develop new integrative, network-based statistical methods that can uncover mechanistic biological information explaining the speci c characteristics of an individual patients cancer. We will apply these methods to four colorectal cancer data sets to deeply characterize four recently discovered subtypes of this cancer in order to identify new targeted therapeutic strategies that can lead to improved outcomes for colorectal cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This project is aimed at improvement of glioblastoma (GBM) therapeutic strategies, taking into consideration the supporting role of tumor infiltrating myeloid cells on tumor progression and treatment resistance. The studies will elucidate the Pyk2-dependent machinery of cytokines release through the extracellular vesicles (EVs) mechanism in GBM cells, Pyk2 dependent populations of tumor-derived EVs and their effect on tumor infiltrating myeloid cells activation. The results of the study will help to identify molecular targets for managing tumor immune microenvironment and to enhance current GBM treatment protocols.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: This project will bring new understanding about how brain functioning in older adults is affected by a short term manipulation of the dietary ratio of the principal saturated fat and monounsaturated fatty acids (palmitic acid and oleic acid). The relationship among brain functioning and dietary fat composition will be studied. These data will have implications for understanding mechanisms underlying how diet influences brain functioning that is relevant to normal as well as pathological brain aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Emerging evidence demonstrates the importance of not just looking at genetics or the environment but rather, the interactions between genetic diversity and environmental exposures influencing human health and disease, including sensory processing disorders associated anxiety, autism, and schizophrenia. The etiology of sensory processing disorder remains equivocal; however, it is hypothesized that environmental factors including exposures to environmental contaminants can be important. This proposal uses a novel and powerful new model, the medaka fish, for determining gene- environment interactions that contribute to deficits in sensory processing behaviors observed with neuro-psychiatric conditions.
