IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Listening effort and fatigue present major challenges for individuals with hearing loss, often leading to anxiety and social disengagement. This proposal focuses on how effort and fatigue are affected by factors relevant to real-world communication: the ability to see a talker’s face, the need to overcome cognitive and acoustic speech perception challenges, and the demands of participating in live conversation. Findings will inform the development of tools to diagnose and manage listening effort and fatigue that better reflect everyday communication experiences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gaining insight into the molecular basis for the opposing roles that the ERK2-DBP and D domains play in PDAC pathogenesis will enable us to exploit this information to develop new strategies for therapeutic intervention. Moreover, because the RAS/ERK cascade is a critical driver in human PDAC, these findings will have profound implications for the treatment including conceptually innovative ERK2 drug targeting strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will investigate 7 promising neurotrauma biomarkers to be practically adopted for use in multi- institutional clinical studies in acute and subacute TBI, with rapid, reliable results. The goal of this study is to develop reference materials which will allow laboratories the ability to report consistent biomarker results with age-specific reference intervals throughout the lifespan that will allow discrimination from normal values. Finally, we propose to develop preliminary information on how biomarker levels are affected by injury severity, whether they can be used to monitor incipient secondary injury, and whether they have promise as prognostic biomarkers of persistent post-concussive symptoms.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Esophageal adenocarcinoma is a serious health problem in the United States, with a low survival rate and few treatment options. This proposal will examine how protein adduction by isoLGs affects the cellular and molecular mechanisms to promote cancer, which may lead to the development of novel therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project aims to decrease the impact of disability and increase the well-being of children with severe speech and physical impairments (SSPI) for whom conventional forms of verbal communication and access to traditional augmentative and alternative communication (AAC) devices are challenging. Project findings will help mobilize and improve patient-oriented brain-computer interface development for AAC access (BCI-AAC) by pro- moting accelerated training times and supporting inclusive and multimodal AAC access across the lifespan by giving children with SSPI a method of communication, allowing individuals to better communicate with their health providers and more fully participate in medical decision-making. These progressive benefits will help de- crease the risk of preventable adverse medical events and promote children's participation in the worlds of edu- cation, play, and friendship.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The National Plan to Address Alzheimer’s disease has identified education of dementia care providers as a top priority to address the need for quality care for the population of persons with dementia that will triple in the next 30 years. This study will adapt and test online interactive training for nursing home staff that improves staff communication and reduces behavioral symptoms of persons with dementia that they care for. This research will adapt and test communication training to meet the needs of nursing homes that serve high proportions of residents of diverse races and ethnicities, to improve care and overcome dementia care health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite advances in stroke prevention and treatment, stroke continues is a public health priority as a leading cause of death and disability worldwide. Multicenter clinical trials are needed to test new discoveries that may reduce this burden in the treatment, prevention, and recovery arenas. The Ohio Valley RCC proposes continued partnership with the NIH Stroke NET to improve clinical trial efficiency, success, and quality, and thereby advance stroke care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is not known whether it is feasible to perform circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) sequencing in real-time to guide treatment decisions during therapy for newly diagnosed diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Patients who achieve an excellent interim ctDNA-defined response during frontline treatment experience high cure rates and can likely receive an abbreviated chemotherapy course with decreased toxicity and without compromising outcomes. This response-adapted approach, if feasible, can subsequently evaluated in a larger randomized study, as well as applied to escalation strategies for patients with suboptimal interim ctDNA-defined response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multispectral optoacoustic tomography (MSOT) is a non-invasive newly emerging imaging technology that potential for detecting inflammation. MSOT can identify areas of inflammation, but additional molecular information is often required, particularly in areas of chronic inflammation, which can be enhanced by probiotic bacterial-based contrast agent.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Osteosarcoma (OS) is the most common bone tumor in pediatric patients, and the survival rates for patients with lung metastatic OS (pOS) have remained poor for more than 3 decades despite encouraging progress in the management of non-metastatic primary OS. For this reason, novel and directed therapy approaches that target pOS are desperately needed. It has been shown that TGF-β production is increased in the sera of OS patients and this increase in TGF-β production is correlated with high grade OS and associated with the presence of lung metastases, suggesting that targeting TGF-β signaling may be a novel therapeutic approach for pOS. This proposal seeks to establish an orally available small molecule inhibitor of TGF-β Type 1 Receptor as a novel therapy for pOS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Middle-aged and older people with schizophrenia have high rates of cognitive impairment and associated disability, however there is a lack of effective interventions. Obstructive sleep apnea may be a potentially treatable contributor to cognitive problems in people with schizophrenia. This project proposes to lay the groundwork for future intervention trials by clarifying the impact of sleep apnea on cognition, examining the role of inflammation as a surrogate biomarker, and identifying key risk factors that contribute to cognition in this high-risk and understudied group.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA NORTHERN CALIFORNIA HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: PARP inhibition (PARPi) including Olaparib is a novel strategy for the treatment of advanced prostate cancer approved in 2020. Despite this tremendous step forward, resistance to PARPi has already been clinically documented. Very little is known regarding the mechanisms of resistance development. This proposal will study novel models of PARPi resistance which will allow us to characterize mechanisms mediating PARPi sensitivity. This study will define the role of IGFBP3 as a key mediator of resistance, and explore novel therapeutic strategies which may be developed for clinical impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Anthropogenic chemicals are likely contributing to rising rates of neurodevelopmental disorders (NDDs) with socioemotional deficits, but the vast majority of work on NDDs to date has focused on genetic rather than environmental risk factors. Here we employ an animal model of social behavior, the prairie vole, to investigate how developmental exposure to a widespread environmental chemical contaminate impacts areas of the nervous system relevant to two behavioral traits common to many NDDs: anxiety and sociality. To achieve this goal, we focus on a widely-used flame retardant mixture implicated in human and animal studies known to contribute to a wide variety of sex-specific adverse effects on socioemotional related behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE TNBC is heavily reliant on the autophagy program for survival. We have discovered that ULK3, a key regulator of autophagy initiation, is highly expressed in TNBC and genetic or pharmacological inhibition of this kinase causes autophagy cessation and compromises TNBC viability. For the first time, we have generated a highly selective ULK3 inhibitor and in the proposed studies herein, we will evaluate the efficacy of the molecule in vitro and in vivo, in addition to performing deeper analyses on the expression of ULK3 in human specimens of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In elderly people, an episode of psychosis characterized by the development of delusions or hallucinations increases the risk of subsequently developing dementia; the biologic mechanism(s) responsible for this increased risk are poorly understood. Tau proteins in the brain, known to increase the risk of Alzheimer’s disease psychosis, may be responsible for the increased risk of dementia in people who become psychotic. The current application will use novel brain imaging and peripheral blood tests to measure tau proteins in elderly people who have become psychotic to determine whether tau may be a risk factor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Auditory comprehension deficits are pervasive in stroke-induced aphasia, yet there are few tools that can be used to precisely identify the source of these deficits within the speech and language system. The proposed study has the potential to improve characterization of auditory comprehension in aphasia by examining the validity and test-retest reliability of an objective tool, temporal response function (TRF) modeling. Establishing the validity of TRF-derived measures will build confidence in their ability to assess auditory comprehension, whereas knowledge of normal variability across sessions for TRF-derived measures will help researchers to make informed inferences about treatment-related outcomes or spontaneous recovery so that test-retest variability is not mistakenly taken to reflect meaningful change.

PROJECT_TITLE: Reliability and validity of temporal response function modeling in aphasia

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE Testosterone levels decline steadily with increasing age in men, and this change has been implicated as a risk factor for age-related memory loss in general and for Alzheimer’s disease in particular among older men. The proposed experiments will test the potential cognitive benefits of testosterone treatments using castrated male rats to model the dose-dependent effects of testosterone on learning and memory. To determine the physiological mechanisms by which testosterone influences the aged brain, male rats from three age classes (young, middle-aged, and old) will be tested on specialized maze tasks, their brain protein levels will be assayed, and neural connections among brain regions will be assessed using electrophysiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Early puberty in girls is one of the strongest predictors of depression in early adulthood. These studies will examine how exposure to an endocrine disrupting compound, which accelerates the onset of puberty, can alter a brain system important for mood. These studies will directly inform the development of novel strategies to improve mental health outcomes in young women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Listeria monocytogenes is the causative agent of listeriosis, a potentially fatal foodborne infection that can affect humans and animals. To survive in host cells and establish infection, L. monocytogenes must be able to withstand oxidative damage caused by reactive oxygen species generated by host oxidative burst. This proposal investigates how L. monocytogenes adapts its metabolic pathways to combat oxidative stress to enable future development of better treatment options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Colorectal cancer is the second most common cause of cancer deaths in the United States, with 150,000 new cases and 55,000 deaths per year. Our proposed studies will provide novel understanding to how cancer cells become dependent on an amino acid called glutamine. Most importantly, we will investigate whether deprivation of glutamine in cancer cells by a drug will starve cancer cells to death, thereby providing a novel therapy to treat colorectal cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oxidative stress is a known contributing factor to the pathogenesis of mental illness. Mercury is a neurotoxin that promotes oxidative stress by binding to selenium moieties present in antioxidant selenoenzymes, thereby disrupting their function. The objective of this proposal is to better comprehend how interactions between mercury and selenium during adolescence influence redox signaling and subsequent risk of psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE T-cell large granular lymphocytic leukemia (T-LGLL) is an incurable leukemia that results in frequent infections, transfusions, and death with no FDA-approved therapies and few marginally effective treatment options. T-LGLL is caused by an inflammatory growth factor, interleukin-15 (IL-15), that was recently targeted in a clinical trial with an IL-15 blocking drug (BNZ-1) with some efficacy, though laboratory studies demonstrated that leukemia cell populations became resistant to BNZ-1 by gene changes that disable anti-self-destruct (apoptotic) genes. This proposal seeks to use cutting-edge genomic techniques that enable the identification of gene changes in every single leukemia cell, to test the hypothesis that decrease in apoptotic gene pathways in populations of T- LGLL lead to resistance to treatment with BNZ-1; thereby providing targets for future novel drug trials for T-LGLL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Symptoms of idiopathic hypersomnia are debilitating and pose safety concerns and thus, there is a critical need to improve diagnostic accuracy. Using sleep neurophysiological biomarkers to diagnose this neurological disease is novel given most clinicians focus on measuring daytime sleepiness to establish diagnosis and treatment efficacy. The idiopathic hypersomnia nocturnal sleep traits we identify will also serve as the foundation for development and testing of therapies that improve sleep pathology and reduce disease burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project focuses on the fundamental question of how bacteria organize their DNA to maintain cellular health, consistent with the NIGMS mission to support basic research that increases understanding of biological processes and lays the foundation for advances in disease diagnosis, treatment, and prevention. Understanding the sensitivity of the nucleoid dynamics to the number, size, and spatial distribution of chromosome interacting domains is a fundamental question that should also suggest approaches to disrupt that structure, which would have lethal effects on bacteria by impeding protein binding and DNA transcription.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Amblyopia, or “lazy eye,” is a neurodevelopmental condition that interferes with the normal development of vision in 2-3% of children. Available treatments are beneficial if the condition is detected during early childhood, but complete recovery of normal vision is achieved in less than 50% of children. Two new approaches to amblyopia treatment will be investigated and findings from these clinical trials will potentially open a new avenue for treatments that restore normal visual function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: Project Narrative Millions of Americans suffer from deficits in reward processing and working memory in the context of psychiatric disorders, such as major depressive disorder, schizophrenia, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Early life stress and exposure to air pollution increase the risk of developing these disorders and affect reward processing and memory. In this project, we will systematically investigate how early life stress and pollution impact key brain circuits and test ways to prevent their negative effects of stress on the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Very little is known about how the sensory information relayed by the peripheral gustatory system influences the choice of foods or the way they are eaten, despite the critical relationship between taste and eating and how this knowledge could dramatically improve the design of nutrition guidelines. In particular, we do not know how the individual nerves, which innervate taste buds of the tongue and provide gustatory information as food enters the alimentary tract, affect ingestive behavior or how the form or energy density of the foods consumed may interact with these processes. We will use a behavioral approach to identify what role individual lingual gustatory nerves play in food choice and meal patterns to determine if these nerves provide information that aids in the control of food intake and discern if food characteristics like form or energy density may interact with this function to improve our understanding of biological factors influencing eating behavior and potentially increase the practicability of nutrition guidelines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic Ductal Adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is a notoriously difficult to treat disease, and is resistant to immunotherapy based therapeutic approaches. We’ve found that depletion of CXCL5 is sufficient to mount an immune response against PDAC and increase T cell infiltration. The current studies, will take advantage of a Plectin targeted adenovirus-based delivery system to suppress tumor derived CXCL5 and validate alterations in efficacy of checkpoint inhibition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a need to mentor junior clinical investigators with the research skills to improve care for persons living with Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) and family care partners. IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The book project links the notion of health equity to a philosophical theory of social justice that is more amenable to achieving greater equity in health than many prevalent theories of social justice. Using this theory of justice, known as “relational egalitarianism”, as a basis, it also provides guidance for how health equity should be understood, measured, and represented in the health sciences, policy, and education. The book is of public health relevance because it thus contributes to minimizing unjust health disparities, also known as health inequities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to develop a novel methodology to enable monitoring of oxygen levels in live cells. The methodology will be based on a fluorescent protein fused to various naturally occurring oxygen-binding proteins; proposed biosensor will be amendable to targeting to different cellular compartments or tissues. The ability to image oxygen gradients with subcellular resolution will lead to transformative insights into oxygen sensing and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite advances in detection and treatment of pancreatic cancer, there remains no clinically efficacious treat- ment for cachexia—the severe wasting syndrome that accompanies 80% of pancreatic cancer cases. The work in this proposal combines advanced epigenetic techniques with a novel mouse model for pancreatic cancer survivorship to study the molecular underpinnings of sustained metabolic deficits after cancer recovery. Expand- ing our understanding of the persistence of metabolic symptoms after cancer recovery will provide vast benefit to improving the quality of life for patients experiencing and surviving from pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Suicide is the second leading cause of death among those ages 10-34 years and the risk of suicidal thoughts and behavior skyrockets during adolescence, especially among girls, yet there is no firm understanding of why this is so. In two separate prior projects, our team has revealed that 1) adolescent girls’ acute social stress responses predict suicidal thoughts and behavior, and 2) that specific characteristics of the menstrual cycle are associated with elevated risk of suicide among adult women. This proposed project integrates these research programs to better help understand why girls are at increased risk, when girls may be most at risk, and which girls are at highest risk for future suicidal thoughts and behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Select strains of bacteria in the human gut produce a small molecule genotoxin known as colibactin. This grant seeks to delineate the structure and function of colibactin in order to test the hypothesis that it plays a causal role in colorectal cancer formation. This work will illuminate new strategies for the treatment and prevention of colorectal cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Enhanced endoplasmic reticulum (ER)-mitochondrial contact formation with local IP3 receptor enrichment and intensified calcium signaling has been claimed as causative factor in mitochondrial dysfunction associated with non-alcoholic fatty liver and obesity. However, the molecular mechanisms of this local communication and of several mitochondrial Ca2+ effectors are poorly understood. The proposed work will help to delineate the structure-function correlation of the ER-mitochondrial contacts in hepatocytes and will provide a new analytical toolkit for quantitative and effective evaluation of their ultrastructure for a range of scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Lay Summary Although immuno-oncology approaches have benefitted many cancer patients, immunotherapy approaches for glioblastoma (GBM) have failed to demonstrate clinical benefit. Based on promising preclinical and early clinical data, we propose the use of an oncolytic virus strain armed with an immunostimulatory gene, the toll- like receptor 2 agonist NAP, as a novel antitumor approach against GBM that can enhance immunotherapeutic efficacy and result in synergy when combined with immune checkpoint inhibitors. We also propose to further increase activity by using IDO and JAK inhibitors in order to address a common mechanism of resistance to immune checkpoint inhibitors and enhance viral replication, prior to comprehensively testing both the efficacy and safety of this multipronged strategy on a path to clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Non-metastatic cancer patients and their physicians need information about the short-term and long-term risks of recurrence, and how these risks vary with age, gender, race-ethnicity, other demographic characteristics, tumor characteristics, and received treatment. We aim to make the Georgia Cancer Registry the world’s first cancer registry to record recurrence information for four cancers that account for 4 in 9 incident cancers, and to use this information to describe recurrence patterns. Given its large and diverse population and high quality cancer registry, Georgia is the ideal setting to implement the world’s first registry of cancer recurrences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hypertension (high blood pressure), present in almost 50% of the population of the United States, is a major risk factor for heart and blood vessel disease leading to premature death and disability. Retention of salt and water by the kidney is required for hypertension to develop. This application will increase our understanding of the mechanisms whereby the kidney renin-angiotensin system regulates salt and water excretion, suggesting new molecular targets for the treatment and prevention of hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: This application from an established and highly productive cardiovascular and stem cell scientist focuses on the ways in which cells regulate the genes that they express so that scientists will be better able to promote regenerative therapies for cardiac diseases such as heart attacks. Recent studies indicate that DNA is organized in highly complex ways within the nucleus and that gene expression is regulated, at least in part, by spatial localization within nuclear compartments. DNA tethered tightly to the inner nuclear membrane in regions known as lamin associated domains, is repressed, and this proposal will seek to explore the emerging concept that cellular identity can be manipulated by controlling the regions of DNA that associate with the nuclear membrane with the goal of enhancing cardiac regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fasting and caloric restriction are effective to treat patients with pre-diabetes or non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), but intensive lifestyle changes are difficult for many to implement and sustain. We discovered a key pathway in the liver, which is activated during fasting, and is sufficient to treat pre-diabetes and NAFLD in mice. In this proposal, we will define how ARG2 mediates its therapeutic effects, and examine its efficacy to bring forth new therapies that mimic the actions of ARG2 to ultimately treat obesity-related metabolic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative We found that the protein which has received tremendous attention for its role in immune response, the programmed death ligand 1 (PD-L1) has novel nuclear function and can promote tumor cell growth by regulating chromosome division. These observations provide strong rational to target nuclear PD-L1 and block tumor growth. Especially in TNBC, PD-L1 dependent cell growth is essential for breast cancer survival, and therefore, this strategy could have significant clinical impact, especially to treat patients who might not respond to current PD-L1 antibody.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Exposure of unfixed tissue or liquid biospecimens to temperatures at which they are thawed (which in many cases is well below the common laboratory freezer temperature of -20 °C) can dramatically impact clinical research results—a phenomenon that has been shown to produce an inordinate number of false leads in biomedical research. No criteria for establishing biospecimen sample integrity have been set and no quality thresholds exist that must be met before NIH/NCI (taxpayer) funds are spent on studies involving archived research specimens. This project will develop bright-pink-to-clear color change-based indicators designed for a dozen different biospecimen handling/storage requirements that, ultimately, will be implemented by placement into custom-designed dual-chambered, flex-activated (like a glow-stick) see-through devices that can be housed on (notched into) the outside of a specially designed sample storage vial—and thus kept with (but not touching) the individual specimen over the entire course of its existence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Multiple sclerosis (MS) is one of the most prevalent (~1 million MS patients in the US) and debilitating neurological diseases that affects patients in early adulthood and is the second leading cause of non-traumatic paralysis. Importantly, the spinal cord is damaged in MS, potentially leading to neurological deterioration, however, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and in particular, diffusion MRI are poorly suited to offer information about the biological substrates of MS in the spinal cord primarily because of its size and constant motion. Recently advancements in diffusion MRI (and associated modeling of diffusion contrasts) have been made and hold the promise of providing insight into the biophysical substrates of tissue damage in MS, but the application in the cervical spinal cord, the relationship between diffusion MRI and conventional MRI, and a more complete description of neurological damage in the spinal cord with advanced diffusion MRI has not been adequately evaluated or vetted, which is the thrust of this proposal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Multiple sclerosis (MS), the most frequent inflammatory disease of the central nervous system (CNS), afflicts up to 2.5 million people globally. It begins at age 20–50 years, and there is no known cure. Medications used to treat MS are modestly effective, at least in relapsing remitting MS, but all available therapies are immunosuppressive, and thus predispose to opportunistic infections including JC virus leading to progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), which may be fatal. To date, no therapy has been advanced that specifically targets astrocytes, which are key players in CNS innate immunity, and which may be targeted without immunosuppression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative The properly regulated expression of protein-coding genes transcribed by RNA polymerase II (RNAPII) is essential for normal growth and development; disturbances in this regulation are hallmarks of cancer and other diseases. Both the transcription cycle of RNAPII and the cell division cycle are governed by the opposing actions of cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs) and protein phosphatases, which have emerged as potential targets in cancer therapy. Comprehensive models of how CDKs and phosphatases work together during the transcription cycle, and how this coordination is disrupted in cancer cells, are needed both to deepen understanding of normal gene regulation and to guide efforts to target the RNAPII machinery therapeutically.

PHR: Narrative The proposed research aims to detect and characterize magnetic resonance imaging signals in white matter associated with neural activity and brain function, and quantify their relationships with cortical activity and their biophysical origins. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prevalence of neurological disorders has doubled in the past 20 years and continues to escalate such that it is estimated that over 13.8 million people in the US will be afflicted with a neurological disorder by 2050. Defects in the cellular pathways that limit the abundance or facilitate the removal of potentially toxic proteins have been linked to increased neurological dysfunction and decreased overall longevity. Research within this proposal focuses on combatting aging-associated disorders through the targeted manipulation of factors that can reduce the toxicity of defective proteins by either limiting their production or enhancing their destruction.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diversity and inclusion in the biomedical workforce at all levels is critical to maintaining excellence. This grant seeks to address the issues of diversity and workforce development raised in the recent report by the Biomedical Workforce Advisory Committee through the development of a tailored academic and research-training program for post-baccalaureates interested in pursuing doctoral degrees in two broad areas of biomedical sciences, which we designate as the life and population sciences. The program will provide post-baccalaureates from disadvantaged backgrounds and groups underrepresented in the sciences with a one or two year mentored- research and academic experience at Harvard University.

PHR: NARRATIVE Our overall goal is to identify cross-sectional and longitudinal local patterns of cartilage and bone interactions unique to patellofemoral joint osteoarthritis and determine the mediation effects of gait biomechanics and bone morphology on disease progression. We will conduct a longitudinal cohort study investigating 100 people with isolated patellofemoral joint osteoarthritis, followed for 2 years. This work is urgently needed to fully understand bone-cartilage interactions and reveal biomechanical risk factors for patellofemoral joint osteoarthritis progression.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This grant application describes broadly based biophysical characterization of two important aspects of bacterial cell physiology. First, we will investigate the macroeconomic principles of proteome allocation by bacteria in response to different environmental challenges. Second, we will investigate the assembly of bacterial ribosomes, which is a key cellular process to produce the macromolecular machine that synthesizes all proteins in the cell.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Calcium homeostasis modulators (CALHMs) constitute a family of nonselective ion channels that are permeable to the signaling molecules calcium and ATP; they are thus critically involved in calcium and purinergic signaling. The proposed study focuses on uncovering the oligomeric state, multichannel assembly, molecular structure, gating mechanism, and pharmacology of the CALHMs, taking advantage of single- particle cryo-EM, electrophysiology, and other functional approaches. The proposed research is relevant to public health and NIH's mission because this work will provide a deep understanding and broaden our knowledge of the relationships between atomic structures and the complex biological and pathological functions of CALHMs, paving the way for the development of therapeutics to treat neurological diseases including Alzheimer disease, ischemic brain damage, and depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
ORG_NAME: VETERANS HEALTH RESEARCH INSTITUTE OF CENTRAL NEW YORK, INC.
PHR: Military veterans are more vulnerable to experience chronic pain, experience psychiatric disorders, and die by suicide; however, extant research has yet to examine interventions to address suicide risk and functional impairment from chronic pain within the same intervention. Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy has demonstrated promise for individuals experiencing chronic pain and for individuals at risk for suicide, individually, but no study has combined these treatments for more robust effects on each of these outcomes. Therefore, we plan to develop a manual to address both functional impairment and suicide risk then assess its feasibility, acceptability, and parameters on key functioning outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative. Our goal is to develop and commercialize an automated system that interrogates microarrays of reverse-transfected mammalian cells to detect and quantify GPCR responses to agonists, inverse agonists, and other classes of ligand. By enabling screening against large numbers of human GPCRs in parallel, the system will dramatically expand the scope of GPCR drug discovery and development projects without expanding their costs, and thus lead to new therapeutic treatments for neurological and mental diseases and conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative High initial sensitivity to aversive drug effects is likely to result in drug avoidance and reduce the probability of addiction. The study of mechanisms associated with high initial sensitivity to aversive drug effects could provide new therapeutic targets for intervention. By identifying and mapping functional circuits regulating drug aversion, we will gain new insight into how aversion-modulating systems are recruited in drug avoiding populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project addresses a key public health issue with broad applicability to many diseases and health behaviors: how to help people follow a complicated medical regimen and achieve better health outcomes. We will test the role of coaching support focused on problem solving and incentives to help young adults with type 1 diabetes feel better and be healthier. We expect that the things we learn about helping young adults with type 1 diabetes will apply to many other health problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Dietary lipids are known to amplify inflammatory responses in chronic inflammatory diseases, which are associated with defective tissue repair processes. Although it is known that diets high in fat exacerbate inflammatory conditions such as inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), it is unclear how dietary lipids impact the intestinal immune system and tissue repair. Understanding how environmental components, such as diet, can induce or amplify inflammatory immune cell functions that support loss of tissue resolution will open the door to novel treatments for IBD and other inflammatory conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The increasing prevalence of cannabis use has created a significant public health concern, particularly for the highest using group, young adults; however, additional research is needed to understand how to mitigate the harms associated with frequent and heavy cannabis use. The proposed study will fill an important gap in the cannabis and PBS literature by providing a foundation for future PBS interventions and potentially offering insight to why recent PBS focused interventions have yielded inconsistent results. Results from the present study will provide a measurement of daily cannabis PBS and a personalized, data-driven approach to PBS focused interventions.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because hospitals remain unaware of many existing patient safety threats due to their over-reliance on flawed voluntary incident reporting. By demonstrating the effectiveness of a coproduced (created in partnership with families), equity-focused, multicomponent communication intervention to engage patients and families in hospital safety reporting, our study will (1) provide a framework for hospitals to overcome the current limitations of voluntary incident reporting and (2) identify unrecognized areas to improve safety, particularly for vulnerable patients. Genuine coproduction with patients and families will open new strategic approaches to improving the safety, quality, and equity of healthcare, in line with AHRQ's mission.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: A Multicenter Randomized Controlled Trial of a Patient Safety Reporting Intervention for Families to Improve Medical Error Detection and Reduce Inequities
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Narrative Interventions to decrease venous thromboembolism (VTE), a leading cause of preventable harm, have focused on improving prescription of prophylaxis for hospitalized patients; however, VTE prophylaxis medication nonadherence is an enormous and largely unrecognized problem in hospitals across the country. We will deliver interactive, online, scenario-based education to all frontline nurses at our participating hospitals (SA1) regarding the importance of VTE prevention for hospitalized patients. We will scale up a successful patient- centered, evidence-based education bundle intervention using real-time electronic health record data for hospitalized patients who missed doses of VTE prophylaxis medication (SA2) and assess satisfaction about the quality of nurse-patient communication regarding prescribed medication (SA3). The goal of this project is to empower patients to make informed evidence-based decisions about their VTE preventive care and improve VTE prophylaxis medication adherence among patients hospitalized in heterogeneous environments.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Disseminating a Patient Centered Venous Thromboembolism Prevention Bundle
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: Depression and anxiety-related disorders are highly prevalent, debilitating, and are often linked to abnormal stress processing. The stress-associated neurotransmitter corticotropin releasing factor (CRF) is widely distributed throughout the central and peripheral nervous system. This proposal posits that chronic stress shifts CRF responsivity and CRF modulation of behavior in a way that propels individuals to a state of negative perceptual bias and withdrawal from their environment and contends that this shift is key to understanding vulnerability to diseases such as depression and anxiety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Mental disorders are often early-onset chronic diseases, with brain and behavioral risk markers of common internalizing/externalizing problems evident in infancy. To accelerate translation, we will use multi-method imaging, behavioral and data science innovations to generate an infant mental health risk calculator for pragmatic public health use, derived from a clinically enriched “Mental Health Earlier-Synthetic Cohort” of 1,020 infants using established study samples (characterized from birth-54 months). Clinical prediction algorithms will deliver broadly useful tools for earlier prediction and prevention of mental disorder and parameters to inform when imaging methods will be most informative in large-scale neurodevelopmental studies.

PHR: Unlike adult infections, newborn infections with herpes simplex virus (HSV) can have dire outcomes – with more than half of these infants experiencing viral spread into the brain or other organs. We will use viral comparative genomics, along with phenotypic comparisons in cellular and animal models of infection, to decipher how differences in viral genetics impact the severity of neonatal disease in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative High blood pressure (hypertension), caused in some cases by genetic mutations such as in Familial Hyperkalemic Hypertension (FHHt), is a great burden to public health both medically and financially. The kidney tubules are the main site in the body that adjusts body salt content, and by doing so, helps to set the blood pressure to an optimal level. The proposed research investigates the molecular mechanism behind a newly discovered genetic mutation that causes FHHt and may lead to the development of new drugs or cost- efficient treatments to target hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: This project will provide the first-ever direct measure of muscle mass in a large sample of community dwelling postmenopausal women using the D3-creatine method, a highly accurate and scalable measure of muscle mass that can be carried out remotely (at home). This novel approach will be used to compare the antecedents and consequences of low muscle mass in cancer survivors and age-matched cancer-free controls. This research will contribute to the development of public health recommendations and intervention strategies to prevent low muscle mass and associated adverse health outcomes in older and long-term cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Increased inflammation in patients with schizophrenia is associated with motivational deficits and negative symptom severity, which in turn contributes to poor functional outcomes including excess morbidity and mortality as well as treatment nonresponse. Increased inflammation is associated with alterations in activation of the ventral striatum and the anterior insula, brain regions that subserve reward, effort, and motivation. This project will provide mechanistic insight into whether inflammation impacts these brain regions to contribute to motivational deficits in a subgroup of patients with schizophrenia and will provide a foundation for personalized treatments that reduce inflammation to ultimately reverse the devastating impact of amotivation and negative symptoms in patients with schizophrenia and increased inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Through targeted one-on-one mentoring between faculty and undergraduate students from communities underrepresented in the sciences, ROUTES seeks to increase engagement of underrepresented minorities (URMs) in the increasingly complex field of environmental health (EH) research. ROUTES will establish a multidisciplinary program centered around meaningful EH research experiences in industry, government, and non-profit sectors as well as on-campus funded research projects. Through integration with existing on campus P42 and T32 training programs, ROUTES will provide training, professional development, and networking opportunities to encourage URM students to pursue research careers in EH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Sarcoma are metastatic and aggressive tumors, for which therapies have not improved in the last years. Novel studies have been impeded by the paucity of appropriate experimental tools and reliable mouse models. Accordingly, we propose: i) to generate and characterize novel reliable sarcoma mouse models that carry the most frequent genetic alteration found in patients ii) illuminate the expression profile of the sarcoma cells and discrete sub-clusters of them, to understand how these profiles influence the TME composition, and iii) to test how these models respond to different radiotherapy administration schedules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Name of Principal Investigator: Sean N. Avedissian Project Narrative My long-term goal is to become an independent investigator in translational and clinical pharmacology of antiretroviral drugs (ARVs) focused on HIV reservoirs. The goal of this application is to advance significantly my career development, through didactic coursework and mentored research, and develop expertise in the field of central nervous system-focused HIV pharmacology. The research proposal includes both clinical and translational work fundamental to understanding ARV drug penetration and activity in the central nervous system in people with HIV. Data from these experiments will guide future approaches to design ARV regimens optimal for treatment of people with HIV infection who develop HIV-associated neurocognitive dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a life-threatening blood disease. Many new drugs targeting newly identified genetic mutations in AML are demonstrating promising effect in clinical studies. However, one major obstacle to greater success with targeted therapy of leukemia is drug resistance. To understand the resistance to a potential clinical drug AC220 of AML, we have carried out a genetic screen to study the mechanisms of resistance to AC220 in AML cells and discover a number of novel genes whose knockouts cause drug resistance to AC220. We will further explore the underlying mechanisms of acquired drug resistance in AML and translational potential of our findings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current treatment options for stroke are time-limited and require expertise, and equipment, that is not widely available to most patients who have suffered a stroke. This proposal is investigating the effect of blocking one of the known ways in which the immune system responds to stroke to determine if this approach can lessen the damage that occurs after stroke. The overall goal of these studies is to obtain more information needed to develop different treatment options that can improve outcomes from stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The overall objective of this proposal is to refine our understanding of the impacts of home health care, early outpatient care, and Medicare Advantage after hospitalization for acute myocardial infarction (AMI) in older persons by examining their effects in the context of functional impairments and illness severity. We will focus on outcomes of primary importance to older patients, including “home days” (days alive out of the hospital and other inpatient facilities) and health status. This hypothesis-driven research will leverage the most comprehensive set of data on functional impairments and geriatric conditions collected during AMI hospitalization on a large, national cohort to inform strategies to improve outcomes of importance to older patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neonatal clinical trials have difficulty including diverse populations of infants, such as those whose parents are racial or ethnic minorities, report lower income, or have lower educational attainment. Under-representation of these populations results in an evidence base that may not be generalizable, which is particularly problematic because these infants are at higher risk for worse outcomes for many common neonatal problems and associated morbidity, mortality, cost, and long-term disabilities. The proposed project will describe how parents make enrollment decisions and create and pilot test a modified recruitment approach designed to improve the recruitment process and to increase participation of under-represented populations in neonatal research.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to elucidate the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying Neural tube defects (NTDs), that are among the most common birth defects in humans. To achieve this, we will utilize a novel mouse model of NTDs that has a failure of cranial mesenchyme expansion and neural fold elevation. Our findings will yield mechanistic insights into the causes of NTDs, elucidate the contribution of an understudied process driving neural tube closure and implicate an important candidate gene for genetic counseling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep disturbances are prevalent and contribute to mental and physical health problems, cognitive difficulties and physiological dysregulation - significant public health problems. Health disparities in sleep along socioeconomic and racial/ethnic lines and their consequences on long-term trajectories of health and adaptation from childhood through early adulthood are essentially unknown. This study will create new knowledge by identifying mechanisms that explicate when and why socio-economic and racial disparities in sleep emerge, and by elucidating the long-term effects of sleep disturbances in the development of broader health disparities from childhood through early adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is aimed at defining how disruption of the circadian clock, both genetic and environmental, accelerates colorectal cancer pathogenesis. We propose that the circadian clock regulates Wnt/b-Catenin signaling, and disruption of this control results in aberrant gene expression and accelerated intestinal proliferation. Our molecular studies will provide new insight towards future directions for targeted therapeutic intervention of colorectal cancer that rely on pharmacological modulators of the circadian clock.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  The spinal column is composed of neural and mesodermal tissues, and birth defects, such as scoliosis, that affect the spinal column can originate from abnormal development of either tissue. This project uses an innovative application of deactivated Cas9 technology to investigate how two transcription factors regulate mesodermal differentiation and migration of mesodermal progenitors in axis elongation critical in spinal column development. By elucidating the roles of these transcription factors this project will shed light on combinatorial gene function in development as well as the genetic and cellular dynamics of vertebrate body elongation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Lay Summary: Glioma intelligence from behind enemy lines We used “microdialysis” to sample the biochemical signatures of living human brain cancers during neurosurgical procedures and identified high level of resiliency-promoting metabolites. We use neurosurgical access to human brain tumors to determine when, how and why these metabolites accumulate and how best to eliminate them, using microdialysis to evaluate progress in real time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the project is expected to have a positive impact by providing information on the mechanisms by which tumor suppressor p53 status determines estrogen receptor beta (ERβ) function in breast cancer, especially triple negative breast cancer (TNBC). There is an urgent need to identify novel targets and develop new therapies against TNBC because targeted therapies are not currently available against these aggressive cancers, and the remaining option, chemotherapy, is also relatively ineffective. The proposed study will facilitate better understanding of ERβ and p53 signaling crosstalk and has the potential to facilitate developing new therapeutic strategies against TNBC, and therefore, is relevant to the part of NIH's mission that pertains to research on causes, diagnosis, prevention, and cure of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Contact PI: Reddy, Julia PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on provider and policy responses to prenatal substance exposure and the custody outcomes of affected infants. It will also inventory best practice policies and tools perceived by labor and delivery providers as able to improve policy consistency and mitigate the consequences of maternal substance use disorders, which responds to NIDA’s mission to increase the applicability of research in real-world contexts. By examining both the implementation and outcomes associated with nonuniversal prenatal substance exposure-related child protection system reporting policies, the proposed research is responsive to NIDA’s Strategic Plan Goal 4, to assess the impact of policies related to drug use and substance use disorders on public health and well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a pressing need to develop and implement plans for COVID-19 pandemic response and control for low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). Prevention science, with mathematical models and related approaches, supports epidemic planning and preparedness, but must be based upon context-specific epidemiological parameters for maximal utility. In this study, we will identify COVID-19-specific parameters for low-income settings to be implemented in mathematical models for prevention and pandemic response.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antibiotic resistance, due to antibiotic overuse, is a major threat to human health, and if unchecked will fundamentally alter the landscape of healthcare. This proposal will clarify effective ways to implement and assess the safety of diagnostic stewardship programs to reduce antibiotic use in critically ill children and will identify strategies to disseminate diagnostic stewardship programs.

PROJECT_TITLE: Respiratory Culture Stewardship to Reduce Antibiotic Use in Critically Ill Children

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is relevant to public health because it aims to improve the safety of nursing care delivered in neonatal intensive care units (NICUs). The research is significant because it will improve neonatal patient safety by changing the way nursing workload in the NICU is measured and used for workload management, organizational learning, and improvement. The project is innovative because it will use data readily accessible in electronic health records to develop a new multi-level model of workload for registered nurses and use this model to guide the design and development a future clinical decision support tool for workload management and safety improvement.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Realtime Measurement of Situational Workload in NICU Nurses to Improve Workload Management and Patient Safety
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health since it focuses on dissecting the mechanisms underlying the regulation of a highly conserved signaling complex (TORC1) known to play an important role in cancer development, diabetes, obesity and depression. The work may also reveal differences between the pathways that control cell growth in lower eukaryotes and humans--opening the door to creating drugs that can selectively block the growth of fungal pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Age is the primary risk factor for the leading causes of disability and death, and interventions are needed to slow the rate of aging and improve health. In order to develop and test emerging interventions, we need accurate indices of aging processes. The proposed studies will validate a metric of biological aging that will be used to predict human healthspan, accelerate clinical trials to intervene on the aging process, and improve human healthspan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Mild Cognitive Impairment: A Prospective Community Study. This study of dementia and cognitive decline is being conducted in a population-based cohort of older adults from a “Rust Belt” community of relatively low socio-economic status. The overall goal of the study is to identify factors which might increase risk of dementia and cognitive decline, so that steps can be taken to reduce these risks, thus reducing the risk of dementia and improving the health of older adults in the community.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prematurity is associated with a high prevalence of neuropsychological disability, even without major brain injury. This study seeks to identify early magnetic resonance imaging biomarkers of disturbed brain development, their association with ex-utero circulatory and oxygenation exposures of prematurity, and with neuropsychological outcome. Findings will inform specific targets for future interventions to improve neuropsychological outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Pathogenic variants in the Cyclin-dependent kinase like 5 (CDKL5) gene cause CDKL5 deficiency disorder (CDD, MIM 300672, 105830), a severe developmental and epileptic encephalopathy associated with cognitive and motor impairments and cortical visual impairment. While capability for disease modifying therapies is accelerating, there is a critical barrier for clinical trial readiness that may result in failure of these therapies, not due to lack of efficacy but due to lack of validated outcome measures and biomarkers. The measures and biomarkers validated here will be adaptable to other developmental and epileptic encephalopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Osteoporosis and hypertension are major health concerns that lower lifespan and hinder the ability to remain independent and active as people age. This project will investigate pathways by which hypertension and aging activates the bone marrow to cause bone loss and weaken bone. By using established pre-clinical models of this disease and aging, the collaborative team with different but complementary expertise is well positioned to identify a new and translatable strategy for the prevention of fragility fractures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Childhood decrements in neurocognitive development result in large population burden and expenditure. The proposed research will identify the extent to which prenatal and postnatal neurotoxic mixtures as well as key prenatal nutrients jointly influence neurocognitive development in childhood. This research will provide early life biomarkers that reconstruct prenatal exposures and predict childhood neurocognitive performance with the goal of developing novel and early-life interventions to protect children.

PHR: Project Narrative Lynch syndrome (LS) is a hereditary disease which predisposes patients to an increased risk of developing colorectal and other extra-colonic cancers. Determining the mechanism by which loss of MMR contributes to tumorigenesis will aid in the diagnosis, prevention and treatment of these cancers. This proposal seeks to test whether loss of MMR leads to an immediate growth and/or survival advantage in intestinal stem cells as an important early event in the tumorigenic process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative. A critical faculty impaired in psychopathology is self-reflection: People’s capacity to reflect on the cognitive processes (thoughts, beliefs, desires, etc.) underlying their behavior. I use a novel, objective measure of this capacity – which assesses people’s accuracy when reflecting on how they’re making choices – to characterize variation in self-reflective accuracy across psychiatric symptom dimensions, and to test whether accuracy can be improved through a mindfulness intervention. This research provides a generative paradigm for studying self-reflection in choice, paving the way for future investigation into the neurocognitive mechanisms underlying self-reflection, its impairment, and its improvement.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Little is known about how pubertal blockade, the first step in the medical management of a young transgender adolescent, affects bone health and psychological well-being. The proposed project will explore how bone and mental health are impacted in these adolescents during pubertal blockade, and will examine the interplay between physical and psychological health. Our work will open new avenues for identifying preventive strategies to counter potential adverse effects of medical management on bone health in transgender adolescents, and will provide new information on the monitoring of both physical and mental health outcomes.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE __ Unnecessary antibiotic exposure in newborns is common and has been associated with a variety of short- and long-term adverse outcomes. Antibiotic stewardship programs can safely and effectively reduce antibiotic exposure in the nursery setting, but most nurseries in rural or medically underserved areas lack the local expertise and support for nursery stewardship. Our study will test the widespread dissemination and implementation of a telehealth antibiotic stewardship program for rural nurseries that has been shown to be feasible, safe and effective.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Dissemination and implementation of a telehealth program to deliver effective antibiotic stewardship support to rural or medically underserved newborn nurseries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative: The goal of this research is to develop and validate a comprehensive computer-based technology that will allow surgical trainees to practice their surgical skills on computer-based models. Surgical procedures and techniques, learnt and perfected in this risk-free manner before application to patients, will translate to fewer operating room errors, reduced patient morbidity and improved patient outcomes resulting in faster healing, shorter hospital stay and reduced post surgical complications and treatment costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study aims to comprehensively delineate the host-microbe mechanisms that modulate enteric hyperoxaluria within a complex host-microbe environment and determine the effect of oral antibiotics on that environment in humanized mice. Understanding oxalate metabolism at a systems level will provide novel opportunities for the development of bacteriotherapies to alleviate recurrent urinary stone disease (USD) that are tailored to individual patients. Considering the depth of interactions between oxalate and the gut microbiota as a whole, understanding how the microbiota regulates oxalate is highly significant and critical for the development of effective and persistent bacteriotherapies for recurrent USD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many neuro-degenerative/cognitive disorders manifest vascular impairments, including reduced functional hyperemia. However, isolating the impact of reduced functional hyperemia from other vascular changes is technically challenging. This proposal will harness a novel technique to block functional hyperemia independently from other vascular changes to determine the impact on neural function in health and in Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The microbiome is composed of the beneficial microbes in the gastrointestinal tract that play a role in maintaining gut health. The proposed work will investigate the mechanisms by which a microbe-generated metabolite, Valerobetaine (VB), alters colonic epithelial cell metabolism and identify the effect of VB on intestinal tissue health. A better understanding of the roles and mechanisms of microbe-generated metabolites can allow for their utilization as therapeutic options in the treatment of disorders such as Inflammatory Bowel Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The consequences of sugar overconsumption in America are clear: two-thirds of Americans suffer from diet- related chronic illnesses including obesity and diabetes. Specialized sensory cells in the intestine, called neuropod cells, drive sugar appetite. The proposed studies will define the receptor required for neuropod cell sugar sensing, revealing a novel pharmaceutical target for downregulating sugar appetite.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent studies have demonstrated that the levels of C. albicans and C. tropicalis are significantly higher in Crohn’s disease (CD) patients than in their non-diseased relatives. These human data, coupled with our findings that Candida-infected C57BL/6 (B6) mice are more susceptible to chemically-induced colitis compared to uninfected controls, strongly suggest that Candida infections may play a role in triggering flares during CD and that antifungal therapy may be beneficial in CD patients. Due to the rising public health burden from inflammatory bowel diseases, a more thorough understanding of ways in which candidiasis affect the gut microbiome and consequently immune responses is of critical importance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative The focal point of this project is to decode the cellular and molecular mechanisms that drive infiltration of glioblastoma (GBM), which is a major cause of recurrence and contributes to the high mortality rate of this disease. We propose to uncover how the activity of subsets of neurons contributes GBM infiltration, while also examining the roles of axon guidance genes in GBM infiltration. These studies will reveal new cellular and molecular mechanisms that control the infiltration and invasion of GBM that are likely to be applicable to other forms of brain tumors and also other types of tumors that metastasize to the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative Malaria is caused by Plasmodium, a parasite that is spread by mosquitoes, and the disease is often characterized by a high fever and other flu-like symptoms. The disease affects all organs of the body and can cause a heightened immune response that can lead to death; the World Health Organization reported that in 2017 there were ~435,000 deaths due to malaria. To better treat and prevent malaria, the goal of this proposal is to understand how the body’s immune system detects Plasmodium and identify the genes and pathways responsible for responding to and eliminating this parasite.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Notch receptors have emerged as one of the most frequently mutated genes in small B cell tumors including mantle cell lymphoma (MCL); however, progress in leveraging Notch inhibitors as therapeutic options has been stymied partly due to a limited understanding of underlying mechanisms of their sensitivity and resistance. This proposal seeks to determine precise Notch-driven regulatory circuits of key pathways that drive MCL tumor growth and identify how Notch-driven regulatory programs are altered in drug-resistant MCL. By addressing these unanswered questions, this proposal sets the stage for informed trials of Notch inhibitors in Notch-addicted MCL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Mobilization of both adaptive and innate immune cells can assist in the treatment of breast cancer and other cancers. We have identified a protein acyl transferase enzyme, DHHC3, that may regulate both adaptive and innate anti-cancer immunity. To gain insight into the importance of DHHC3 we will i) determine whether its effects on CMTM6 palmitoylation and PD-L1 expression lead to regulation of adaptive anti-tumor immunity, and ii) determine whether its effects on oxidative stress regulators such as ERGIC3 and TXNIP are essential for regulation of oxidative stress, senescence, and tumor clearance by innate immune cells.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infants in neonatal intensive care units can sometimes experience harmful things that should not happen to them (e.g., infections). One reason this happens is because the workload of nurses gets too high, and then nurses miss important things. We will study a new way of understanding and measuring nurse workload so that in the future we can more accurately monitor nurse workload and address it when it gets too high.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The unique metabolic phenotypes found in tumors offer many promising targets for cancer therapy, but pathway redundancy has emerged as a major challenge to successfully targeting many of the most important metabolic pathways. We have found that luminal breast tumors cannot synthesize the non-essential amino acid serine due to epigenetic suppression of the gene encoding PSAT1, an enzyme in the serine synthesis pathway. In this proposal, we will determine whether this makes luminal breast tumors sensitive to inhibition of serine uptake in vivo, which may represent a new target for treatment of advanced luminal breast cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The traditionally subjective clinical management of patients with craniosynostosis has caused a large variability in treatment approaches between surgeons and institutions, and many patients require additional surgeries after showing unsatisfactory long-term outcomes. These suboptimal treatments are common for three main reasons: (1) local volume anomalies and their progression have not been characterized to estimate how much extra local volume patients need during treatment; (2) our knowledge about how treatment modifies cranial growth is limited and post-surgical development predictions are not possible; and (3) there are no objective and personalized methods to evaluate long-term outcomes, so treatment selection remains subjective. We aim to characterize the processes of abnormal local volume development in patients with craniosynostosis before and after treatment, create methods to evaluate, predict and compare post-surgical outcomes, and identify relapsing patients using objective data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative. Antibiotics are wonder drugs that have tamed bacterial infections over the past century. Unfortunately, pathogens are now becoming resistant to the best antibiotics used in clinical practice today. This project is aimed at identifying non-antibiotic strategies to prevent and treat bacterial infections. Successful execution of this project will add to the arsenal of tools we have to fight bacterial infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Early detection of young people at clinical high risk for psychosis offers a critical opportunity for early intervention to improve the course of illness, and perhaps even prevent onset entirely. Current interview- based methods for psychosis risk detection lack specificity, and are only available in a handful of research centers in the United States. The proposed study aims to improve accessibility and broaden impact of high risk screening by testing brief computerized measures, ultimately able to be administered on the internet, and to improve prediction by focusing on tasks specific to underlying mechanisms driving emerging psychotic symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Granulomas are the sites where M. tuberculosis and host cells interact, yet despite the importance of granulomas in TB, they are poorly understood. In this project, we employ the strengths of studies in 3 species, including humans, rhesus macaques, and new strains of mice, to understand the cell composition, spatial interactions, movements, and functional states in TB granulomas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure is a leading cause of death in the US and worldwide, and loss of cardiomyocytes is a major contributor to heart failure. Adult cardiomyocytes cannot replenish themselves by proliferation. The overall goals of this study is to develop comprehensive understanding of genetic pathways that dictate the inability of adult cardiomyocytes to proliferate, toward overcoming those barriers to promote cardiomyocyte renewal and preventing heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Overall component Tuberculosis (TB) has been the leading infectious disease cause of death worldwide for the past decade and we are not on track to achieve the WHO End TB goal of reducing TB incidence by 90% by 2035. The mission of the Emory/Georgia TB Research Advancement Center (TRAC) is to catalyze and expand multidisciplinary research to provide new knowledge and improve our understanding of TB. The TRAC will foster the development of the next generation of TB researchers and provide resources and support for new and established TB researchers through three scientific cores – Clinical & Population Science, Basic & Translational Science, and Bioinformatics & Integrated Systems Biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is highly significant and directly relevant to public health since it focuses on developing new methods for targeting pancreatic cancer growth and metastasis by targeting coupling between tumor microenvironment and pancreatic cancer cells. This proposal's overarching objective is to identify the critical metabolic regulators of pancreatic cancer growth in vitro and in vivo. Our paradigm shifting approach of targeting tumor microenvironment could lead to regulation of oncometabolites, provide novel understanding of pancreatic cancer growth and metastasis, and uncover critical approaches for cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project builds on a 14-year follow-up, scheduled for 2022, of a cohort of children and adolescents living in agricultural communities in Ecuador (the ESPINA Study). This project proposes to assess whether pesticide spray seasons are associated with cyclical alterations in mental health symptoms and cognitive performance assessed over two years using a smartphone-based assessment platform, and to test whether pesticide exposure biomarkers are related to elevated depressive and externalizing symptoms and decreased cognitive performance. Findings from this project will advance the current field of environmental health and inform future brain and mental health risk assessments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is to reveal 1) how cancer cells induce painful complications of bone metastases, and 2) the mechanisms whereby pain signals promote the growth of bone metastatic cancer cells. We will also block this cancer-nerve interaction to treat bone metastases and its painful complication. This study will provide insights into the roles of sensory nerves in bone metastatic progression, and safer and more effective treatment strategies for bone metastases and associated pain.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal aims to understand how different cell types in the developing embryo are generated, the transcription factors involved and the sequences in the genome activated in different cells. Our findings will inform human development and lay the foundation to investigate human developmental disorders.
