IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The thirteen known genetic etiologies of ‘isolated’ (AR IL-17RA, IL-17RC, ACT1, and AD IL-17F deficiencies) or ‘syndromic’ CMC (AR CARD9, IL-12p40, IL-12Rb1, ROR-g/gT, ZNF341, and AD JNK1, IL6ST, STAT3 deficiencies, and AD STAT1 GOF) impair IL-17A/F immunity. The molecular and cellular mechanisms that disrupt IL-17 immunity and underlie CMC remain incompletely understood, while half of the patients with idiopathic CMC lack a genetic etiology. We thus aim to pursue the molecular, cellular, immunological, and clinical study of both known and novel inborn errors of IL-17A/F immunity in patients with isolated or syndromic CMC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Malaria caused by infection with Plasmodium vivax results in significant morbidity around the world, and resistance to antimalarial treatments presents a major hurdle to control and elimination efforts. Here, we will use a combination of evolutionary and experimental genetic methods to identify putative P. vivax molecules involved in drug resistance. Following confirmation, P. vivax drug resistance polymorphisms will be key to surveillance for antimalarial efficacy and the design of strategies to prolong the usefulness of antimalarial drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE CD97 is an adhesion class G-protein coupled receptor (aGPCR) frequently expressed in human acute myeloid leukemia (AML) that is required for LSC self-renewal. CD97 exists as three isoforms with potential differences in ligand binding and signaling profiles; however, it is not clear if there are isoform-specific roles for CD97 in LSCs. We will use a combination of genetic and molecular approaches, including novel human synthetic CD97 antibodies we have generated, to identify the physiologically relevant interaction domains as well as the structural and signaling requirements for CD97 function; these studies will not only yield novel insights into the mechanisms that regulate LSC self-renewal, but identify specific antibody reagents that may be quickly translated to the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Natural killer (NK) cell therapy for acute leukemia and multiple myeloma is limited by lack of NK cell persistence and loss of function. A subset of NK cells, called adaptive NK cells, is longer-lived and exhibit enhanced functional responses against tumor cells. This proposal will investigate the use of adaptive NK cells to treat leukemia and myeloma and test methods to retain their function after exposure to tumor cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Scarring is the end result of injury in adult skin and results in an enormous financial and medical burden for our society, yet no molecular therapies exist that can prevent scarring or its sequelae. Facial wounds heal with reduced scars compared to back and abdominal scars; however, molecular drivers governing the outcome of skin wounds derived from different embryonic origins remains unknown. Therefore, we will explore the biomolecular and tissue mechanical drivers of facial skin healing in order to facilitate development of novel targets to minimize scarring and promote regenerative wound healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Metabolic function can cause cellular stress, which in term can impact aging. We found that an understudied stress response in the Golgi regulated lipid metabolism and is important for a compensatory pathway that affects secretory function and changes during aging. By understanding how this link between metabolism and stress is regulated, we will make important insights into mechanisms underlying changes in the aging process. These processes are also relevant to a broad variety of human diseases such as Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The financial and humanitarian cost associated with enteroviruses is substantial - this project aims to understand key aspects of the lifecycle that can be then targeted therapeutically. We are focussing on the protein shell, termed a capsid, this surrounds the viral genetic material and is made up of repeating copies of three proteins. After assembling around the genome, one of these proteins is cleaved by an unknown mechanism into two, which converts the particle into an infectious form, the resolution of this process may pave the way to developing antiviral drugs and vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE My goal for the K25 award is to establish myself as an independent neuroimaging statistician, with expertise in whole-brain network analyses and an integral member of multidisciplinary research teams devoted to addressing diseases of the brain. The training component of this award will provide a foundation in image analysis and computational neuroscience to deepen my understanding of the brain as a complex system. The research activities will focus on developing new methodology to improve whole-brain dynamic connectivity analyses with the end goal of improving patient outcomes for various brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Harnessing epigenetic regulation into Synthetic Biology has the potential of augmenting the scope of cellular engineering with the functional capabilities of that support natural development, such as integration of multiple signals over time to support cellular fate decisions that are stably inherited and the execution of temporally controlled gene expression programs. To address this need, the proposed research aims will establish a versatile circuit design platform that leverages epigenetic regulation to elicit memory and temporally regulated expression programming in mammalian cells, such as cellular timers to orchestrate gene expression sequences, recorders for monitoring and appropriately responding to disease in the host and artificial cell differentiation to drive cells to adopt distinct and complementary functional roles. These capabilities will be critical for engineering novel cell therapies to effectively tackle complex diseases and address future therapeutic challenges.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health because it is expected to enhance long-term neurological and neurodevelopmental outcomes following in-utero spina bifida repair through use of innovative strategies, thereby representing a major national cost as measured by both patient and their caregivers’ quality of life and economic burden. Though combination of surgical technique and a regenerative biomaterial with beneficial properties, these studies will provide fundamental insights into how spinal cord deterioration can be mitigated, leading to a foundation for the development of new strategies for treating spina bifida in-utero. Thus, this proposal is relevant to the part of the NIH’s missions and goals pertaining to enhancing health and reducing illness and disability, and to foster innovative research strategies and their applications as a basis for ultimately protecting and improving health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The biological mechanisms that drive genetic susceptibility to ovarian cancer are not well understood. This grant will use ultra-sensitive sequencing to characterize with high resolution TP53 mutations in fallopian tube during normal aging and in women with susceptibility to ovarian cancer to determine whether elevated risk of ovarian cancer is associated with increased somatic TP53 clonal evolution. This research will increase our understanding of ovarian carcinogenesis and enable to develop better strategies for ovarian cancer prevention and prediction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Although tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKis) such as imatinib revolutionized the treatment of Philadelphia chromosome-positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia (Ph+ALL) and chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), the TKis will not eradicate leukemia in majority of patients. We propose to test completely novel anti- Ph+ALL/CML approach involving targeting the DNA polymerase theta to induce “synthetic lethality” in leukemia stem cells, while sparing normal counterparts. Our findings may have broad application to treat other tumors displaying specific defects in DNA repair mechanisms.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE This is a competing renewal application for a D43 Fogarty International Center-sponsored Global Infectious Disease Research Training Program in Vaccine Development and Public Health between the International Centre for Diarrhoeal Disease Research in Dhaka, Bangladesh (icddr,b), and the Massachusetts General Hospital (MGH) in Boston. The program focuses on long-term training in laboratory sciences and public health, includes both degree and non- degree programs, and provides individual and institutional capacity building in Bangladesh. The program builds upon ongoing and active scientific collaborations between the icddr,b and MGH, including on Vibrio cholerae, typhoid fever, and enteric infections, as well as adding training in respiratory infections and emerging pathogens, with a goal of continuing to build local capacity in biomedical investigation of host-pathogen interactions and vaccine development in Bangladesh.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypothesis-driven biomedical research often requires the de novo generation of gene-length or longer DNA constructs. However, existing DNA assembly technologies require considerable hands-on time and are difficult to multiplex and scale. The goal of this proposal is to develop a new in vivo gene assembly technology that will both increase the throughput and reduce the cost of long DNA construction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Experimental insight into the mechanism of organic reactions is critical for the rational design of new and improved methodologies for the synthesis of medicinally relevant organic molecules. This proposal addresses this integral need by utilizing experimental and computational approaches to understand reaction mechanisms in two emerging areas of catalysis where new reaction discovery has far outpaced mechanistic understanding – (a) the conversion of abundant carbon-hydrogen bonds to valuable new carbon- carbon bonds commonly known as C-H functionalization; and (b) methodologies that combine nickel and photocatalysts to forge valuable new carbon-carbon or carbon-heteroatom bonds from inexpensive precursors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will advance our understanding of the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary effectiveness of a novel park-based PA intervention in adults with SMI. This project is relevant to the mission of NIH and the National Institute of Mental Health because it will 1) improve physical activity and reduce cardiometabolic risk in SMI populations, and 2) identify novel implementation and dissemination processes and mechanisms by utilizing local parks and certified peer specialists (CPSs) to deliver the PA intervention within existing mental health services. This study will lay the foundation for large-scale effectiveness trials, which can lead to improvements in PA and reduction of cardiometabolic health disparities in adults with SMI.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Each year, roughly 600,000 patients served in U.S. trauma centers develop posttraumatic stress disorder or depression after traumatic injury, but few receive mental health follow-up care. The Trauma Resilience and Recovery Program is a sustainable, stepped-care model that has addressed the mental health needs of over 8,000 patients in four Level I-II trauma centers and is being adopted by 8 additional trauma centers in the Carolinas. This study will examine the effectiveness and implementation of TRRP with a diverse sample of 350 patients served at The George Washington University hospital.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Testing a Scalable Model of Care to Improve Patients’ Access to Mental Health Services after Traumatic Injury

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Methamphetamine use and HIV infection share a common route of transmission (i.e., injection) and some common long-term adverse outcomes including impaired cognitive and immune functions. However, neither the specific types of cells nor the precise molecular causes of these outcomes are well understood, and little is known about how the effects of HIV and methamphetamine might exacerbate these symptoms. We will therefore use cutting edge genomic techniques to develop critical new insights into the human brain and its dysfunction in response to HIV and methamphetamine use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Human GABAB receptor and human calcium-sensing receptor are dimeric G protein-coupled receptors that mediate key biological phenomena including neurotransmission and Ca2+ homeostasis. Here we address the fundamental questions of how these receptors are activated by extracellular stimuli and how their functions are regulated. Defects in the signaling activities of these receptors are associated with disorders of the brain, bone and mineral metabolism, and our work will inform about the disease mechanisms and assist the design of novel therapeutic agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) is a major unmet clinical need given its substantial burden of morbidity and mortality and absence of effective therapies. The prevalence of HFpEF is significantly higher among women than men and emerging data suggest that sex differences in inflammatory pathways may contribute to the female susceptibility to HFpEF. To improve our limited understanding of the pathogenesis of HFpEF, we will study upstream mediators of inflammation as they relate to clinical precursors and HFpEF outcomes in men vs women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Yupik people of St. Lawrence Island are disproportionately affected by hazardous contaminants from formerly used defense sites that harm their lands, waters, traditional foods, health and well-being; they are also affected by the long-range transport of pollutants into the Arctic. This study addresses a primary environmental public health concern through investigation of the nature, extent, biological effects, and human health implications of contamination from the formerly used defense site at Northeast Cape on St. Lawrence Island, a major defense installation dating from the Cold War era that left a legacy of hazardous waste such as polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), pesticides, and mercury. The research will inform remediation decisions and public health assessments, and provide data and implement actions necessary for re-establishing the displaced traditional community at Northeast Cape, as well as serve as a model for improving health outcomes of arctic communities broadly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Osteoarthritis (OA) is a highly prevalent degenerative joint disease for which there is no cure or effective therapy. Oxidative stress plays a key role in the development and progression of OA, however conventional antioxidants have had limited therapeutic success due to poor stability and bioavailability. This research aims to overcome these limitations to OA therapy, by engineering a nanomaterial with antioxidant properties that effectively reduces oxidative stress in cartilage and reduces inflammation to improve joint structure and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD) suffer from widespread tissue injuries and develop markedly increased blood levels of phosphate and fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23). We have experimental evidence suggesting that phosphate and FGF23 can directly target the heart and cause pathologic changes in cardiac structure and function. In this research proposal, we will determine how phosphate and FGF23 act on heart tissue and whether FGF23 made by heart muscle cells can cause CKD-associated heart injury, which would suggest that CKD patients might benefit from therapies tackling phosphate and FGF23.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative Despite knowledge that age, germline mutations (e.g. BRCA1, BRCA2, or PALB2), and family history of cancer are all risk factors for breast cancer, understanding what makes one person more susceptible to this disease compared to another is not well known. We propose to leverage two remarkable discoveries we have made with our innovative microfluidic platform, mechano-Node-Pore Sensing (mechano-NPS) —breast epithelial cells from younger and older women have different mechanical properties, and cells from young women who are at very high risk of cancer because they carry a germline mutation appeared mechanically “older” than the women’s chronological ages—to develop a breast cancer susceptibility detection system, which will measure the “mechanical age” of a woman’s cells. Clinically useful genetic testing relies on a handful of known monogenic risk traits, but we hypothesize that emergent mechanical properties, measured from a few hundred cells, are a characteristic of the biology that underlies cancer susceptible states, even those that are polygenic or epigenetic in nature and are passed within a family but that have so far defied definition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Food allergy is a serious and rapidly growing public health concern and the lack of a thorough understanding of disease mechanisms has adversely affected the development of highly effective therapies. Our proposed studies examine how a gut protein named resistin like molecule beta (RELMb) acts to disrupt immune tolerance to ingested foods to result in food allergy. We will also determine how targeting this protein can reset the immune system towards tolerance of ingested food allergens and these studies will allow the development of novel, effective therapies and prevention strategies to aid patients with food allergy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT There continues to be a need for clinician scientists who are skilled in modern scientific methods and have the background to develop novel approaches to the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of diseases affecting the heart, lungs, and blood over the entire life course. The proposed Duke NHLBI Scientist-Clinician-Investigator Stimulating access to Research during Residency (Duke NHLBI SCI-StARR) program provides dedicated research time to Resident-Investigators fromthe Departments of Pediatrics, Medicine, and Surgery to foster their maturation into independent physician-scientists who use cutting-edge methods of laboratory and clinical research to pursue long-term academic careers investigating important issues related to human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Excessive alcohol use contributes to a wide range of negative health outcomes, including accidents, violence, alcohol dependence, and cardiovascular disease. Existing interventions to reduce alcohol use may not be appropriate for TNB people, both due to inapplicable and potentially unacceptable content (e.g., gender- specific drinking guidelines) and because they do not address anti-TNB stigma as a key determinant of alcohol use in this population. Relationship-focused interventions have the potential to jointly address alcohol use and co-occurring depression/anxiety symptoms in TNB people by reducing adverse relationship experiences (e.g., intimate partner violence) that result from stigma—and leveraging supportive romantic relationships as a buffer against the effects of stigma.

PHR: NARRATIVE Regardless of the biological source (bacterial, fungal, plant, animal, or engineered organism), natural product scientists face a common bottleneck: structure elucidation of compounds found in complex mixtures. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid use in adults including pregnant women has skyrocketed in recent years which led to the government's declaration of the opioid epidemic as a public health emergency in 2017. Newborns exposed to opioids prenatally are at high risk for developing a drug withdrawal syndrome known as Neonatal Opioid Withdrawal Syndrome (NOWS). In this proposal we will identify predictors of NOWS and chart the neurodevelopmental outcome of newborns with NOWS with the ultimate goal of developing tools that will allow clinicians to intervene early, improve care for these infants and improve their long term developmental outome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative (public health related) Seizure disorders (epilepsies) are very common and some children suffering from seizures also have autism and intellectual disabilities. In this proposal, we will use mutation-bearing mouse and cell models, including patient- derived cells, to in-depth study the disease mechanisms and test a novel rescue option via repairing impaired protein trafficking. Our goal is to design the most effective treatment option based on the specific patho- mechanisms and correct the problem at the root level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE (PROJECT NARRATIVE)  The proposed research is relevant to public health because it provides detailed insight into the fundamental mechanism of mitochondrial fission, an essential process in cellular homeostasis. Consequently, mitochondrial division is misregulated in several diseases, leading to organelle dysfunction and eventually cell death. Therefore, the proposed research aims dissect the regulatory mechanisms that govern organelle division and the physiologic changes associated with altered mitochondrial morphology to identify novel therapeutic targets and inform future studies that advance disease diagnosis, treatment and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although more than 170 RNA modifications have been identified so far, we only know the function of a few of these, mainly due to technological limitations. The goal of the proposed research is to bring the power of mass laddering technology from proteomics to RNA for developing a direct RNA sequencing and quantitative mapping tool for multiple RNA modifications at single-base resolution all in a single analysis, as a critical step toward elucidating their possible impact on human health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project examines how being on cardiopulmonary bypass activates a severe inflammatory response that impairs the function of all most every organ in the body, especially in infants. We will test how a pro-inflammatory molecule is activated by bypass, how this molecule causes damage to organs, and if blocking this molecule reduces post-bypass inflammation/organ damage. The resulting data will be used to help new ways of protecting infants during cardiac surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The major goal of this proposal is to investigate the role and underlying mechanism(s) of IGF2BP2 (a reader of RNA N6-methyladenosine) in MLL-rearranged (MLLr) acute myeloid leukemia (AML) pathogenesis and leukemia stem/initiating cell (LSC/LIC) self-renewal, and to also assess the therapeutic potential of pharmacological inhibition IGF2BP2 in treating MLLr AML. The success of this project will define the pathological function of IGF2BP2 in MLLr AML biology and provide profound novel insights into the complex mechanisms underlying MLLr AML pathogenesis and LSC/LIC maintenance, and may also lead to the development of effective novel targeted therapeutic strategies to treat MLLr AML. Therefore, our project is of great significance in both basic science and translational research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will define a newly recognized system for communication between the immune systems of the skin and gut. The work builds on the scientific premise that the exposure of intestinal stromal fibroblasts to hyaluronic acid fragments released from the skin enhances the capacity of these precursor cells to differentiate into adipocytes. The project will show how this process of reactive adipogenesis is important for antimicrobial defense and inflammation of the intestine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Tuberculosis, one of the world's most important diseases, with 10 million cases and 1.6 million deaths in 2017, is the leading cause of death from a single infectious agent worldwide (and among the top ten causes of all death). BCG, the currently administered vaccine against tuberculosis, is only partially effective. This proposal will apply a combination of novel strategies to develop a vaccine that is safer and much more potent than BCG, comprising a highly attenuated Mycobacterium tuberculosis engineered for precise control of its in vivo growth and clearance so as to maximize its immunoprotective response and simultaneously eliminate its capacity to disseminate in an immunocompromised host.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Several adult and pediatric cancers are driven by activating RET fusions/mutations which can be effectively treated by selpercatinib, a novel, FDA-approved selective RET inhibitor. Unfortunately, resistance to selpercatinib is both uncharacterized and a liability. This proposal seeks to computationally and preclinically characterize intrinsic and acquired mechanisms of genomic and non-genomic resistance to selective RET inhibition to identify therapeutic strategies that prevent or delay the development of resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative This project is relevant to public health because it addresses a novel mechanism of mesenchymal lineage dysfunction and bone loss in aging. If successful, it will provide a scientific basis for development of new strategies to prevent and/or treat bone loss. It is also expected to advance the field of bone biology by elucidating yet unknown mechanisms connecting phagocytic activity of mesenchymal stromal cells, subsequent metabolic disruption, senescence and their dysfunction leading to decreased osteogenic capacity and bone loss. This is highly relevant to the NIH mission of developing fundamental knowledge that will help to reduce the burdens of human aging and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol toxicity is a leading cause of liver disease. The long-term goal of this research project is to investigate how alcohol changes protein signaling and activity in the liver through modification of cysteine and lysine amino acid residues. We will study these processes to better understand how alcohol-associated liver disease occurs and to develop targeted therapeutic interventions to protect the liver from alcohol toxicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) is a blood cancer that results in the death of the majority of patients. The body's immune system, particularly T cells, may recognize and eradicate the leukemia cells but are often unable to do so due to negative signals that are generated by the leukemia. The work in this proposal will allow us to better understand how drugs that target leukemia impact the immune system, which will help develop future therapeutic strategies for this lethal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: A central question in biology is to understand how the naive genome in the early embryo progressively undergoes a series of modifications to control gene expression in “time and space” such that proper cellular differentiation programs are correctly implemented. We recently investigated embryonic germ layer formation, the earliest cell fate determination process and demonstrated that Foxh1 and its associated transcription factors functions at the top of a hierarchy of interactions by marking developmental genes for activation beginning with the onset of zygotic gene expression. Here, we propose to tease out the interactions between maternal transcription factors and chromatin and uncover how the genome of embryos undergoes major structural changes as they proceed from pluripotent to differentiated cell states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative I will learn how cannabis (specifically CBD) products have been researched and regulated and how to apply natural language processing (NLP). I will field a detailed survey with open- and close-ended questions to (1) Describe the characteristics of CBD users, (2) Characterize CBD use as a substitute or adjunct to other medications, and (3) Characterize self-reported CBD- related adverse events. I will apply modern text analysis approaches vested natural language processing to analyze responses to open-ended questions, discovering responses that cannot be anticipated based on current understanding or may be missed by theoretical expectations.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) are myeloid neoplasms with dismal prognosis, frequent progression to acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and no effective treatment. The goal of this proposal is to investigate G⍺s, the alpha subunit of the stimulatory G protein, as a therapeutic target for MDS with splicing factor mutations and identify opportunities for therapeutic interventions that inhibit its activation or downstream signaling. This work can establish a new therapeutic target and can lead to novel therapies that can transform the treatment of MDS, AML and possibly other cancers.

PHR: Narrative  Frontonasal dysplasia (FND) are congenital craniofacial disorders that profoundly impact the form and function of the face, nose, and mouth. FND patients require multiple corrective surgeries and often suffer life-long impairment. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The picornaviruses are a large family of viruses that cause a range of human diseases, including paralysis, hand foot and mouth disease in young children, and many cases of the common cold. These viruses replicate using an RNA-dependent RNA polymerase enzyme that is very error prone, resulting in viruses that can rapidly adapt to different cell types or become resistant to antiviral drugs. The primary focus of this project is to gain an atomic level structural understanding of the basic protein-protein and protein-RNA interactions that control virus replication with a secondary focus to understand why the viral polymerase is so error prone and use this information to interfere with its normal function in ways that could lead to new vaccines or antiviral drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Community-based interventions to improve psychosocial wellbeing and reduce sedentary behavior among insufficiently active Black adults are lacking. This study will be the first to establish the feasibility and acceptability of a culturally adapted, light-intensity yoga intervention to improve psychosocial wellbeing, reduce sedentary behavior, and promote movement among insufficiently active Black adults and to demonstrate whether the intervention can be delivered with fidelity across two geographically distinct sites, a large urban city and a more rural, medically underserved nonmetropolitan area. If the efficacy of this yoga-based intervention is confirmed in a larger, multi-site efficacy trial, it could offer an attractive, scalable community- and faith-based intervention to improve psychosocial wellbeing and physical activity in low active Black adults and reduce health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this study is to optimize and validate a series of 3D Ultrashort Echo Time (UTE) MRI sequences with TEs ~100 times shorter than those of clinical sequences for comprehensive evaluation of joints with hemophilic arthropathy (HA) through assessment of hemosiderin, cartilage, and the osteochondral junction. We will first optimize a series of UTE MRI techniques in phantoms and human patellar samples, then validate them in ex vivo tissues from hemophilia patients following total knee arthroplasty (n=10) and from normal cadaveric human knee joints (n=10). Finally, we will apply the optimized 3D UTE and clinical MRI techniques in three groups of hemophilia patients with mild (n=20), moderate (n=20), and severe (n=20) HA at two time points (baseline and 12 months) and in one group of age-matched healthy volunteers (n=20) once, to evaluate the outcomes of prophylaxis by correlating cross-sectional and longitudinal UTE and clinical MRI measures with Hemophilia Joint Health Scores (HJHSs), Pettersson radiograph scores, and other self-reported outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  There is a paucity of effective treatments for cerebral palsy and this proposal tests new promising drugs aimed at a preventive cure for this disease. These are new drugs aimed at inhibiting an enzyme present in brain called neuronal nitric oxide synthase. New information about how these drugs act, how they affect brain cells, and how effective they are in an animal model of cerebral palsy will be very valuable for future translation to clinical use in humans throughout the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Public Health Relevance In comparison to many other childhood cancers, the prognosis of pediatric brain cancers remains poor. Targeting pathways that relate information from the tumor microenvironment and serve as intracellular regulatory hubs presents new opportunities for developing innovative therapeutic approaches, including in pediatric brain tumors. The proposed research will develop a tunable three-dimensional cell culture platform that is compatible with automated high- throughput screening for targeting an oncogenic signaling pathway that serves as a central integrator of information from the tumor microenvironment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Every day, humans and other animals make decisions based on our preferences. This project will investigate how the lateral habenula and dorsal raphe nucleus, both implicated in disorders such as depression and anxiety, are involved in these decisions, which are an indispensable part of our lives and a key determinant of mental health. Understanding the role of these structures in subjective decision-making will lay the groundwork for future investigations of the behavioral and neural systems that underlie depression, anxiety, and related disorders, and open the door to new therapeutic avenues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Personalized cancer therapy represents one of the promising strategy of cancer treatment, however, the success rate is still limited to only a fraction of the patients. The purpose of this project is to examine novel mechanisms of cancer progression with a specific focus on how genomic copy number alterations and to study the Achilles’ heel of cancer cells associated with the presence of these genomic events. Because these alterations are very frequent in cancer but absent from normal tissues, these efforts have the potential to identify novel therapeutic targets to improve cancer patients’ outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: This project will examine maternal phthalate exposure across pregnancy and the postpartum to determine the extent to which these metabolic disrupting chemicals may influence body weight/composition changes and cardiometabolic health during the first four years after childbirth. Newer statistical modeling approaches will be used to identify sensitive windows of exposure during which phthalates most impact maternal cardiometabolic health. The results of this project will provide important knowledge about how metabolic disrupting chemicals during pregnancy and the early postpartum impact cardiometabolic trajectories, with long-term implications for women’s health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Medulloblastoma (MB) is the most common pediatric malignant brain tumor and has a global impact on children's overall health. Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell immunotherapy has the potential to improve outcomes in patients with MB; however, CAR T cells efficacy for brain tumors have been limited this far. In this study, we propose to overcome current CAR T cell limitations and enhance CAR T cell efficacy for MB by establishing CAR T cells targeting two brain tumor antigens, silencing negative T cell regulators, and targeting suppressive effectors of the brain tumor microenvironment including tumor associated macrophages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Regulation of transcription by transcription factors and coactivators is a key mechanism for control of cell growth, differentiation, and development. Defects in transcriptional regulation directly contribute to many human illnesses. Our proposed work will identify conserved fundamental regulatory mechanisms and gene-specific functions of transcription factors and coactivators that explain how diverse transcription factors cooperate to precisely modulate gene expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is caused by the inability to regulate blood glucose levels due to decreased islet β cell function or mass and has been attributed to loss of β-cell identity or de-differentiation. While the etiology of β- cell immaturity in T2D is unclear, impairments in nuclear-encoded mitochondrial gene expression and transcription factor expression occur. These studies will investigate how the transcription factors MAFA and MAFB and mitochondrial health control human β-cell identity and function to maintain β-cell maturity and proper insulin secretion.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed program will have significant, long-term impact on health research in Ghana and the West Africa subregion by building research ethics capacity in individuals and institutions and by strengthening the faculty and curriculum at the new MSc. in Bioethics Program at the University of Ghana. To achieve these aims, we will provide training and mentorship for faculty members at the UG Bioethics Program, co-create and implement a capacity building program designed to meet the needs of key institutions in Ghana’s research ethics system, and provide in-depth training and opportunities for professional development to 24 health professionals and academic researchers who will become experts in research ethics and integrity and leaders at their institutions. These activities will shape health research and research ethics in Ghana and the subregion to improve population health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project examines behavioral and neurocognitive correlates of reading to differentiate contributions of executive function (EF) weaknesses from ADHD status in dyslexia. Using a longitudinal design, this research aims to (1) bring a novel understanding of how ADHD diagnosis and EF weaknesses impact behavioral and neurocognitive reading growth among students with dyslexia, (2) offer a novel test of the Multiple Deficit Model, (3) offer novel data on EF brain networks in dyslexia, (4) and inform approaches for assessment and intervention for struggling readers. Our discovery of behavioral and neurocognitive reading growth will offer the largest and longest study of dyslexia to date, with insights as to whether EF or ADHD status may prevent some students with dyslexia from closing gaps in reading performance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Type 2 diabetes begins with resistance to insulin and then transitions to impaired insulin secretion by unknown mechanisms. We have identified novel mutations in Cela2a gene that cause impaired insulin secretion and sensitivity in patients with metabolic syndrome and diabetes. We aim to discover novel drug targets for diabetes by characterizing the gene and its targets in model animals, using novel molecular techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The Gram-negative bacterial pathogens Escherichia coli and Salmonella infect the gastrointestinal tract and are leading causes of morbidity in diverse patient populations. Infections caused by these pathogens pose a significant and urgent threat to public health and developing new antimicrobial strategies that target these organisms with minimal impact on the gut microbiome are needed. The transition metal iron (Fe) is an essential nutrient for E. coli and Salmonella, and the Fe-acquisition systems these pathogens use to obtain Fe from the host may provide new non-traditional antibacterial approaches that target these pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE According to the CDC, obesity has reached epidemic proportions, with over 60% of the U.S. population being overweight or obese, thus, there is a serious demand for the development of new therapeutics to combat obesity and its sequelae. Excess weight gain leads to dysfunction of mitochondria, essential organelles that convert ingested nutrients into energy that can be used by the body. Mitochondrial dysfunction within the brain is especially detrimental as the brain is critically involved in the regulation of body weight, therefore, by investigating mechanisms that can improve mitochondrial function in the brain, I hope to discover a novel, effective and safe target for the treatment of obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: In this proposal we investigate the function of discrete neuronal activity dynamics that emerge in the prefrontal cortex while animals reinstate heroin seeking, and how such activity is modulated by both progesterone and its metabolite allopregnanolone as they suppress reinstatement. The proposed research is relevant to public health as elucidating the precise mechanisms underlying drug-seeking behavior can guide development of more effective treatment approaches for opioid use disorder. The proposed research is, furthermore, relevant to NIH's mission as it pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will contribute to the understanding of neural circuits that underlie motivated behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Native Americans are a vastly underrepresented minority population across all scientific disciplines. Herein, “Advancing Resource & Research Opportunities in Environmental Health Sciences (ARRO-EHS)” proposes to strengthen the academic and research ecosystem at Salish Kootenai College (SKC), a Native American serving tribal college, resulting in more competitive students for advanced degree programs in environmental health sciences. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the most common infectious cause of birth defects in the developed world, and therefore a major target for immune interventions that will disrupt viral transmission to new hosts or spread within a host. CMV enters hosts through mucosal barrier tissues, where it avoids rapid immune control by unknown mechanisms and then escapes to distant tissues. The aim of this proposal is to define mechanisms that limit T cell control of CMV in a natural mucosal site of entry and to determine how T cells modulate viral persistence and dissemination to distant tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Changes to auditory midbrain structure and function resulting from aging and age-related hearing loss may lead to neural hyperactivity and distorted neural representations of sound, which may underlie speech recognition difficulties. This project uses electrophysiology, neuroimaging, and behavioral methods to study the extent to which the auditory midbrain creates an exaggerated and atypical representation of the temporal features of sound, and whether this atypical representation is related to impaired speech recognition for older adults in challenging listening conditions. A better understanding of the extent to which neural hyperactivity and distorted temporal processing is present in the auditory midbrain of older adults and those with age-related hearing loss can inform future studies of subcortical neural hyperactivity and work towards improving speech communication outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will use genetic and computational tools to evaluate and facilitate the preclinical utility of patient- derived xenograft (PDX) models for the three most common subtypes of pediatric solid tumors: Osteosarcoma, Ewing sarcoma and Rhabdomyosarcoma (alveolar and embryonal). We will also develop novel PDX models that incorporate CRISPR/Cas9 and also have a humanized immune system. A key component is reagent/model/data sharing to enable and accelerate research in to these rare “orphan” diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Bacterially produced small molecules (i.e., natural products) have inspired many of the most important therapeutics in use today. Large-scale sequencing of bacterial (meta)genomes has revealed that the biosynthetic diversity traditionally explored in the laboratory by fermentation represents only a small fraction of what is predicted to exist in nature. This proposal brings together advanced bioinformatics, next-generation metagenomics, and total chemical synthesis to identify new antiproliferative agents that are inspired by biosynthetic gene clusters that have remained inaccessible using other natural product discovery approaches.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Mental health conditions are common among pregnant and postpartum women, and there is an urgent need to develop timely evidence regarding the safety of antipsychotic medications when used during pregnancy. We propose developing and implementing TreeScan, a novel signal detection method, for simultaneous evaluation of a broad range of potential maternal, fetal and neonatal adverse outcomes as part of a near real-time active safety surveillance system for antipsychotic medication use in pregnancy. Such an approach will not only avoid unnecessary exposure for mother and fetus to potentially harmful medications but, equally important, will provide re-assurance when no large harmful effects are detected so that women are not unnecessarily deprived of important medications for the treatment of psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Leukemias with rearrangements of the MLL (KMT2A) gene, classically seen in infants and therapy-related leukemia, remain difficult to treat and cure even with modern therapies. These leukemias highly express an RNA binding protein, MBNL1, which regulates alternative RNA splicing and is essential for leukemia cell survival. The proposed research will explore the mechanisms underlying this dependence, and further develop a new and much-needed targeted therapy against this protein for this high-risk group of leukemias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: Measurement based care (MBC) is an emerging best practice involving serial assessment of clinical status and using those findings to inform clinical decision making. However, there is a lack of research on how to best apply principles of MBC for patients with bipolar disorder. Project goals are to determine which validated bipolar disorder instrument is most acceptable and helpful in clinical care, demonstrate that the preferred instrument can be used to monitor outcomes with high fidelity in routine care, and assess feasibility of comparing effectiveness of MBC to enhanced usual care in a randomized trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This dissertation proposal highlights the continuing burden of HIV that affects adolescent girls and young women in sub-Saharan Africa. Although individual behaviors and attitudes are influenced by many interpersonal, community, and societal factors, HIV prevention research has focused on the individual as the risk-taker and therefore, the primary target for HIV prevention interventions. This study will go beyond the individual to inform the development of community and societal HIV prevention approaches and model interventions that promise the most benefit to adolescent girls and young women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In this project we will determine the roles of specialized myxoma virus-loaded white blood cells, called tumor- specific T cells, in promoting an immune response against solid tumors in mice and determine their potential for use in cancer adoptive cell immunotherapy. We hypothesize that transfer of these tumor-specific T cells will eradicate large established tumors and prevent recurrence in vivo in both mouse and human tumor models, due to their ability to 1) directly kill the tumor cells; 2) release myxoma virus to tumor cells, and 3) induce autosis in tumor cells to eliminate tumor with high heterogeneity in tumor antigen expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT (NARRATIVE) (Project Title: Folding and Degradation of Membrane Proteins) Imbalances between membrane protein folding and degradation is a cause of a number of human diseases, via inefficient folding and excessive degradation caused by inherited mutations, or overwhelming aggregation of misfolded proteins beyond cellular degradation capacity. Using our steric trapping approach for studying membrane protein folding as well as the feasible model system for studying detailed mechanisms of degradation, we will provide the basic principles for understanding membrane protein misfolding and associated disease mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The high abuse rates of therapeutic opioids have fueled a strong debate on the treatment practices of using prescription opioids and whether pain is a major factor in addiction susceptibility. The present proposal will use preclinical rodent models of chronic pain to investigate the impact of pain on opioid drug taking and relapse with a focus on understanding the contribution of the kappa opioid receptor system within the amygdala. A better understanding of kappa opioid receptors and its endogenous ligand dynorphin in mediating emotional- affective aspects of motivated behaviors in chronic pain states has translational significance for the advancement of KOR antagonists as novel therapeutics for treating opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The oxidative pentose phosphate pathway (oxiPPP) regulates cell metabolism by producing metabolic intermediates and reductive NADPH, and inhibiting LKB1-AMPK signaling through ribulose-5-phosphate (Ru-5-P), the product of the third enzyme 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase (6PGD). We provide evidence supporting that γ-6-phosphogluconolactone (γ-6PGL), a “dead end” byproduct of the oxiPPP with unknown physiological function, serves as a signaling molecule that contributes to AMPK activation by enhancing inhibition of AMPK upstream phosphatase PP2A by Src. Thus, we hypothesize that oxiPPP regulates AMPK homeostasis by balancing the opposing LKB1 and PP2A.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Type 1 diabetes causes significant increases in morbidity and mortality, and is responsible for considerable social and economic costs. A cure is urgently needed, but current gaps in our knowledge of its etiology, and a paucity of mechanistic biomarkers, are major impediments. This study proposes to fill these gaps by identifying biomarkers that can predict rates of future disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE TAM receptors (Tyro3, Axl and Mer) are dysregulated in numerous diseases including cancer, autoimmune diseases, and diseases induced by chronic inflammation. They also play important regulatory roles in adult tissues, including maintenance of the vascular and immune systems, creating challenges to target them therapeutically. This study investigates TAM receptor self- association, and association with co-receptors. Information from these studies will guide understanding of how these receptors are activated, and will inform how to effectively correct aberrant TAM receptor activity in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We aim to identify deficits in the receipt of guideline-indicated care among black patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease (PAD). We further endeavour to identify the specific role of physician implicit bias in the delivery of symptomatic PAD-related care and to develop a systems-based intervention to address disparate care delivery. In successfully completing this project, we will have preliminary data to support the development of a full-scale, multi-site intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With our new discovery of the formation of three major subsets of virus-specific CD8 T cells in response to chronic viral infection, the aim of the study is to further elucidate the cellular, molecular and genetic pathways that govern the heterogeneity in T cell exhaustion. Harnessing this knowledge, we further aim to redirect CD8 T cell differentiation to restore and enhance their antiviral function and simultaneously limit T cell exhaustion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Telomere dysfunction is a hallmark of human cancer. Telomere-repeats containing RNA (TERRA) is a key regulatory molecule of telomere homeostasis, providing a mechanism for telomere chromatin remodeling, DNA replication processivity, and homologous recombination repair. TERRA may also serve as a telomere damage stress response signal that can alarm immune cell inflammatory signaling. Investigation of TERRA will provide information on telomere maintenance in cancer and aging, and may provide new methods for early stage cancer diagnosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of the proposed project is to characterize how hearing-related behavior in daily life underlies the association between hearing loss and poor social-emotional health outcomes and whether hearing aid use can moderate this association. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will determine how and to what extent audiologic intervention can moderate the risks of depression, loneliness, and isolation following hearing loss. Findings from this study will provide evidence for the role of audiology in quality of life improvement, lay groundwork for new clinical practices to maximize intervention benefits in daily life, and demonstrate new ways to conceptualize and measure intervention outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative This K24 Mid-Career Investigator Award seeks support for Dr. Cosgrove, professor of psychiatry at Yale and Co-Director of the Translational Alcohol Research Program (TARP), an NIAAA-funded T32 for postdoctoral fellows and residents; training and mentorship activities supported by this award will take place in the context of a project on the Yale-Specialized Center of Research Excellence (SCORE) that is focused on investigating sex differences in the neurochemistry and treatment for alcohol use disorder (AUD). The K24 award will support Dr. Cosgrove in her career development with training in the areas of alcohol-related metabolomics, alcohol-induced liver disease, and mentorship skills, with a focus on diversity, equity and inclusion, with the goal of providing mentorship to a diverse group of mentees with a wide range of alcohol interests.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of this proposed study is to prepare for a multisite randomized controlled trial that will examine the efficacy of a telerehab intervention to improve upper extremity function in patients with systemic sclerosis. We will establish our multisite research team, develop our study procedures and regulatory documents, and train our occupational therapists who will assess outcomes and provide the intervention for the trial. This planning period will allow us to develop a robust U01 grant application to test the efficacy of telerehab which will provide an important step in knowledge of how to provide treatment for patients with rare disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ciliopathies are complex genetic disorders that can exhibit severe birth defects due to abnormalities in the formation or function of the cilium. A large number of proteins are thought to be involved in the cilium, but in only a few of these do we know the molecular pathways in which they function and whether they are associated with disease (ciliopathies). In this proposal, we take advantage of the explosion of genomic information from patients with rare developmental disorders and recent advances in identifying genes associated with the cilium to identify novel ciliopathies in rare and undiagnosed disease repositories, generate precision engineered mouse models corresponding to these patients, define the molecular and cellular pathways responsible for their birth defects, and generate data that can be used to predict therapeutic strategies through CPAM's drug discovery pipeline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) Abdominal pain is driven, in part, by alterations to the sensitivity of sensory neurons that innervate the intestine. The proposed studies investigate how glial cells interact with sensory neurons to influence abdominal pain and how these interactions are influenced by sex, inflammation, and early life adversity. Understanding these fundamental mechanisms that regulate gut sensory function will lead to new therapies to treat abdominal pain in irritable bowel syndrome and inflammatory bowel disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The RAS gene family encodes the central components of the RAS signaling pathway, which is the most frequently altered oncogenic pathway across all cancers but is especially prominent in pancreatic, colorectal, lung, and skin malignancies. These RAS-driven cancers collectively account for the largest single source of cancer-related mortality in the United States but are often treatable if intercepted at an early stage, meaning that new strategies are desperately needed to anticipate and prevent RAS-driven cancers. In this proposal, I outline an interdisciplinary research project grounded in my 12 years of experience in genomic data science to systematically discover new inherited genetic factors that influence the onset, progression, and dynamics of RAS-driven cancer, which has the potential to uncover previously unknown facets of cancer biology, enable preventative screening tailored to an individual’s inherited genetic risk, improve equity in clinical oncology, and nominate new targets for the prevention or treatment of these devastating malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE Most smokers are interested in quitting, more than half attempt to quit each year, and nearly all relapse within a year, largely due to difficulty managing cravings, which is a prominent symptom of withdrawal. Cigarette craving has been a target for smoking cessation treatments, however, these treatments have yielded low abstinence rates thereby prompting calls for novel treatment approaches to reduce cigarette cravings. Based on compelling laboratory data, utilization of olfactory stimuli represent a novel approach to improve smoking cessation and mitigate cigarette cravings; thus, this study will: 1) build upon basic, laboratory research to refine and evaluate the effect of a novel olfactory stimulation delivery system on cigarette cravings in vivo during a smoking cessation attempt, and 2) determine whether an olfactory stimulation delivery system can increase successful smoking cessation when paired with an established smartphone-based smoking cessation intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Parkinson’s disease (PD) is a systemic neurologic disorder and proteinopathy, influenced by the dysfunction of autophagy lysosomal pathways resulting in the accumulation of aggregated protein and neurodegeneration. Chlorinated solvents, such as trichloroethylene (TCE), are pervasive air and water contaminants and are linked to PD risk epidemiologically. This proposal investigates how inhalation of TCE impairs lysosomal function, in part by activation of LRRK2, uncovering novel mechanisms for PD risk from environmental solvent exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sensory deprivation in one modality results in adaptive reorganization in the spared modalities, a phenomenon known as crossmodal plasticity. This proposal seeks to identify, for the first time, when crossmodal functional changes emerges during early development and the underlying neural circuit rearrangement. Results from the proposed experiments will provide a clear template to guide investigation of early crossmodal changes in other sensory pathways (e.g., somatosensory), will accentuate the impact of well-balanced ambient sensory environment in sensory development and will shed light on novel therapeutic interventions for the recovery of function of deprived senses in infants with sensory disorders, e.g., congenital hearing impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative There is urgent need to identify new therapeutic targets for treating advanced ER+ breast cancer (BC) with endocrine therapy (ET) resistance and/or metastasis. Based on our important findings we postulate that FBXL16, a poorly-studied F-Box protein, promotes ER+ BC development, metastasis and ET resistance by upregulating the stability and expression levels of ERα (both wild type and the ligand-binding domain (LBD) activating mutants) and co-activator SRC-3 and thus the oncogenic ERα signaling. If proven true, our study would advance our understanding of the mechanisms underlying ET resistance and metastasis of ER+ BC, and would provide a rationale to develop novel therapy against FBXL16 for treating advanced ER+ BC, in particular those driven by ERα with LBD activating mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Exposure to wildfire smoke is known to adversely impact the pulmonary system, though there remains an overall lack of knowledge surrounding the mechanisms and health risks across this highly variable exposure landscape of wildfire smoke, particularly within the expanding Wildland Urban Interface (WUI). This grant is designed to leverage the experimental strengths across in vitro, in vivo animal, and human systems to provide data needed for the health risk assessment of complex wildfire smoke mixtures. Findings will yield populations that are at heightened risks for health effects of wildfire smoke inhalation exposures based upon nearby fuel sources, and data will be used to effectively quantify these risks across difficult to study exposure scenarios that now require health guidances.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The Stroke Net Regional Coordinating Center-University of Pittsburgh (STN-UP) will continue to leverage the regional dominance of UPMC in healthcare, the CTSI, existing clinical research collaborations at the University of Pittsburgh and other institutional resources for its successful clinical trials infrastructure. The STN-UP will continue practices that have led to successful trial recruitment and regional research network administration, while adopting new measures to further increase efficiency and capacity for entering patients into trials with equitable representation of women and minorities, and contribute to the educational, collaborative, and administrative functions of the National Clinical Coordinating Center (NCC), the National Data Management Center (NDMC) and the overall network. The combined efforts of NIH Stroke Net and STN-UP will ensure that diverse patients have access to impactful stroke trials and maintain specialized training for clinician researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS) is the most effective treatment for severe obesity; however, many patients experience significant weight regain that undermines improvements in physical and mental health. MBS patients are advised to engage in regular PA to prevent significant weight regain, but most do not, and interventions do not address patients' low internal drive to be regularly active. This study tests an Acceptance and Commitment Therapy-based intervention designed to motivate bariatric patients to make sustainable changes in physical activity to prevent significant weight regain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will use the zebrafish as a cost-efficient model system to characterize the roles that novel genes play in regulating eye lens development. The proposed experiments will address open questions about how lens cells lose their nuclei and organelles to produce the transparency of the lens and prevent cataract, while also adding to our general understanding of how cells remodel themselves in diverse tissues. Undergraduate college students at Ashland University will gain valuable experience using innovative genome manipulation, molecular biology, bioinformatic and cell visualization techniques while conducting these studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The high spatial and temporal resolution of light makes optical regulation using the light-responsive group an appealing approach for cellular events controlling, which has broad applications in cell biology, neurobiology, and biomedicine. Due to the fundamentally importance of light-responsive groups and the shortage of tools with effective red-to-near infrared sensitivity, we will try to develop an efficient system using rigidified structures based on weak covalent bond, and apply them in drug delivery for cancer treatment. Given the wide usage of these optical tools in basic science and biomedical application, these techniques would allow timed delivery of targeted bioactive molecules in deep tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Velopharyngeal (VP) anomalies, often associated with cleft palate and other craniofacial conditions, can have a substantial impact on speech and communication abilities as well as overall quality of life if unsuccessfully repaired. This investigation will provide the foundation for a successful line of focused, translational research to improve clinical assessments and speech outcomes in children born with VP anomalies as well as reduce the need for subsequent revision surgeries by developing a method for automated, pre-operative, objective, patient- specific anatomic assessment. The results of this proposal will directly contribute to NIDCD’s mission to improve the health of children with speech and resonance disorders associated with velopharyngeal dysfunction by enabling a high impact collaboration between speech physiology, craniofacial/plastic surgery, data science, and biomedical engineering, particularly in the area of precision medicine, to improve speech and surgical outcomes for children with cleft/craniofacial conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Machine learning-based predictors trained to distinguish between pathogenic and benign genetic variants have become an integral part of causal variant discovery and clinical variant classification. However, they have found limited use in genetic and genomic disease risk estimation, largely because the scores they output are not directly interpretable as disease risk, thus, making them inconsistent with current practices in genetic and genomic medicine. The objective of this study is to develop rigorous computational and statistical frameworks for the integration of variant pathogenicity predictors into the calculation of disease risk from single genes and whole genomes in a manner that is compatible with medical guidelines, accurate and clinically useful.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Strategic and interactive approaches driven by sociocultural, cognitive, and language theories have accumulated a large body of evidence documenting improvements in more complex oral and written language skills. Growing evidence demonstrates that more complex sign language skills positively predict literacy skills and may lead to improved health outcomes. This project involves new applications of theory-driven strategic and interactive approaches in an intervention program to target sign language development in deaf children between 5 and 8 years old who are at high risk of language delays.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Breast cancer is a broad range of diseases that account for approximately 6% of all cancer-related deaths worldwide and ranks as the second most common cancer diagnosis among women. While much is known about breast cancer, elucidating the metabolic processes associated with poor patient outcomes, such as the development of chemotherapeutic resistance, is crucial. The proposed project will identify important genomic and phenotypic alterations in breast cancers due to the expression and activation of the pregnane X receptor (PXR) in response to pharmacotherapeutics commonly used in the treatment of breast cancer and identify new targets to treat breast cancer more effectively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Obesity-induced non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and NAFLD-induced liver cancer are increasingly prevalent in the United States and worldwide with no FDA-approved medicine developed. This project aims to investigate the efficacy of Cannabigerol (CBG, a non- psychoactive component of cannabis) with or without combination of cannabidiol (CBD) in treatment of NAFLD/NASH, considering promising preliminary results. Successful completion of the studies can provide basis for a prospective treatment for chronic liver diseases and expand our understanding on how these diseases progress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Age related macular degeneration (AMD) is a leading cause of vision loss in individuals over 55 years of age and is increasing as the population gets older. Treatment options for early AMD are limited, but evidence from observational studies suggests that whole foods, Mediterranean diets and low glycemic load (LG) diets are associated with lower progression of AMD and vision loss. Our goal is to assess the feasibility of a dietary intervention and plan for a future multicenter clinical trial to test a cost-effective approach to slow AMD progression and vision loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE My long-term goal is to build quantitative models that predict and circumvent cancer therapy resistance, specifically focusing on protein kinases currently targeted by over 75 FDA-approved inhibitors. Unfortunately, multiple kinase mutations have been found to resist known inhibitors and drastically reduce patient survival rates, and it remains unclear why these mutations induce such dramatic drug-resistance. Through a combination of high-throughput experiments, physics-based simulation, and machine learning based data-science methods, I will identify the mechanistic impact of clinically observed kinase mutants and build models that predict if a drug- resistant mutant is newly sensitive to alternative clinical therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: This project will provide public health researchers and policy makers qualitative, historical research to make sense of the quantitative materials emerging from Russia as well as the cultural resonance and popularity of Putin’s health campaigns. This research will root these programs in anxieties over a century of demographic challenges. By outlining programs from the Russian- Soviet-then-Russian state not to control women’s reproductive health but improve men’s behaviors this project will provide a new view of Russian pronatalism as a mask for anxiety over male weakness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is a partnership between Washington University and Wysa, a mental health app company, to refine an existing digital mental health intervention that addresses symptoms of depression and/or anxiety and coexisting chronic pain (Wysa for Chronic Pain) for the unique challenges and technology use patterns of middle-aged and older adults. Using a human-centered design approach, novel just-in-time adaptive interventions (JITAIs) will be created to improve the usability of Wysa for Chronic Pain for this target population. The real-world effectiveness of these adaptations will be assessed, and the final package of adaptations will be made widely available to the public by the completion of the study period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: The proposed research project is relevant to public health because it is the first book-length interdisciplinary historical study of the environmental origins and consequences of a major chronic illness. Sweet Blood: Diabetes and the Changing Nature of Modern Health will benefit biomedical scientists, clinicians, historians of medicine, and public health experts by shedding new light on the deep historical antecedents to current social determinants of health. The project is germane to the Public Health Service because it explains how shifting relationships with mutable ecologies create or reinforce inequalities between individuals and populations, further driving diabetes prevalence alongside socioeconomic disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Social anxiety is a highly prevalent and debilitating mental health concern, yet treatment strategies are difficult to access and do not work for everyone. Targeting specific mechanisms maintaining social anxiety is an important research goal and the current study will directly test a new brief self- guided internet-based treatment that addresses avoidance and attentional control as part of the intervention. The role of attention (where someone is looking) and audio vocal behavior (like how loud someone is speaking) on treatment outcomes will be tested to inform future experimental therapeutics, to better enhance and personalize treatments for social anxiety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human behaviors seamlessly integrate perceptual and mnemonic information. To understand how the brain supports these abilities, this project will develop and evaluate biologically plausible computational models of medial temporal lobe-dependent behaviors, incorporating traditional neuroscientific methods within a deep learning framework. This integrated approach provides an unprecedented opportunity for understanding both typical and atypical memory-related behaviors, laying a foundation for future work to develop diagnostic and therapeutic tools to treat mnemonic-related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative The study proposed in this F99/K00 application investigates the relationship between Heart Rate Variability (a measure of autonomic nervous system function) and brain states in healthy, moderate to heavy daily alcohol drinkers following periods of typical consumption and abstinence. To date, the study design has been completed and all data collected, with preliminary analyses run. The F99 phase of the project will involve the remaining analyses investigating connectivity changes with and outside of the Default Mode Network across drinking states, while future directions of the project, to be conducted during a postdoctoral fellowship and the K00 phase of this fellowship, will include more advanced dynamic assessments of brain states using functional networks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brain pathologies such as neurodegenerative diseases and brain tumors have alterations in redox signaling. In the F99 phase of this proposal, brain tumor models are utilized to elucidate the mechanism by which brain tumor initiating cells suppress oxidative damage to promote their survival. For the K00 phase, continued studies with brain tumor models will shift focus to elucidate impacts on the bone marrow (BM) microenvironment to alter myeloid lineages and recruitment into the brain.
