IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PROJECT 1) Detailed analysis of cellular, molecular, and genetic information as well as spatial resolution of affected cell types is a key goal in understanding the cellular processes that give rise to Alzheimer’s disease. The current standard neuropathology protocols for sampling tissue, generally formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissue preservation, do not lend themselves to in-depth chemical and molecular analysis, nor does traditional neuropathological characterization of disease states provide sufficient detail to determine the pathophysiology of altered genes and proteins. When successfully completed, this project will have combined traditional and quantitative neuropathologic methods to better characterize AD pathologic stages and identify cases for Projects 2 and 3 and transformed donated brain tissue sampling and preservation in order to promote modern techniques and preserve valuable human tissue in a manner that is amenable to state-of-the-art molecular profiling and cell type analysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PROJECT 2) Alzheimer’s disease follows a highly stereotyped progression that differentially affects cell populations in the brain, and yet transcriptomic and epigenetic studies to date have largely focused on bulk tissue comprised of mixed cell populations, potentially obscuring key cell type-specific differences. The project proposed here will apply cutting edge single cell transcriptomic and epigenomic analysis in brain regions affected by Alzheimer’s disease (AD) pathology and across different stages of the disease to gain a dramatically higher resolution understanding of the cellular specificity of AD pathology and to identify signatures of the early pathogenesis of AD prior to the emergence of pathology. These data will help to understand differential vulnerability or resistance of specific cell types in AD, and push towards a mechanistic understanding of AD progression by identifying dysregulated gene networks within affected cell types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE New bioanalytical and computational technologies that can accurately identify cancer risks early are needed to improve cancer outcomes equitably. Here, we propose to develop an innovative spectrochemical liquid biopsy platform based on metasurface-enhanced mid-infrared absorption spectroscopy and machine-learning discrimination models. While the proposed research will optimize the novel imaging-based on-chip chemical fingerprinting technology using ovarian cancer samples, the developed diagnostic modality can be applied to detect a broad spectrum of disease-associated spectral patterns from biofluids in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PROJECT 3) Alzheimer’s disease involves a predictable progression of neuropathological protein aggregation across brain regions. New highly multiplexed methods for fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) and immunohistochemistry (IHC), combined with detailed transcriptome-based classifications of cell types, offer a new high-resolution approach to understand selective vulnerability and resistance of different cell types to AD pathology. The goal of this project is to develop and apply highly multiplexed RNA combined with IHC methods to study quantitative changes in specific cell types with increasing AD severity, dysregulated molecular pathways in specific cell types, and relationships between pathological protein deposition and specific cell types in Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Inflammatory diseases are often the consequence of inappropriate T cell effector activity or insufficient immune suppressive mechanisms. We have found that metabolic pathways are highly dynamic and exert strong effects on T cell differentiation and function. This study will explore metabolic vulnerabilities of inflammatory and regulatory T cells in methionine and nucleotide synthesis pathways that may be exploited to modulate T cell subsets in inflammatory bowel disease and other inflammatory disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative There is an urgent need to develop new strategies to improve uptake of cardiac and pulmonary rehabilitation. This is especially true in rural communities where resources are limited and transportation to center-based programs is a major barrier. We propose to examine whether implementing a stepped care model, in which patients have access to a hierarchy of interventions, is more effective than center-based programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative  Early detection of young people at clinical high risk for psychosis offers a critical opportunity for early intervention to improve the course of illness, and perhaps even prevent onset entirely. Current interview-based methods for psychosis risk detection lack specificity, and are only available in a handful of research centers in the United States. The proposed study aims to improve accessibility and broaden impact of high risk screening by testing brief computerized measures, ultimately able to be administered on the internet, and to improve prediction by focusing on tasks specific to underlying mechanisms driving emerging psychotic symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Tick-borne viruses, including the U.S.-endemic Powassan virus, cause a substantial and increasing burden of human illness, and more knowledge is needed about how they replicate and cause disease. This project will investigate a poorly-understood component of the Powassan virus life cycle, which is recombination within viral RNA molecules. This work will evaluate whether Powassan virus creates recombinant RNA molecules and whether there are differences in recombination when the virus replicates in ticks versus mammalian hosts, with the ultimate goal of understanding how recombination may contribute to disease and transmission in tick-borne viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Radical S-adenosyl-L-methionine enzymes are found in all kingdoms of life and perform reactions that underpin human health, disease, and metabolism. We propose to study the mechanisms of these reactions, focusing on the central role of organometallic intermediates. Our approach is to investigate structurally and functionally faithful model complexes of these reactive species to elucidate their roles in catalysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Although the role of p53 in tumor suppression is indisputable, it remains a daunting task how to target this pathway for cancer therapy. Like Mdm2, the VPRBP-USP2 axis is critical for repressing p53 function in human cancers; unlike Mdm2, the VPRBP-USP2 axis acts as a master regulator of PD-L1 expression in a p53-independnet manner. By using both tissue culture and animal models, we will dissect the mechanisms of both USP2 and VPRBP in regulating p53–mediated tumor suppression as well as their effects in anti-tumor immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative This hybrid clinical-implementation study will be conducted in 3 phases: 1) a pre-implementation phase using CFIR to determine the barriers and facilitators of the adoption of TASSH and to develop the practice facilitation (PF) intervention; 2) an implementation phase which will compare, in a cluster RCT of 30 HIV clinics among 960 HIV+ patients, the effect of the PF intervention vs. a self-directed condition (i.e. receipt of information for implementation of HTN control without PF) on BP reduction; and 3) a post-implementation phase using RE- AIM to compare the effect of PF vs. self-directed condition on adoption and sustainability of TASSH. The PF intervention will comprise an advisory board of key stakeholders who will provide leadership support for TASSH adaptation and its implementation; practice facilitators, and trained nurses, who will deliver TASSH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Vibrio cholerae is a globally important pathogen and the burden of cholera is estimated to reach several million cases annually. V. cholerae virulence depends on a cell-cell communication process called quorum sensing that controls the timing of production and release of virulence factors and the formation of biofilms. The investigations proposed here will expand our understanding of how quorum sensing controls virulence in this important pathogen. In addition, this study will facilitate the development of synthetic strategies for controlling V. cholerae virulence and could have significant ramifications for improving human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative BDNF gene therapy for Alzheimer’s disease is neuroprotective and improves cognitive function, but delivery by direct brain injection is invasive and treats only a small percentage of cortex. Intrathecal infusion of AAV9-BDNF gene therapy is simple, minimally invasive, and broadly treats the entire cerebral cortex when combined with two hours of Trendelenburg positioning. This novel approach could enhance the safety and efficacy of gene therapy clinical trials for Alzheimer’s disease and other neurological disorders, and could support the discovery of new preclinical gene therapies for Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the enormous public health problem of suicide among adolescents, little progress has been made toward improving assessment and prevention for this vulnerable group. We will conduct a prospective, longitudinal study to examine the near-term temporal associations between within-person fluctuations in sleep disturbance, dysregulation in affective, cognitive and arousal-related systems, and changes in suicidality over time in ultra-high risk adolescents. Critically, since sleep is a modifiable risk factor, our findings hold great promise to inform the development or modification of existing sleep/mental health interventions to lower suicide risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The lens is a complex tissue whose proper development requires the precise spatiotemporal induction of differentiation-specific gene expression and of organelle removal from the central light path to create a transparent tissue whose function is to focus images on the retina. We discovered an essential role in both these processes for the signal transduction molecule PI3K. In this grant we propose studies that will define the mechanisms by which PI3Ks govern the expression of genes that are critical to acquisition of the lens fiber cell phenotype as well as the PI3K-dependent pathways that regulate the loss of organelles from the center of the lens to form an organelle free zone (OFZ).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer vaccines offer the possibility of stimulating the immune system to provide sustained protection against tumor growth. The main goal of this proposal is to develop an all-in-one peptide vaccine delivery system that provides targeted antigen and adjuvant delivery to professional antigen presenting cells. We anticipate that the proposed research will lead to an anti-cancer peptide antigen delivery system that is ready for rapid translation, while elucidating important fundamental mechanism questions for peptide antigen delivery.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Stunted growth and development are leading risk factors in the global burden of disease, and if trends continue, the global community will fail to meet 2025 stunting targets established by the World Health Assembly by 27 million children. The Grandi Byen research offers not only the promise of insights into complex biological and psychosocial mechanisms, but feasible solutions to confront stunted growth and development. The intervention taps available resources with high impact potential – willing parents vested in their child’s development, affordable animal source foods for high quality nutrition, and WASH behaviors to mitigate urban infection risks. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic short sleep is increasingly common in the United States and is a risk factor for the most common tauopathy, Alzheimer disease. We recently discovered that chronic short sleep hastens the temporal progression of tauopathy. The proposed studies will identify mechanisms underlying the sleep loss- induced progression of tauopathy and thereby reveal therapeutic targets to prevent sleep loss worsening of tauopathies, including Alzheimer disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative The proposed project aims to test a new neurofeedback intervention for adolescents with Tourette Syndrome that trains them to control activity in a region of their brain believed to be involved in tic generation. We will also monitor how the intervention affects brain patterns to confirm that it is working in the expected manner and to explore its effects on brain networks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Project Narrative Traumatic brain injury remains a significant public health issue with diffuse axonal injury (DAI) as a primary contributor to patient morbidity, especially in pediatric populations. I will test the hypotheses that unmyelinated axon segments serve as initiating loci for DAI pathogenesis with the cytoskeletal protein spectrin contributing to secondary (delayed) axotomy and that neuroprotective strategies to preserve cytoskeletal integrity will improve outcomes. Integration of histology, behavioral studies, and advanced neuroimaging techniques will provide novel insights into DAI pathobiology and create a model that predicts injury severity and prognosticates post- traumatic recovery.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE In non-pandemic periods, tuberculosis (TB) is the leading killer from a curable infectious disease, while malnutrition, both undernutrition and poor nutrition leading to conditions such as diabetes mellitus, is the most important driver of TB disease globally. This Global Infectious Diseases Research Training Program (GIDRTP) aims to strengthen existing educational and research linkages with the University of Virginia and the Kilimanjaro Christian Medical University College/ Kilimanjaro Clinical Research Institute in Tanzania, to develop postdoctoral research leaders working in malnutrition and TB. Utilizing lessons learned from prior GIDRTPs at University of Virginia and harnessing the current infrastructure of funding from the National Institutes of Health, Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, European and Developing Countries Trials Partnership, World Health Organization and the Danish Ministry of Foreign Affairs for TB and malnutrition research in Tanzania, we aim to support postdoctoral trainees' growth to junior scientists and content leaders that will compete for independent funding, set research agendas, make policy and benefit their communities in-line with the World Health Organization's End TB Strategy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Pigments produced by bacterial pathogens contribute to the virulence of the microorganism. Here we describe the discovery of and propose to elucidate the composition of an uncharacterized pigment of the human pathogen Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus). It is also our objective to identify genes involved in its biosynthesis and regulation, and how the pigment aids in bacterial fitness or pathogenesis. Our proposed work is likely to advance the understanding of how S. pyogenes survives in the body and may advance efforts to develop a successful vaccine against this pathogen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Brain tissues or plasma samples from patients and mice with Alzheimer’s disease (AD) contain increased levels of mast cells (MCs), MC activator IgE, IgE receptor FcεR1, and MC activation products. Our preliminary studies demonstrated that MC-deficiency or inhibition with an over-the-counter human anti-allergy drug Zaditor® improved AD-like pathologies and memory loss in mice. This proposal will test the hypothesis that MCs play a direct role in AD pathogenesis and the human anti-allergy drugs may have therapeutic potential in AD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Chronic pain is a prevalent and difficult-to-treat problem for at least half of all persons receiving opioid agonist therapy (OAT) for opioid use disorder – i.e., buprenorphine/ naloxone (BUP) or methadone maintenance treatment (MMT). Hatha yoga may be a useful and attractive adjunctive treatment for pain in OAT patients that could serve to decrease suffering related to pain as well as decrease risk of relapse and improve quality of life.. In this project, we propose to study various potential intervention components, with the goal of create an optimized yoga intervention package that can be tested in the next step in this line of research, which is fully- powered efficacy trial with the primary outcome of reduced life interference due to pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance to Public Health (2-3 sentences): Annually, approximately 1 in 12,500 Americans are newly diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and over 12,000 die from the disease. The overall survival rate of AML patients is below 25% for adults and 70% for children and these poor outcomes are largely due to high rates of resistance to the current standard of care treatments and disease relapse. The aim of this proposal is to identify the molecular underpinnings of AML pathogenesis and therapy resistance to develop more effective therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Annual lung cancer screening and tobacco treatment are pillars of cancer prevention and control yet are often not provided by physicians or received by patients in primary care settings. New evidence suggests that personalized risk feedback including a patient's genetic and clinical information could highlight the benefits of these practices and engage physicians and patients in improved care. This study will test the impact of a genetically-informed intervention on physicians' ordering and patients' completion of lung cancer screening and tobacco treatment in primary care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is a significant pathogen for elderly populations, but despite decades of effort, no vaccine exists to protect this or any population from RSV infections. This project will develop a novel RSV vaccine candidate for the elderly using cotton rats as a surrogate human model. The results of the study will provide new information about elderly immune responses to RSV and vaccines and key data to support planning for clinical trials of the vaccine safety and efficacy in the elderly.

Here, we use a new method to grow tumors alongside invading immune cells as 3-dimensional “patient- derived organoids” (PDOs) to understand and improve cancer immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Relevance Whereas most technology development related to T cells derives from study of peptide antigens, human T cells broadly respond to mycobacterial lipids that are displayed on the surface of CD1 proteins. Further, recent studies show that CD1-reactive T cell responses occur broadly in humans and use T cell receptors that are similar among patients. Here we propose to determine the mechanisms of lipid recognition by T cells during tuberculosis infection to identify lipids that can be used for diagnosis and treatment needed to contain the worldwide TB epidemic, which killed more than one million people last year.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have found that maternal folic acid supplementation via intraperitoneal injection rescues cleft palate phenotype in a mouse model. The proposed studies will elucidate the minimum dose and embryonic developmental window for folic acid treatment, as well as the cellular and molecular mechanism of the rescue. Our long-term goal is to build upon these findings and identify therapeutic strategies for early intervention to reduce the incidence of cleft palate.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This research is of high public health relevance because of the sizable population of adolescents with epilepsy at high risk for lifelong impairments in executive functioning (i.e., skills necessary for goal-directed and complex activities, including problem-solving, initiating, monitoring, organization, planning, self-regulation and working memory) and quality of life. We will test Epilepsy Journey, a multicomponent treatment program with web- based modules and telehealth visits, which is designed to equip adolescents (ages 13-17) with epilepsy with problem-solving skills to manage their executive function challenges. This work is relevant to the NIND’s mission to help all people live longer, healthier lives and will ultimately reduce health disparities and improve access to psychosocial care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: We are proposing to create new miniaturized sampling devices that are specifically designed for measurement of drugs at their site of action. The proposed microextraction-based techniques will be used to analyze antibody drugs in the body (and tumors), alleviating the need for blood draws and biopsies. This research will expand our understanding of medicinal drugs and will facilitate the correct determination of therapeutic drug doses – ultimately increasing the safety of medication for all age groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The public health burden of short and long-term hypoxia exposure can be significant, particularly in regions where large populations live at high altitudes. Understanding the genetic basis of acute and chronic hypoxia could lead to the development of new treatments and interventions to improve public health outcomes related to hypoxia exposure. Using birds from the Himalayas that are residing in their “native” altitude and those that will be experimentally exposed to “non-native” altitudes, we will quantify changes in physiological traits and their genomic/transcriptomic signatures, that can directly contribute to the mechanistic understanding of the underlying genetic basis of acute and chronic hypoxia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This Pathway to Independence Award will apply a multi-omics approach, building on the unique design and rich dietary and biomarker data in the Nurses’ Health Studies to comprehensively evaluate the relationship between chronic inflammation and breast cancer risk. The proposed research project will provide novel insight into inflammatory pathways and specific proteins that will serve as the critical first steps for future development of risk biomarkers and therapeutic targets for preventing ER-negative breast cancer. The project also has the potential to inform more effective and precision dietary approaches for the prevention of breast cancer, and particularly aggressive breast tumor subtypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: While mutations of LRRK2 are the most common genetic cause of Parkinson's disease (PD), the unmutated form of LRRK2 also seems to play an important role in the neurodegeneration that characterizes typical non-genetic PD. The toxicity of LRRK2 mutations appears to be related to overactivity of this enzyme, and it is unclear how LRRK2 becomes over-activated in non-genetic PD. This project is designed to determine (i) how unmutated LRRK2 gets activated, (ii) where in the cell this occurs and (iii) how this leads to neurotoxicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES CENTER AT EL PASO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hematopoiesis is the formation of all the cellular components of the blood, and while much is known regarding mechanisms regulating blood cell development, the role of G0/G1 switch gene 2 (G0S2) in normal hematopoiesis remains unknown. Our data suggests that G0S2 is involved in commitment of hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells toward the myeloid lineage. Understanding the role of G0S2 in regulating lipid and energy metabolism during normal hematopoiesis will inform strategies to harness this molecular pathway for treatment of pathologic conditions like metabolic diseases and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Multicenter International Durability and Safety of Sirolimus in LAM (MIDAS) Registry (NCT02432560) has collected longitudinal data across the United States for about five years on approximately 400 patients with lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM), a progressive rare lung disease that occurs primarily in women. The major gaps hindering meaningful progress in LAM include our inability to reliably predict and identify the patients who are at increased risk of disease progression and the lack of a disease-specific patient-reported outcome measure that informs us of items that are most relevant to LAM patients. We seek to empower patients to be at the center of clinical decision making and therapeutic drug discovery in LAM by using the MIDAS data to validate and refine a: 1) risk score calculator that helps predict future risk of lung function decline and response to treatment, and 2) LAM-specific clinical outcome assessment measure that enables the design of patient-centered trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research project is aimed at developing a 3D cardiac tissue model with adult heart like physiological properties, which will significantly advance the fields of human cardiotoxicity screening, disease modeling and new treatment development for patients with cardiovascular diseases. Specifically, this research investigates the effects of vascularization, cardiac extracellular matrix and mechanical stimulation on the maturation of cardiomyocytes derived from induced pluripotent stem cells. The results of this project will lead to a novel engineered cardiac tissue consisting of three major cardiac cell types and vascularized cardiac extracellular matrix with the unique advantages of high cell density and functional maturation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative- Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) is a devastating disease in our society, which currently has no validated treatment paradigm leading to improved clinical function. This project will attempt to validate surrogate objective biomarkers on currently, commercially available MRI sequences, to better understand the natural history of ICH in terms of iron- mediated neurotoxicity from 7-10 days to 6 months. This project has immense translational significance as such surrogate markers are lacking and the results will better inform future trials examining novel treatment paradigms to prove their efficacy in ICH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prenatal metal exposures are consistently linked with altered child growth and development, and placental dysfunction is central to these effects. We propose the first study on the impact of metals on the placenta N6- methyladenosine (m6A) epitranscriptome, the ensuing effects on the placental proteome, and child birth outcomes and growth trajectories. Our focus on the placenta—an extraembryonic tissue that is key to early-life programming—will lead to novel insight into the mechanisms governing the effects of prenatal metal exposure and may uncover new molecular targets and biomarkers for treatment and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Millions of people are already at risk of mortality and other adverse health outcomes due to heat stress. The risks are inequitably distributed, with low-income people facing the greatest risks of illness and death due to cardiovascular disease, respiratory infection, respiratory disease, chronic kidney disease, diabetes, and respiratory infections; heat stress can also result in adverse pregnancy outcomes and poor mental health. Without accurately quantifying personal heat stress and evaluating the relative impact of various risk factors, interventions to equitably reduce heat stress on a population level may be ineffective or inefficient. This study will assess personal heat stress in informal settlements in Dhaka, Bangladesh among individuals without access to air conditioning to characterize heat stress, identify housing types associated with heat stress, and evaluate interventions to reduce heat stress indoors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Advanced age and cigarette smoking (CS) are the top non-genetic risk factors for age-related macular degeneration (AMD). The extent that aging and CS drive mitochondrial dysfunction and variable RPE phenotypes is still unclear, representing significant scientific knowledge gap in the field. This proposal will characterize the cellular and molecular features of disease-causing subtypes in RPE cells, including epithelial mesenchymal transition (EMT), senescence, and cell death, and link those with the severity of mitochondrial dysfunction associated with aging and CS in both animal models and human AMD samples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Fanconi Anemia protein, FANCV/REV7, cooperates in several DNA repair functions including crosslink repair, DSB repair, and telomere maintenance. The D’Andrea laboratory has recently demonstrated that FANCV/REV7 binds to the CHAMP1 complex, a heterochromatic complex consisting of CHAMP1, POGZ, and HP1a. This grant will evaluate the role of this protein complex in DNA repair and its requirement in telomere length maintenance in human tumor cells with the ALT pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  High-throughput sequencing experiments can provide information about gene expression in human pathogens during infection, but existing computational methods for processing the information are insufficient. In this project, computational tools and methods will be developed for analyzing high-throughput sequencing data, and these new methods will be evaluated on data collected from various bacterial organisms. More broadly, the computational infrastructure developed in this project will serve as a resource to biological and medical researchers studying myriad bacteria that are human pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Our overall objective is to unravel T cell development throughout a bat's lifespan, leading to long-term viral suppression via adaptive immunity. Fundamentally, T cells arise from the bone marrow, they then migrate to thymus where they develop into naïve T cells, that circulate in peripheral tissues and blood - where they act as 'sentinels cells’ (e.g., CD4+ helper, CD8+ cytotoxic) that suppress viral infection. However, after 100 years of anatomical study in bats, the role of the thymus in T cell development has not been described, nor has how T cell development occurs in the thymus or other lymphoid organ, which is the fundamental tenet of T cell immunology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clopidogrel is among the most widely prescribed medications to prevent adverse cardiovascular outcomes in patients with acute coronary syndrome and/or undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention. Given the wide variability in platelet aggregation and clinical outcomes in response to clopidogrel therapy, it is critical to identify the metabolic and genetic factors that cause altered drug efficacy and to better predict those who are more susceptible to altered clopidogrel response. The proposed research will provide insights into the cause(s) of clopidogrel failure and will ultimately help physicians prescribe the most effective antiplatelet therapy based on metabolic and genetic background.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative  This project documents the role of medicine and physicians in barring disabled people from many legal, political, and social rights, such as marriage and voting, in the decades after our nation’s founding. Health professionals, public health officials, and historians of medicine must recognize medicine’s historical role in supporting and defending structural ableism. Such an awareness provides crucial context for present-day work for greater access and equality in medicine and American society more broadly.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Vision impairment and blindness due to optic nerve injury from trauma, optic nerve stroke, and glaucoma are serious clinical problems that have dramatic consequences on the Veteran’s quality of life. Ocular injuries and disease characterized by the degeneration of retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) and optic nerve atrophy result in the reduction or loss of vision. This Merit Review will test the hypothesis that limiting a calcium-permeable (CP)- AMPA glutamate receptor mediated increase of intracellular Ca2 following optic nerve injury or during early elevated ocular hypertension maintains or restores RGC function and structure. Studies will utilize pharmacological and genetic approaches that suppress CP-AMPAR activity to assess RGC dendritic structure, synaptic receptors, light responsiveness, long-term cell survival and visuomotor behavior. Foundational findings will set the stage for the development of novel therapeutic strategies and interventions targeted to reduce retinal cell and axon degeneration. These studies are consistent with the health-related goals of the VA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fear of cancer recurrence (FCR) is alarmingly high among patients with primary malignant brain tumors and their caregivers, yet psychological interventions targeting FCR have historically excluded both populations from investigation. This project aims to assess the feasibility and acceptability of recruitment strategies, target population, and appropriateness of a waitlist-control group for the delivery and evaluation of FearLess, a newly- developed, evidenced-informed, mindfulness-based, cognitive-existential, telehealth psychological intervention specifically designed to target FCR in neuro-oncology. This study builds upon our previous work, and results are vital to resolve information gaps regarding recruitment methodology, study population suitability, and control group feasibility prior to FearLess protocol finalization and large-scale intervention trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Osteoporosis is an age-related disease characterized by low bone mass and leads to a compromised musculoskeletal structure and increased risk of fracture. Mechanical loading, in the form of exercise interventions, are known to result in enhanced bone formation. This project, using a diverse interdisciplinary team of researchers, investigates the role of mechanical strain and fluid shear stress on the osteocyte/dendrite membranes in activation of bone formation biological pathways and the changes associated with aging in both males and females.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative This project is aimed at developing new approaches to MRI through advances in the use of field cycling, novel spatial encoding strategies, and spin editing methods. The aim is to further a class of open MRI devices that can be made in any shape or size. These developments will pave the way for small footprint, low-cost scanners, making MRI much more accessible for screening and treatment monitoring, especially of common, chronic, and potentially progressive diseases for which MRI is currently underutilized.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Diabetic retinopathy (DR) is a retinal disease that is a leading cause of severe vision loss worldwide. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This qualitative study will interview adolescents aged 14 to 17 years to ask about their perspectives on the benefits of, challenges with, and suggestions for improving telehealth such as video and telephone consultations. Understanding the perspectives of adolescents can help improve communication with healthcare providers during remote visits and ultimately youth’s health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will develop and establish the content validity, and preliminary convergent validity and test-retest reliability of the Palliative Care Readiness (PALCARE) tool in determining readiness for early palliative care (PC) among older adults with cancer. The resulting tool will allow the primary oncology team to assess readiness for early PC in this population, help provide targeted PC in the domains where they feel ready, and help in the development and implementation of interventions aimed at improving readiness in PC domains where they do not yet feel ready. Ultimately this project will improve early PC utilization among older adults with cancer and improve their quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative All life forms require their genetic material to be organized and packaged into cells, but this genetic sequestration often silences gene expression. Here, the mechanism that relieves the silencing of virulence genes in the bacterial pathogen Shigella, will be studied by undergraduates and graduate students at the University of Nevada Las Vegas. The primary focus of these studies will be a newly identified ligand of the key anti-silencing protein, VirB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The etiology of inflammatory bowel disease is largely unknown. In an unbiased forward genetic screen for mouse mutants susceptible to experimental colitis, we found that the Golgi protein TVP23B is critical for regulating goblet and Paneth cell function in the intestine via glycosylation. Our work is focused on understanding the function of TVP23B in regulating intestinal immune homeostasis.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Drug overdose is the leading cause of accidental death in the United States. While opioid overdoses comprise most overdose deaths, stimulant overdose deaths are rising. This project examines an important but missed opportunity—non-fatal overdose—to improve Veterans’ health care and health outcomes. To improve post- overdose care, the Veterans Health Administration developed a national clinical note template—the Suicide Behavior and Overdose Report (SBOR)—which is currently recommended for unintentional overdoses (majority of overdoses) but will soon be mandated. However, the SBOR is currently optimized to address opioid, not stimulant, overdose. Also, despite the promise of the SBOR to improve post-overdose care, unknown is the extent to which clinicians are using it and whether its use improves post-overdose care as intended. This project will fill a great need to understand how to improve the SBOR and, ultimately, post- overdose treatment for Veterans who have non-fatal overdoses and remain at high risk for poor outcomes.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: NARRATIVE Heart dysfunction is now the leading cause of death in patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). The central objectives of this proposal are to combine genetic differences with blood and imaging markers to help predict development of significant heart dysfunction and scar. These aims have the potential to decrease the size and cost of therapeutic clinical trials for DMD heart disease, speeding up the adoption of new therapies and improving quality of life in boys and men with DMD.

PROJECT_TITLE: Prospective Development of a Multimodal Biomaker Platform for Predictive Risk Stratification of Cardiac Disease in Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Knee osteoarthritis (OA) is a leading cause of premature disability and a substantial public health burden that is disproportionately borne by Veterans. There are no drugs to halt or reverse advanced OA. Thus, treatment of earlier OA is needed. The Targeting Osteoarthritis Pain and Progression (TOPP) Collaborative Merit Review aims to establish necessary preclinical and clinical information to improve understanding of how OA develops and to identify new treatments for different types and stages of OA. The degenerative meniscus tear (DMT) might be an early sign of knee OA. This means some DMT patients may already have biological knee OA even though their Xrays don’t yet show OA. This particular research project will examine if certain proteins in joint fluid, blood and urine predict whether pain and OA become better or worse after arthroscopic partial meniscectomy (APM). It will also contribute critical information and biospecimens for use in the TOPP collaboration so better treatments can be developed to help Veterans and others with knee OA.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Hypercapnia, or elevation of the level of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the body, commonly develops in patients with advanced lung diseases, and is associated with frequent lung infections and an increased risk of death. This project will determine how hypercapnia leads to more and severe infections with influenza virus, one of the most common reasons for patients with chronic lung disease to become seriously ill or die. The findings from this research will lay the basis for future studies aimed at preventing the deleterious effects of hypercapnia on the immune system.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is an important priority for the Veterans Administration, but treatments to date utilizing medications and / or psychotherapy have had limitations. Electrical treatments represent a new horizon in the treatment of PTSD and psychiatric disorders in general, and new non-invasive treatments avoid the high cost, and lack of reimbursement by insurance companies that limited wide-spread implementation of implanted stimulation devices. This project will look at a novel new possible treatment for PTSD that could represent a paradigm shift in this disorder called non-invasive transcutaneous cervical (neck) Vagal Nerve Stimulation (tcVNS) and how it affects brain and physiological responses to stress in veterans with PTSD as well as effects of long term treatment on PTSD symptoms.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Diseases affecting the filters of the kidney (podocytes and glomeruli), such as diabetes, are the leading cause of end stage kidney disease (ESKD). Eleven percent of Veterans meet the criteria for chronic kidney disease (CKD), which leads to ESKD and premature death from cardiovascular disease. As a kidney doctor at the VA and in the South Carolina Army National Guard, I frequently see patients with CKD, and it is difficult to tell them there are very few specific therapies to treat CKD. A safe, approved, and efficacious drug would be a major advance. The goal here is to validate a novel therapeutic target, the beta 2 adrenergic receptor (β2-AR), activation of which we showed accelerates recovery of kidney function following injury, including in a diabetic mouse model. Formoterol, which activates the β2-AR, is an approved drug with an excellent safety profile used to treat chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). This application investigates, using mouse models and a retrospective cohort study of Veterans, the utility of repurposing β2-AR activators such as formoterol for the treatment of CKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative While goal-directed behaviors are essential for animal survival and dramatically disrupted in neuropsychiatric disease, the cellular mechanisms supporting these processes remain unclear. The striatum is a key node in mediating goal-directed function via complex interactions between spiny projection neurons and local circuit inhibitory neurons. This proposal employs viral-genetic, physiological, electrochemical, 2-photon imaging and behavioral methods to explore how a specific subtype of striatal interneuron – the low-threshold-spiking cell – modulates goal-directed striatal output.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Spinal cord injury and disorders (SCI/D) are a substantial health concern impacting about 273,000 Americans and 45,000 veterans. Restoring lost function is the goal of regenerative and rehabilitative therapeutic approaches for SCI/D. The VA Gordon Mansfield Spinal Cord Injury Consortium (VA-GMSCIC) is an effort to develop late-stage translational therapeutics in a nonhuman primate (NHP) model in preparation for clinical testing of emerging therapies. Prior and current funding has focused on multifaceted data collection, with multiple centers collaboratively collecting data on the same subject, each with specific domain of expertise. The current VA Merit Award built a Federated Data Commons to optimize decision-support, and knowledge- discovery across all data from VA-GMSCIC rehabilitation and regeneration studies. The renewal will integrate translational Electronic Health Records (tEHR), robotic rehabilitation, neuromodulation and machine intelligence tools to support advanced safety/efficacy studies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: A majority of trauma-exposed Veterans continue to experience PTSD symptoms after evidence-based treatment (EBT). Anhedonia, i.e., reduced positive affect and reward responsiveness, is common in trauma- exposed Veterans, and impaired reward responsiveness has been implicated as a risk factor for developing PTSD and poor treatment response. The proposed research will use computational modeling and functional neuroimaging to identify individual markers of reward function and test the usefulness of such markers in predicting successful reduction of PTSD symptoms following EBT. By using a detailed mechanistic framework of reward processing, this research will help improve our understanding of PTSD complex clinical profile and to develop predictive tools to determine which trauma-exposed Veterans are at risk of poor EBT response. Results from this research may also help identify specific reward processing targets to develop adjunctive treatments to improve the effectiveness of psychological care for Veterans exposed to trauma.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative To address the dual needs of parents for support in navigating Autism Syndrome Disorder (ASD) services and maintaining positive family functioning, we propose to test Autism Parent Navigators (APN), an innovative in-home, peer support model for parents with a young child recently diagnosed with ASD. Extensive pilot work over the past 3 years has generated evidence of feasibility, acceptability, and impact. We will assess the efficacy of APN in a randomized trial with 180 families; test the mediating pathways through which APN impacts outcomes; and assess whether baseline parent characteristics, child characteristics, or program processes moderate outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposures to toxic metals and psychological and social stressors in early life are uniquely and jointly associated with poorer child cognitive and socioemotional development. This study recognizes that physical, social, and psychological risk factors tend to cluster; thus, we propose to examine how profiles of prenatal exposures to concurrent toxic metals and psychological and social stressors are associated with child developmental outcomes. By then rigorously examining the moderating effects of caregiving experience, this study has the potential to identify strategies to mitigate the effects of early risk factors experienced across the physical and social environments on child development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major barrier to the development of effective treatment options for multiple sclerosis include is the limited specificity of clinical imaging markers for axonal damage, one of the key contributors to disability progression. This project will evaluate the relative influence of demyelination and axonal damage in the development of permanent disability in MS by providing a validated noninvasive MR imaging marker of axonal damage using strong imaging gradients. The tool will be validated through longitudinal and imaging-histopathologic studies and form the basis for identifying clinically relevant imaging outcomes in assessing response to reparative and neuroprotective therapies in MS.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project(Narrative( HIV-uninfected individuals born to mothers with HIV are known to exhibit adverse health outcomes in early life, yet the long-term clinical consequences for this population – exceeding 18 million people worldwide – are largely unknown. This project will delineate metabolic and immune sequelae of in utero HIV exposure among HIV-uninfected young adults, and identify mechanisms that may contribute to these outcomes. Only by characterizing lifelong disease risk among HIV-exposed but uninfected individuals can we optimize screening, prevention, and treatment strategies for this group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infrequent or never testing for HIV has been associated with high rates of infection in Black sexual and gender minority youth (SGMY) indicating a public health imperative to increase routine HIV testing. Social media influencers have been successfully used in consumer marketing; however, they have not been leveraged for HIV prevention efforts despite their potential as a scalable and cost-effective approach for public health intervention. This project will identify and train Black SGMY Instagram influencers, for the first time, to develop and deliver theoretically-grounded persuasive Instagram messages to promote routine HIV testing to their social media networks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative For the tens of millions of individuals living with human immunodeficiency virus 1 (HIV-1), antiretroviral therapies are life-saving medicines that prevent the onset of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). Our lab previously reported compounds with anti-HIV-1 activity that belong to a unique class of antiretrovirals not currently used in clinical practice. Here, I aim to determine how these compounds modify the assembled structures of the HIV-1 virion and to establish the biochemical parameters of compound binding to lay the groundwork for the next generation of HIV-1 therapeutics in order to help outpace antiviral drug resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  In order to efficiently control energy homeostasis, the brain makes predictions about future caloric needs and food availability in order to invigorate food-seeking behavior. It is know that dopamine neurons encode reward prediction error signals that reinforce learning and guide the development of reward-seeking behavior. This proposal aims to investigate the role of dopamine in lateral hypothalamic area and test the hypothesis that LHA receives prediction error signals from the ventral tegmental area-revealing a novel feeding neural circuit and defining a new role for dopamine in feeding behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Nausea is an unpleasant sensation of visceral malaise that has remained poorly understood at a molecular and cellular level. The area postrema is a tiny brain structure that mediates certain nausea responses, and this project will use genetic approaches to explore the functional organization of the area postrema- from how visceral stimuli are detected and encoded to the roles of different cell types and receptors in nausea-associated behaviors. Understanding sensory mechanisms underlying the sensation of nausea may provide new and needed strategies for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Binge alcohol consumption poses a major public health burden in the U.S., leading to increased rates of mortality and other pathophysiologies, such as anxiety and depression. The proposed work will examine how repeated cycles of binge-like alcohol drinking dysregulate serotonin signaling in a discrete neural circuit, which may drive future binge alcohol intake and contribute to negative health outcomes. This may lead to the identification of more effective therapeutic strategies for the treatment of alcohol use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Synthetic tailoring of polypharmacological drugs is often difficult, as the most appropriate targets may not be readily apparent and therefore few roadmaps exist to guide chemistry. In this application we propose a multidisciplinary approach for accessing novel target and chemical space so as to derive highly precise polypharmacological compounds. By combining chemical and genetic modifier screens, with computational modelling, we will identify distinct kinases that can strongly enhance (‘pro-targets’) or limit (‘anti-targets’) the activity of kinase inhibitors within models of KRAS variant metastatic colorectal cancer, and then harness this information to predict and synthesize novel compounds optimized towards whole animal networks.

PHR: Project Narrative: Molecular Mechanisms of Adjuvant Triplet Combinations The next frontier in adjuvant combination research is to identify and characterize higher-order combinations of adjuvants which can mimic the effects of the most potent live attenuated vaccines and be used in new vaccine formulations against infection. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This application proposes to identify a novel regulatory mechanism by which overexpression of oncoprotein LSD1 facilitates triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) progression. This project is also aimed at utilizing novel LSD1-targeting agents to enhance tumor suppression, augment antitumor immunity, and overcome therapeutic resistance in TNBC. The results from the proposed studies are expected to provide novel mechanistic insight and rationale for effective combination of leading LSD1 inhibitors with standard or immune therapies as new treatment strategies for patients with advanced TNBC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Poly(ADP-ribose) Polymerase 1 (PARP-1) has important roles in DNA damage repair, regulation of gene expression, and cell death signaling. Inhibitors of PARP-1 have emerged as promising therapeutic agents for the treatment of cancer and inflammation. The studies in this proposal will progress our mechanistic understanding of PARP-1 activation and regulation, improve current models of PARP-1 biological functions, advance our understanding of PARP inhibitor mechanism of action, and develop improved PARP inhibitors with potential strong relevance to the cancer clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Complete and timely colonoscopy after an abnormal stool-based colorectal cancer screening test results in early detection, cancer prevention, and reduction in mortality, but follow-up in safety-net health systems occurs in less than 50% at 6 months. The proposal will implement multi-level approach consisting of a stepped-wedge clinic- level intervention of team-based best practices co-developed with primary and specialty care, a patient-level technology intervention to provide enhanced instructions and navigation to complete diagnostic colonoscopy, and a mixed methods evaluation to explore multi-level factors contributing to intervention outcomes. Developing a solution to this high-risk and diverse population has the potential to translate to other health systems, support patient self-management, and address other patient conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Many characters of interest in biomedicine evolved long ago and are fixed in a particular species, distinguishing it from unaffected relatives; finding the genes underlying any such ancient trait has been a central challenge in the field. We have developed a method, RH-seq, for genetic dissection of interspecies trait variation, and applied it in invertebrate models. We now propose to study how species-defining alleles confer their effects, alone and together, in a yeast model system, and we propose to port our approaches for interspecies genetics to mouse cells, with a focus on cellular senescence.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JOHN D DINGELL VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: It is estimated that spinal cord injury (SCI) affects approximately 12,000 new individuals every year in the United States, with the majority are cervical and/or upper thoracic injuries. Despite this high prevalence of respiratory and sleep disorders in the chronic SCI population minority of patients are treated and are adherent to standard mechanical therapies. This proposal addresses a new therapeutic intervention in SCI. We hypothesized that daily acute intermittent hypercapnia (dAIHc) is feasible, improves respiratory symptoms, and alleviates sleep apnea in patients with chronic SCI. We will perform a pilot feasibility study to examine the impact of dAIHC for two weeks durations among Veterans with SCI. We believe that this novel approach to treating OSA will yield significant new knowledge that improves the health and quality of life of these patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Knee osteoarthritis (OA) is a growing problem among active duty military and Veterans. Knee OA clinics are experiencing steady increases in patients throughout the VA. Few interventions are available which include weight management, knee braces, pain medications and/or surgery. However, these efforts to mitigate knee OA are often ineffective. Development of exoskeletons may offer a potential solution for Veterans with knee OA to reduce pain while walking and performing mobility-related activities of daily living (ADLs) with the potential to reduce pain medication intake and delay/reduce the need for knee replacement surgery. If successful, this project will provide Veterans with knee OA a useful alternative to standard braces and other non-surgical treatments. Reduction in knee pain with improved walking velocity and performance of ADLs would help to improve daily physical activity levels for Veterans with knee OA. New protocols for testing exoskeleton technologies for ambulation and ADLs and knee OA-specific guidelines for clinicians and users will be delivered.

PHR: Narrative: The computational methodologies we develop will be applicable to a broad set of metalloen- zymes and proteins of biomedical relevance. In particular, we target fundamental mechanistic problems in enzymes that catalyze nucleic acids synthesis/modiﬁcation and lipid metabolism, since mutations in these en- zymes are implicated in numerous human diseases such as cancer, insulin resistance and diabetes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Stethoscopes are valuable tools for clinical diagnosis of respiratory infections; though, they remain limited by a number of issues including subjectivity, inter-listener variability, need for advanced medical expertise as well as vulnerability to ambient noise that can mask lung sounds of interest. The current project develops technology employing novel sensing materials augmented with artificial intelligence analytics to provide unique surround sound access to adventitious sounds from the lungs.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Antimicrobial use is the strongest risk factor for the emergence of antimicrobial resistance, and nearly half of Veterans are prescribed an antimicrobial while hospitalized. Antimicrobial stewardship programs (ASPs) can minimize unnecessary antimicrobial use and are thus an essential tool for addressing the crisis of antimicrobial resistance. The VHA has mandated that every hospital have an ASP, but ASPs lack a globally accepted metric to assess their effectiveness. A metric developed by the CDC, known as the Standardized Antimicrobial Administration Ratio (SAAR), is being widely used both in and outside VHA, but it is not known whether the SAAR is valid. This proposal will evaluate the validity of the SAAR and three new metrics our team has created. The goal is to develop accurate and reliable metrics that can be used to evaluate ASP success and, in turn, improve antimicrobial prescribing for Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Smoking rates remain disproportionally high in Chinese immigrants particularly among males, despite the availability of evidence-based smoking cessation treatment services targeting Chinese Americans. WeChat, the most popular social media platform among Chinese globally, is fully integrated into the daily lives of Chinese and thereby can be a powerful tool to disseminate health messages and promote healthy behavior changes. This K01 project will explore the use of WeChat to deliver a culturally adapted cessation intervention and will provide important feasibility and initial efficacy data to inform future larger trials that use social media approach for smoking cessation treatment among disadvantaged populations including Chinese immigrants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed trial, Latinos Understanding the Need for Adherence in Diabetes using Care Coordination, Integrated Medical and Behavioral Care and E Health (“LUNA-E”), will address health disparities in diabetes care and outcomes for primarily Spanish-speaking, Mexican-born US Hispanics/Latinos receiving care for type 2 diabetes mellitus at San Ysidro Health (SYH), a federally qualified community health center (FQHC) near the US-Mexico border. The study will help advance our understanding of optimal approaches to diabetes healthcare services in a large, growing, US population at high risk for diabetes and related complications. If shown effective, LUNA-E has high potential for broad scaling and dissemination due to its community partnered approach, use of technology, and implementation within a large, exemplar FQHC environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The establishment of highly precise neuronal connectivity during development is required for the proper functioning of the nervous system. For example, genetic disruptions affecting the development of the olfactory system in Kallmann or in CHARGE Syndromes, profoundly and permanently disrupt olfactory function. Our goal in this project is to develop and use new technology that will allow us to characterize the cells that growing olfactory sensory neurons interact with as they navigate to their targets in the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It has historically been very hard to perform measurements and experiments on the adult cochlea, as it is a structure of extreme mechanical sensitivity and delicacy, contains relatively small numbers of cells, and is encased in the strongest bone in the body. This proposal seeks to overcome these limitations by using a new technique, MERFISH to directly measure the expression of genes in the different cell types of the cochlea. This technique may shed light on how the cochlea is able to respond to different sound frequencies, and how different regions of the cochlea respond to injury and age-related degeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite progress in our understanding of the altered signaling pathways triggered by NF1 mutations in bone-forming cells, recalcitrant bone healing in children with Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) remains a challenging orthopedic condition for which no targeted treatment exists. In this proposal, we will investigate the feasibility of selectively clearing the abnormal NF1- mutated bone cells, based on their putative sensitivity to senolytics, to promote bone union and improve the musculoskeletal deficiencies associated with NF1.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health because it focuses on elucidating the role of a novel uptake transporter in mediating cellular accumulation of a cisplatin metabolite, which will enlighten how this metabolite promotes hearing loss. Once such knowledge is clarified, there is the potential significance to reduce cisplatin- induced ototoxicity by targeting transporters that regulate this process. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to part of the NIDCD mission that pertains to prevention of hearing loss and communication disorders.

PHR: Project Narrative  Hypertensive and ischemic heart diseases represent two major risk factors of heart failure. Pathological cardiac remodeling under these disease conditions involves adverse alterations at various levels. Studies laid out here will dissect the contribution of de novo pyrimidine biosynthesis in the heart in pathological cardiac remodeling and heart failure, which will provide new insights of our understanding for the underlying pathophysiology and shed light on novel therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Public Health Relevance. This project is relevant to public health because it will describe an important new mechanism of skull and bone formation involving activation of skeletal progenitor cells by the extracellular matrix niche via 2 collagen receptors, discoidin domain receptor 2 and β1 integrins; this niche is altered in many disease states including osteoporosis and diabetes. By describing a new pathway for bone formation, this project will provide possible routes for enhancing skeletal regeneration and repair. Thus, this project in relevant to the NICDR’s mission of supporting basic research to improve craniofacial health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Considering that there are 100 cases of maternal morbidity for every maternal death in the US, addressing the rising rates and racial/ethnic disparities in maternal morbidity across the peripartum period has critical implications for improving the short- and long-term health of women of color. Achieving the dual goals of this study, to build the evidence base on neighborhood context as a determinant of racial/ethnic disparities in peripartum maternal morbidity and contextualize that evidence within the complex system of interrelationships with other multilevel determinants of these outcomes, will support the development of innovative interventions to eliminate racial/ethnic disparities in peripartum morbidity. This has significant implications for both improving the long-term health of women of color and reducing rates of maternal mortality in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic heart failure is a chronic and progressive condition that currently affects over 6 million patients in the US and poses a major public health burden. Symptoms of the disease are due, in large part, to elevated left atrial pressure, which results from failure of the heart to adequately eject blood from its main pumping chamber (left ventricle). We propose a novel, non-implant medical procedure to relieve left atrial pressure through use of a simple, low-risk, minimally invasive catheter to thereby reduce the symptoms and morbidity associated with heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Bisphenol A (BPA) is an organic molecule ubiquitous in plastic-containing consumer products that has been repeatedly linked to a wide array of adverse health effects, including infertility. Recent evidence suggests that the analogs currently used to replace BPA pose similar health risks. This collaborative research project aims to identify BPA analogs that pose low or no risk to human reproductive health through the synthesis of novel bisphenols and the evaluation of their reproductive toxicity in the search for safer plastics.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pain and the addictive effects of opioids used to control pain are critical national health problems affecting millions of Americans. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Type 1 diabetes results from the loss of pancreatic beta cells due to an autoimmune destruction. Stopping the autoimmune response and preventing the beta cell loss is attractive for the development of therapies, but the bottleneck of this approach is the lack of validated biomarkers that can predict the autoimmunity onset and type 1 diabetes development. Here, we propose to systematically validate biomarker candidates and determine their relationship with disease development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE/NARRATIVE For millions of Americans each year, a traumatic stress exposure (TSE) such as motor vehicle collision, sexual assault, or physical assault triggers two highly morbid overlapping developmental processes: the transition from acute to chronic pain and the transition from short-term to long-term opioid use/misuse. Current pain medications for individuals at high risk of chronic pain and opioid use in the early aftermath of TSE either do not decrease the risk of such transition or actually increase the risk. We will conduct the next critical steps in evaluating a highly promising new potential treatment target to decrease the transition from acute to chronic pain and the transition from short-term to long term opioid use/misuse, FK506-binding protein 51 (FKBP51).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: A significant way to reduce the overall burden of Alzheimer’s disease is to identify modifiable risk factors, which could be avoided or treated, that would slow or prevent the onset of Alzheimer’s disease. Traumatic brain injury is a well-established environmental risk factor for the development of Alzheimer’s disease. Completion of these studies will uncover the largely unexplored therapeutic approach of Beta hydroxybutyrate for individuals exposed to a traumatic brain injury to reduce the risk of developing a neurodegenerative disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Flortaucipir PET is widely utilized as a biomarker of Alzheimer’s disease. However, there are many observations regarding flortaucipir PET that is unexplained, such as its uptake in other diseases, for example frontotemporal lobar degeneration. In this grant we will study flortaucipir PET behavior in a large autopsied cohort of Alzheimer’s disease and frontotemporal lobar degeneration brains to better understand its biology.

PHR: Project Narrative  Our main goals are to understand the molecular mechanisms by which neurons activate pathways that induce axon degeneration during development and in neurodegenerative disease. Axon pruning is physiologically important as it allows for the removal of excessive or misguided axon branches and permits the establishment of new neuronal connections. The results from this study will help identify key mechanisms by which axon degeneration can be controlled for potential therapeutic benefit for Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inclusions of the TAR DNA binding protein of 43 kDa (TDP-43) are present in over 60% of cases with Alzheimer's disease (AD), although their contribution to mechanism/s underlying neurodegeneration in AD are lacking. TDP-43 is an RNA-binding protein known to regulate many facets of RNA metabolism; thus, TDP-43- associated toxicity in AD may result from the accumulation of key aberrant transcripts, such as the recently discovered truncated stathmin-2 (tSTMN2) transcript, as a result of TDP-43 mislocalization to the cytoplasm, abnormal post-translational modifications and/or TDP-43 sequestration into inclusions. Thus, in an effort to transform the AD field and improve our understanding of TDP-43-associated disease mechanism driving AD, our goals are to: 1) determine the pathological relationships between TDP-43 and tSTMN2 in AD, 2) evaluate whether tSTMN2 is associated with cross-sectional and longitudinal clinical and neuroimaging measures of neurodegeneration in AD, and 3) identify transcriptome changes in TDP-43-affected neurons that are unique to AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Intracranial electrical stimulation of the brain is a central method in the neurosurgery clinic, approved or in trials for treatment of Parkinson's disease, obsessive compulsive disorder, epilepsy, and others. However, the basic mechanism of action of intracranial stimulation remains unclear. This work uses recent advances in electrophysiology (Neuropixels) and optogenetic tools to study the local and brain-wide effects of electrical stimulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE High-resolution imaging techniques are essential for investigation of the pathogenesis and development of therapeutic and screening strategies for cerebral small vessel disease (SVD), including Alzheimer Disease (AD) and AD-related dementias. We propose to develop novel methods to investigate retinal O2 delivery and consumption with unprecedented spatial resolution and to correlate changes that occur in parallel in retinal and cortical microvasculature during normal ageing and AD. We hope that this work will advance our understanding of the concurrent microvascular dysfunction in cortex and retina during both normal ageing and SVD progression, provide broad utility in assessing retinal microvascular domains in animal models of eye disorders, and augment knowledge of vascular mechanisms of progressive neurodegeneration and cognitive impairment in common forms of SVD as well as in AD and related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An athletic career filled with head impacts predisposes athletes to memory impairments and is a risk factor for dementias including Alzheimer’s disease. To understand the nature of the chronic memory impairments caused by HI, we are focused on the physiological changes that occur in the brain after exposure to a high frequency of non-damaging HI, and comparing our results to a single severe single TBI. In this proposal we will test the hypothesis that repeated head impacts disrupts synaptic transmission within the memory circuits of the hippocampus, and that activation of engram neurons can override these cognitive deficits and reanimate a forgotten memory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) are two incurable neurodegenerative diseases that are characterized by the presence of protein aggregates formed through aberrant phase transition of RNA-binding proteins (RBPs). Agents able to reverse aberrant phase transition and aggregation of RBPs could mitigate their toxicity and have the potential to be developed as therapeutic strategies to combat FTD/ALS. This project focuses on developing RNA oligonucleotide disaggregases to prevent and reverse aberrant RBP phase transition, and elucidating the mechanism of action of these RNA oligonucleotides.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Relevance of the research to public health; no more than 2-3 sentences of text. This research investigates how the timing of different neurons is regulated and contributes to computing visual motion. Since timing is essential to all visual processing, we must understand how it is regulated if we are to understand and treat visual impairments and blindness. Timing is also essential to neural processing beyond vision, so advancing our understanding of timing in neural circuits will help us to understand and treat disruptions in function brought on by disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative We will do experiments to provide fundamental insights into how specific signatures of brain circuit activity relate to circuit computations. We will record and manipulate the activity of populations of brain cells in behaving subjects to measure the relationship between these signatures and specific circuit functions in the part of the cerebral cortex that serves vision. Better understanding of the details of how brain circuits compute will improve the assessment, diagnosis and treatment of a wide range of brain disorders.
