IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This project uses advanced electrophysiological neural ensemble recording to test circuit-level hypotheses about the fundamental interactions between the hippocampal formation and the neocortex that enables episodic memories to be captured quickly and subsequently consolidated into efficient schemas for adaptive behavior. The overarching hypothesis is that the laminar structure of neocortex is optimized to subserve a particular type of information representation, in which the global context of experiences is encoded in sparse activity patterns in Layer II-III that are derived from the output of the hippocampal formation and that associatively link together the attributes (i.e., content) of experience, which are represented more densely in the deeper layers (Layer V). Overall, these experiments will shed new light on the cortex-wide, circuit-level details of how memory works, leading ultimately to improved interventions in cases of memory impairment due to trauma, disease and the aging process and other cognitive deficits such as schizophrenia and autism spectrum disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Analysis of the structure and function of neuronal circuits across multiple individuals is crucial for understanding brain function across healthy individuals and in disease. We propose applying our functional connectomics approach to understand the relationship between neuronal connectivity and function in the context of perceptually-guided behaviors using the genetic model organism Drosophila. By studying how a tractable model nervous system controls visually and olfactory-guided behaviors across multiple individuals and between sexes, our research will provide insight into the fundamental principles of sensorimotor processing and individuality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: The ability to perform different movements in the appropriate order is essential for purposeful behavior and survival, and defects in the brain regions that underlie movement selection can lead to neurological disorders that exhibit abnormally repetitive movements (e.g. autism spectrum disorder). Yet, how neural circuits assemble sequences of movements is poorly understood. In this project, we use innovative neurogenetic methods to provide a highly detailed circuit-level view of a behavioral sequence to better understand how interactions between neurons produce sequenced movements in animals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Nearly every normal behavioral process and disorder of the nervous system is thought to involve the coordinated activity of large groups of neurons. The relationship between neurons and behavior is profoundly nonlinear, so new, nonlinear methods will be required to predict behavior from the activity of neural populations. This ability would revolutionize the way neuropsychiatric disorders are diagnosed and treated because it would be invertible, allowing clinicians to use behavioral methods to diagnose differences in neuronal population activity.

PHR: Narrative Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease, which shares attributes with Alzheimer's Disease; tau protein aggregates, cognitive and motor deficits. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and other neurodegenerative conditions are characterized by heightened inflammation, neurodegeneration, and CNS vascular permeability, including microhemorrhage formation. In this proposal, we employ novel transgenic mice that enable critical dissection of CD8 T cell recognition of antigen during priming and effector states in the CNS. We will test our central hypothesis that clonally expanded CD8 T cells engage brain vasculature and migratory antigen presenting cells during infiltration which contributes to neuropathology and cognitive deficits in AD and Tauopathies.

PHR: The red blood cell plays an important role in oxygen delivery and blood flow to the brain. We are studying whether dysfunction of the red blood cell leads to dementia and cognitive problems. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS THE STATE UNIV OF NJ NEWARK
PHR: Narrative Transcranial current stimulation is increasingly being used to alleviate the symptoms of depression, reduce epileptic seizures, and even to increase learning and cognition in healthy volunteers. However, little is known about the nature of the neural changes induced by transcranial currents. This project seeks to guide the refinement of transcranial current stimulation methods by determining how weak currents affect neural activity in mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Exposure to repetitive head impacts (RHI) from contact sports has been associated with later life cognitive impairment, dementia, and neuropsychiatric disturbances including neurobehavioral dysregulation and depression. The etiology of these heterogeneous and non-specific symptoms is unclear and likely multifactorial. The proposed study will conduct sophisticated in vivo and ex vivo evaluations of white matter integrity and cerebrovascular disease to determine the vascular contributions to cognitive impairment, dementia and neuropsychiatric syndromes in diverse and well-characterized cohorts of contact sport athletes from two major research centers and a U54 collaborative brain bank initiative.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health as its goal is to develop new ways to use electrical deep brain stimulation for the precise control of tonic (slow) and phasic (fast) dopamine release in the brain. Disrupted tonic and phasic dopamine release underlies addiction, depression, Parkinson's disease, and schizophrenia, and improved control would therefore be relevant to translational research as new stimulation technologies could potentially treat these conditions. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH's mission to develop fundamental knowledge that can be applied to reduce human disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Tauopathies such as Alzheimer’s Disease lead to brain cell dysfunction and degeneration and are a significant health concern today. We do not understand why some brain cell types are particularly affected while others are not. We will use human induced pluripotent stem cell derived neurons from patients suffering from early onset tauopathy to comprehensively study this question at cellular and molecular levels. Our goal is to identify ways in which brain cells are protected from disease as a key step towards developing cell-protective therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative Extracellular vesicles (EVs) carry Aβ and tau that may spread pathogenic proteins across the brain. The role of EVs in Alzheimer's disease is currently a major mystery of the disease mechanism and advancing mechanistic dissection of EV biology has been thwarted by a lack of tractable experimental animal systems. This research uses the powerful model system C. elegans to study the fundamental biology of neuronal EVs in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The abnormal accumulation of amyloid peptides (Aβ) are linked to cause Alzheimer's cognitive dysfunction. Inhibition of BACE1, a critical enzyme for the generation of Aβ, may prevent and reduce Aβ generation to avoid excessive amyloid deposition. This study aims to test how BACE1 inhibition will be more effective in treating Alzheimer's patients. We aim to develop approaches that will enhance synaptic strength in addition to reduce Aβ generation. The obtained results will provide timely guidance for the safe and effective use of BACE1 inhibitors in human.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As sensory input changes through time, the sense of smell must track and represent these changes using a form of short-term memory. We will investigate how the mouse processes time-varying odor stimuli, and how neural circuits transform inputs into useful patterns of activity. Gaining insight may lead to better strategies for sensory prostheses and treating sensory deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stroke, the leading cause of long-term adult disability, has no FDA-approved therapeutic treatments to boost long-term recovery in part because we do not understand long-term mechanisms that influence recovery. This research proposes to identify mechanisms of neurotrophin support by B cells, an immune cell subset that moves into uninjured areas of the post-stroke brain to support recovery. These studies will be critical in understanding how the immune system supports neuronal plasticity to improve long-term motor and cognitive recovery after stroke, with critical consideration of age and sex in the response of B cells to stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Tauopathies affect more than 6 million people in the US and include Alzheimer’s disease, progressive supranuclear palsy, and frontotemporal dementia. Tauopathies are the result of multifactorial processes that cause diverse changes in molecular networks linking a host of biological processes that lead to tau aggregates in the brain. This study will use stem cell, transcriptomic, and proteomic approaches to reveal novel mechanisms that drive tauopathy and can be targeted therapeutically.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Our goal is to understand the genetic basis and neural circuits that govern social and collective behaviors in animals and to that end we picked schooling and shoaling in zebrafish as an example, because the larval form of the zebrafish is a very tractable model system in neuroscience, which means that their brains can be studied in great detail. Genes play important roles in controlling behavior, and genetic mutations are associated with neuropsychiatric diseases such as autism and schizophrenia, which are marked by deficits in social behaviors. We found that the mutations in some of these same genes also cause changes in social behaviors in adult and infant zebrafish, and we are now trying to find out what exactly is changed in the brains of these animals, and how these changes can explain the modified behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Loss of stathmin-2 has emerged as a major pathological hallmark in several neurodegenerative conditions including amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal dementia (FTD). Using newly generated mouse models, we will test the impact of stathmin-2 loss on ALS and FTD and develop a therapeutic approach for sporadic and familial ALS/FTD based on antisense oligonucleotides (ASO)-mediated restoration of stathmin-2 level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Lay Summary The heart becomes thicker in response to high blood pressure and other forms of stress in order to maintain its function of ejecting the blood to the whole body system. Together with coordinated stimulation of other mechanisms to ensure survival of heart cells and blood supply to them, this is an essential mechanism during the early phase of stress by which the heart maintains its function even in the presence of stress. We here study the mechanism by which the heart maintains its function in the presence of high blood pressure. We will test our hypothesis that a mechanism that stimulates the use of glucose for energy supply and production of building blocks coordinates the adaptation of the heart to stress so that the heart can continue to eject the blood. The knowledge obtained from this investigation should be useful in the development of novel interventions to protect the heart against stress.

PHR: Project Narrative Few longitudinal studies have explored why and how discrimination-related stressors for Latinx youth, the largest minority group (17.9 million under the age of 18), convey risk for negative mental health outcomes, and the mechanisms leading to or moderating such risk. This revised R01 aims to evaluate specific malleable risk and protective factors at multiple ecological levels so that findings can aid in the development of targeted, culturally sensitive preventive interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to public health because one in five women in the U.S. is a sexual minority and, of the nearly 4 million births in U.S. each year, an estimated 800,000 children are born to sexual minority women. Sexual minority women and their children appear to be one of the most vulnerable maternal and child health populations, yet almost no research has documented their needs. Revealing the needs of at- risk groups—a major priority area for the NIH—will inform interventions to reduce entrenched disparities and dramatically improve obstetrical and perinatal health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Each year in the United States, more than ~50,000 adults develop leukemia and more than half of these patients will die from their disease. Therefore, the need to increase research effort in this area is evident. We assembled a group of world renowned experts to form an Integrated Translational Science Center for Leukemia that selects and supports new ideas from outstanding US and international investigators that promises to revolutionary the current treatment approach to leukemia. This Center will work together with the National Clinical Trial Network and other initiatives sponsored by the National Cancer Institute

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative We aim to establish the Health Outcomes around Pregnancy and Exposure to HIV/Antiretrovirals (HOPE) cohort to enroll and follow 2000 young women living with HIV (WLHIV), including those with perinatally acquired HIV (PHIV), to address critical scientific questions in the clinical course of HIV infection from preconception to postpartum. The cohort will be recruited from and build on the unique research infrastructure of the well- established Pediatric HIV/AIDS Cohort Study (PHACS) to create a platform for exploring the multilevel dynamic determinants and mechanisms that influence the short and longer-term health of WLHIV during their reproductive years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Breast cancer screening with mammography does not perform well for the many women who have dense breast tissue, but there are not clear guidelines regarding supplemental screening for these women. We will examine the effectiveness of supplemental ultrasound screening in clinical practice and estimate the long-term benefits, harms, and costs of screening strategies in which supplemental ultrasound is targeted to women with high rates of mammography screening failures. The results will reduce the burden of breast cancer among women for whom mammography screening is not adequate, by providing evidence for women, providers, and policymakers to inform breast cancer screening decision-making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative To address persistent and growing health and healthcare disparities, efforts are urgently needed to build the capacity and diversity of the research workforce. Applying integrative health approaches to advance optimal health for all is a promising, but under-studied strategy. The proposed program will strengthen the research workforce by providing diverse, predoctoral learners with a much-needed career on-ramp: short-term, interprofessional research training in integrative medicine, focused on social disparities in health and healthcare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Defining host-intrinsic mechanisms associated with immune failure could lead to the development of immune therapies capable of eliciting anti-tumor immune reactivity across a broad range of cancer types. We identify that chronic signaling through TLR5 on host cells impairs myeloid function and reduces the ability of T cells to respond during immune therapy for ovarian, breast, and melanoma cancers. This research will define the mechanisms of TLR5-induced myeloid dysfunction and failure of PD-L1 blockade, the impact of which could establish inhibition of TLR5 signaling as a novel therapeutic for multiple malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Function focused care is an approach to care in which nurses acknowledge older adults’ physical and cognitive capabilities and integrate physical activity into all care interactions. This care approach prevents the decline in function, limited physical activity, behavioral and psychological symptoms, among other adverse outcomes in hospitalized patients with Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD). Our goal in this work is to demonstrate the efficacy of a practical and effective intervention, FFC-AC-EIT, to optimize function and physical activity and prevent adverse events among hospitalized patients with ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Understanding the mechanisms of cell migration is a fundamental question in cell, developmental and cancer biology. Cells in vivo travel through confining three-dimensional (3D) pores or channel-like tracks created by various anatomical structures in the body. We will herein utilize state-of-the-art bioengineering, materials and imaging tools as well as in vivo models to offer a comprehensive understanding of the mechanisms driving cell locomotion in physically-confined spaces and provide insights for developing technologies that can control, manipulate, promote or stop cell migration in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pharmaceutical drug discovery produces dramatic public health beneﬁts through new and improved treatments for common diseases and disorders, but it is an expensive, time-consuming process involving much trial and error, and failure is common. This work focuses on automated, iterative computational design of new drugs, allowing tight coupling of modeling and experiment to dramatically accelerate the discovery and development process. Improved modeling techniques help guide experimental work, and experimental outputs feed back into rapidly improved designs, with the resulting discovery pipeline providing public health rewards both in terms of new technology and via discovery of new potential antibacterials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative.  One of the most complex issues associated with Substance Use Disorder (SUD) treatment, is the development of strategies that assist in the initiation and maintenance of recovery following addiction. To add further intricacy, there are substantial sex differences indicating women may face significantly more hurdles in maintaining drug abstinence, compared to men. Thus, understanding mechanisms of sex differences in addiction is critical to the development of effective therapies for SUDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health, because it will provide a mechanistic understanding of how genetic mutations in Piezo proteins, which are known to sense mechanical stimuli and function as sensors of light mechanical touch, proprioception, lung inflation and arterial blood flow, are resulting in several poorly- understood human diseases. The proposal will also explore how Piezo proteins work mechanistically. This in return may provide very specific strategies for treating each of the associated diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative A revolution in neuroscience has been the ability to control nerve cells with light; this is made possible by using viruses to deliver special genes to the cells. Such “optogenetic” technologies were developed using rodents, but they remain unreliable in non-human primates, the best animal model for understanding the human brain. We aim to rigorously enhance, map, and validate the efficacy of new viral methods for controlling neurons in the visual system of the primate brain to benefit both basic research and gene therapies for visuomotor disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Our primary goal is to delineate adverse long-term health outcomes after curative therapies in children and adults with sickle cell disease (SCD). Despite the recent success of curing sickle cell disease, there have been limited systematic efforts to elucidate long-term health outcomes. Ultimately, the shortened lifespan of young adults with SCD, attributable to declining heart, lung, and kidney function, for which curative therapies were designed to address, must be measured against favorable and unfavorable late outcomes (mortality and morbidity) of these therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The incidence of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the U.S. is increasing rapidly, faster than all but one solid cancer, but its prognosis remains dismal with a median survival less than one year. This project aims to investigate the use of blood, imaging, clinical biomarkers associated with rapid HCC progression and develop an accurate predictive algorithm for HCC prognosis. This will provide a more tailored approach to patient management and offer them effective therapy early.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sexual assault is a significant public health concern impacting 1 in 5 college women. Alcohol and cannabis are known risk factors for sexual assault victimization, and women who experience nonconsensual sex are at a greater risk of developing alcohol and cannabis use disorders. This project involves the development of a risk reduction program for high risk college women that will integrate evidence- and theory-based alcohol and cannabis prevention content into an evidence-based sexual assault risk reduction program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have discovered that expression of a protein in the serine biosynthesis pathway, PHGDH, is associated with metastasis of triple negative breast cancer: low PHGDH drives production of the cancer-associated metabolite sialic acid and activates cellular programs that promote metastasis. Our project will investigate the links between PHGDH, sialic acid metabolism, and metastasis. This research will establish low PHGDH/high sialic acid as a biomarker of metastatic breast cancer and identify new strategies to treat this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the promise of smoking cessation interventions in people living with HIV (PLWH), intervention potential is limited by a lack of understanding about how to best implement evidence-based cessation strategies in this population. Tobacco treatment with first-line pharmacotherapy, delivered remotely in a proactive, opt-out fashion presents an opportunity for PLWH to receive robust, evidence-based tobacco treatment even if they are not currently motivated to quit smoking. By optimizing the delivery of effective tobacco treatments for PLWH, we hope to increase the number of people receiving tobacco treatment, increase tobacco cessation rates, and reduce the risk of morbidity and mortality from smoking-related causes.

PHR: RELEVANCE:) Abnormalities in platelet number and/or function can cause life-threatening complications such as bleeding and thrombosis. This proposal will fill important gaps in our understanding of the molecular mechanisms regulating the production, the intravascular survival, and the hemostatic function of platelets. Successful completion of the proposed work should lead to improved diagnosis and management of inherited and acquired bleeding disorders, and to novel and more personalized approaches for the prevention of thrombotic complications such as heart attacks and deep vein thrombosis. )

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Chemoresistance of intestinal peritoneal surface malignancies is a considerable clinical problem with lethal consequences to patients. In this project we will develop a tumor organoid-based drug testing platform that models the genomic clonal composition of tumors and clonal drug response toward the prediction of clinical drug efficacy in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on identifying specific pathological changes that reduce insulin delivery to the brain and cause cognitive changes. This new knowledge is expected to not only facilitate the discovery of new drugs against Alzheimer’s disease, but also help repurpose existing drugs that were approved to treat other diseases, such as diabetes and stroke. The proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission pertaining to reducing illness and enhancing health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunotolerance is a key aspect of pregnancy maintenance, mediated by specialized inhibitory immune cells, such as natural killer cells, at the maternal-fetal interface. Yet, these specialized immune cell populations must also remain vigilant to invading placental pathogens, such as cytomegalovirus (CMV), the leading global infectious cause of birth defects and long-term neurologic deficits. Using a nonhuman primate pregnancy model that closely mirrors pregnancy and congenital CMV transmission in humans, this proposal will fill the gap in our understanding of the role of specialized immune cell populations at the maternal-fetal interface and accelerate progress towards effective immune-based strategies to prevent adverse pregnancy outcomes, such as preterm labor and congenital infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This application investigates new strategies to treat sickle cell disease using two potentially transformative technologies for precision genetic manipulation, termed base editing and prime editing. Specifically, we will use these new tools to modify the genome of blood forming cells from affected individuals to either directly repair the sickle cell disease mutation or circumvent its damaging effects. If successful, our strategies will lead to a safe and effective cure for a devastating disorder that affects 100,000 Americans and millions worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older adult smokers are at elevated risk for cognitive decline and Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) development and, unless they can successfully quit smoking, their prevalence will continue to rise. Unfortunately, older smokers are half as likely to attempt to quit smoking compared to younger adults, which may be a function of both dysfunctional beliefs/motivational deficits of older smokers and clinician inaction. The proposed work will develop and test a readily translatable Stage 1 motivational intervention for smoking cessation in older adults consisting of: (1) a novel patient-informed motivational message promoting smoking cessation, and (2) clear access routes to evidence-based smoking treatments (EBSTs) within a healthcare setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because over 20 million people worldwide suffer from focal drug-resistant epilepsy and are potential candidates for cure with epilepsy surgical interventions. Upon successful completion of the proposed research, we expect our contribution to be development of noninvasive imaging biomarkers to predict IEEG functional dynamics and epilepsy surgical outcomes. Our findings may inform current and new therapies to map and alter seizure spread, and pave the way for less invasive, better- targeted, patient-specific interventions with improved surgical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance) One of the most prominent clinical features of severe COVID-19 is exuberant inflammation and endothelial dysfunction. The proposed research investigates the effects of COVID-19 on cardiovascular function using deep phenotyping approaches including human endothelial cell gene expression profiling. These studies will provide the unique opportunity to investigate molecular underpinnings of long-term endothelial effects among patients with obesity and could have important preventive and therapeutic implications in understanding disease susceptibility to COVID-19.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Defective tracheal cartilage development leads to airway collapse during breathing, causing sudden death in infants. We will take the genetic and molecular approaches to characterize how BMP signaling is well- orchestrated in directing the tracheal cartilage development. The outcome of the proposed studies will establish the knowledge base for the practical therapeutic solutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The fungal pathogen Histoplasma capsulatum causes respiratory and systemic disease by invading and replicating within host cells. Within this host cell, Histoplasma capsulatum scavenges host molecules for its own proliferation during infection, yet these nutritional sources are unknown. This proposal will identify the host molecules consumed by Histoplasma capsulatum when it infects host cells, revealing new therapeutic targets to interfere with the pathogen’s ability to gain metabolic resources from the host.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Atrial Fibrillation is a highly prevalent disease in advanced age, a frequent comorbidity to many common diseases, and contributes to increased hospitalization risk and healthcare costs. This project aims to develop a mobile telemonitoring platform to simultaneously monitor symptoms of atrial fibrillation, such as hemodynamic instability and rhythm disturbances, as well as allow the patient and clinician to monitor, predict, and intervene to significant side effects of common pharmacologic treatment of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the cause of many serious human infections, particularly in hospitalized patients with weak immune systems and burn wounds, due to the ability of this human pathogen to form biofilms that are highly resilient to antimicrobial treatment. This proposed research is aimed at elucidating genes and gene functions that enable dispersing bacteria to liberate themselves from the biofilm matrix, regardless of the biofilm matrix composition, and drive the phenotype of dispersed cells. Findings from the proposed study are anticipated to lead to the identification of factors and mechanisms contributing to biofilm dispersion.

PHR: Project Narrative Immunotherapies designed to stimulate immune responses against tumors have revolutionized the treatment of cancer. However, successful immunotherapy is dependent on the presentation of tumor antigens on the cell surface, and treatments designed to enhance tumor antigen presentation have great potential to complement immunotherapies. This proposal outlines experiments to evaluate pharmacological modulation of cellular protein folding pathways as a unique strategy to stimulate antigen presentation and drive anti-tumor immune responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: KPC-2 serine carbapenemase is the major cause of carbapenem resistance in Enterobacteriaceae, deemed an urgent threat by the CDC, while the emergence of NDM-1 metallo-carbapenemase is also raising significant concern. The studies outlined in this proposal aim to develop novel inhibitors against KPC-2 carbapenemase, including dual-activity compounds against NDM-1, and to investigate the unique ability of KPC-2 to hydrolyze nearly all β-lactam antibiotics. The results will provide new chemical scaffolds for novel antibiotic development and provide new understanding of carbapenemase function and inhibition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE People who carry the APOE E4 gene are at higher risk of Alzheimer’s disease, and they have a different brain metabolic response to interventions involving diet and metabolism, including high fat feeding. In our laboratory, we have consistently shown that E4 carriers cognitively improve after high fat feeding. We want to understand this phenomenon using assessment of cerebral brain flow by MRI and by analysis of the metabolic markers in the spinal fluid.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atopic dermatitis (AD) is the most common chronic illness of childhood and is often a lifelong disease. AD is among the top 50 most prevalent diseases worldwide, has the second highest disability rank of all nonmalignant skin diseases, and is characterized by chronic and relapsing skin inflammation and itch. Despite our increasing understanding of the role type 2 cytokines and group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC2s) in AD, development of new AD therapies is hindered by an incomplete understanding of the immune cell types that regulate the disease beyond these cytokines and immune cells. This proposal will interrogate the relevant identity, spatiotemporal dynamics, and effector mechanisms by which natural killer (NK) cells play a previously unrecognized role in limiting type 2 skin inflammation and AD pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The discovery that there are simple ways to turn our own defense mechanisms against cancer was revolutionary, leading to unprecedented cures of some patients with advanced disease that had never been possible with surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy. Unfortunately, this miraculous treatment, called immunotherapy, does not work as often as it should, and it remains a mystery why people with the same type of cancer will have different responses to the same treatment. The experiments being supported by this project are intended to create a blood test to predict whether cancer immunotherapy will work or not and also to provide a solution for patients who are not likely to respond, by adding a second medication to their treatment, which will increase their chances of responding to immunotherapy.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Globally, up to 40% of hospital-acquired infections are catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTIs). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a major public health problem, which is more prevalent in older individuals. The sleep-related decrease of the tonus of upper airway muscles, which keeps airway open in wakefulness, is a key neurological cause of the airway occlusion in most OSA patients. Since noradrenergic neurons significantly contribute to the maintenance of upper airway muscle tone, we will determine whether the functioning of these noradrenergic neurons is impaired with age; this information will be helpful for developing proper therapeutic strategies for the clinical management of OSA in older patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current project investigates the role of diabetogenic CD8 T cells in autoimmune type I diabetes (T1D) from the perspective of beta-cell self-antigen recognition. This will be undertaken by novel biophysical single cell/single molecule methods in combination with cutting edge biological/immunological assays to elucidate the underlying molecular mechanisms. This will provide mechanistic understanding of beta-sell self-recognition (compared to normal foreign-recognition) and offer new insights for future direct therapeutical targeting of diabetogenic CD8 T cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: PACIFIC INSTITUTE FOR RES AND EVALUATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will determine whether the California responsible beverage service (RBS) training law has an impact on alcohol-related motor vehicle crashes, and whether “usual and customary” training will match the efficacy of an online WaytoServe RBS training program in reducing over-service of alcohol to apparently-intoxicated pseudopatrons at licensed on-premises establishments such as bars and restaurants. This study will also conduct a state-wide survey of owners and managers of alcohol outlets to identify barriers and facilitators to their compliance with the new law and its intended effects for improving server behavior. Findings of this study will have implications for state and local regulatory policies regarding RBS training, and for future research on the effectiveness of RBS training.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease of the artery walls that leads to heart attacks and strokes. We discovered in mouse models that vaccination with short sequences of APOB, a protein associated with cholesterol transport, can reduce the inflammation in the artery wall. The proposed work will lay the mechanistic groundwork for developing an atherosclerosis vaccine that is expected to benefit tens of millions of people in the US and billions of people worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative  Basic and clinical research over the past decade is shedding new light on the major role played by the nervous system in asthma, COPD, and chronic coughing. This proposal focuses on unraveling the chemical and ionic mechanisms of airway nerve activation and on identifying the specific aspects of airway inflammation, especially during early life that leads to a hyperactive neuronal state in the airways. The findings will increase our understanding of airway biology, and will continue to define new therapeutic targets aimed at reducing the suffering of those with inflammatory airway diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative. Our preliminary results show that cocaine dose-dependently downregulates a novel, cell type-specific molecular substrate in the midbrain, KCC2, that could be targeted to treat cocaine use disorder. Cocaine taking downregulates KCC2, which disrupts midbrain GABAergic circuitry and augments subsequent cocaine-taking behavior. Using a rodent model of voluntary cocaine taking and seeking we will quantify this cocaine-induced circuitry neuroadaptation, and we will apply two mechanistically different pharmacotherapies to enhance KCC2 function to attenuate or prevent cocaine self-administration and reinstatement, which is an animal model of relapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with cancer undergoing cancer treatments such as radiation therapy or chemotherapy may require emergency department (ED) visits or hospitalization, a public health need that affects treatment outcomes, quality of life, and costs to patients and the healthcare system. We have developed artificial intelligence (AI) models using routine electronic health record data and mobile device step count data that have been demonstrated to predict and reduce ED visits and hospitalizations. The goal of this work is to assess and improve how well these approaches work across a network of diverse hospitals and make the benefits of this AI-supported care apply more broadly and ensure access and equal healthcare to all patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malaria, one of the world’s most devastating diseases, afflicts 200-400 million people and kills nearly 500,000 annually, and these numbers will increase as resistance to currently used drugs spreads. This project aims to determine the physiological pathways which enable rapid drug-tolerance and establish the basis for the adaptive proline response in the parasite. We apply an integrated chemogenomic approach combining Plasmodium genetics, metabolomic flux balance analysis, quantitative mass spectrometry based-proteomics, and rational pharmacology to identify and validate mechanistically relevant targets that can be exploited for the prevention and reversal of drug resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Overexpression of FGFR1 is the driver abnormality in AML associated with the Stem Cell leukemia/lymphoma syndrome, an aggressive disease with very poor survival. Recent studies demonstrate a transcription factor function for FGFR1 and that genes it regulated allows escape from immune recognition. These studies will define genes responsible for these events with a view to developing novel therapeutic strategies for this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Keratoconus (KC) is a common vision-debilitating corneal dystrophy with an ill-defined polygenic basis and a complex etiopathology. We identified poor protective antioxidant responses and gene networks that regulate matrix and cellular functions in KC. Based on these premises, the current study will identify antioxidant biomarkers, disease-predisposing DNA variants by next generation sequencing, and establish patient-derived cell culture models to probe disease mechanisms and therapeutic agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative As an NCI-designated comprehensive cancer center since 1997, the University of Colorado Cancer Center (UCCC) continues to provide significant leadership in the development and conduct of important translational and therapeutic clinical trials for cancer patients that improve the standard of care and extend the quality and quantity of life. As a stated goal of UCCC, mentorship and training of the next generation of investigators is part of our mission. In 2013, with the newly incorporated University of Colorado Health Systems (UCHealth), we integrated our flagship hospital (University of Colorado Hospital (UCH) with the Poudre Valley Hospital system and the Memorial Hospital system as the components of the LAPS institution (since 2014), and have been able to extend integrated clinical care and clinical research to a much larger segment of the Colorado and Wyoming population. This grant will benefit from the integrated electronic medical records, clinical management trial system, regulatory and fiscal management of clinical trials, and bring important clinical trials hours closer to cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Despite the significance of neurotransmitters norepinephrine (NE) and epinephrine (Epi) in a large number of physiological and pathological conditions, adrenergic transmission remains poorly understood, due primarily to limitations of available tools for monitoring NE/Epi. We propose to employ our newly developed high-performance GRABNE sensors (and sensor-based superresolution and deconvolution microscopic analysis algorithms) to define the unusual synaptic properties and functional role for adrenergic transmission, and thus build the baseline for the future translational and clinical NE research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the high risk for sleep-related morbidity, there is a paucity of data on sleep-disrupting psychosocial and environmental stressors associated with sleep deficiency (poor sleep, sleep apnea, and/or circadian misalignment) among older blacks. Our multi-disciplinary team will use novel mHealth devices recording sleep/activity cycles, light, noise, air quality, temperature, and greenspace exposure; novel brain biomarkers; and geospatial analytics to assess effects on sleep deficiency and delineate their role in explaining disparities in the brain and cognitive health of older blacks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Millions of dollars are being expended to build single-cell maps of the cellular, genetic, and proteomic heterogeneity in human cancers. Easy-to-use and off-the-shelf models for visualizing extreme heterogeneity in genetically tractable systems will be necessary for translating the human cancer atlas into biological mechanisms of cancer progression and therapeutic resistance. This proposal is relevant to public health because it will provide first-of-kind technology, termed “MousePaint”, for visualizing massive tissue heterogeneity and experimentally mapping cancer evolution in genetically tractable animal models.

PHR: NARRATIVE Our laboratory has been focused on elucidating the molecular mechanisms that regulate progressive pulmonary fibrosis for over two decades. The goals of this R35 application are to identify the epithelial- mesenchymal interactions that lead to unremitting fibrosis. Augmenting scientific knowledge in understanding the underlying mechanisms and the mode of actions of these interactions in lung fibrosis could significantly aid therapeutic development for patients with progressive pulmonary fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In melanoma, PD-1 blockade has transformed the management of advanced and high-risk resectable disease with unprecedented improvements in progression-free and overall survival. However, non-response remains a pressing issue. Although still early in clinical development, agonists of Toll-like receptor 9 (TLR9) have demonstrated potential for the treatment of cancer. TLR9 agonists directly induce activation and maturation of plasmacytoid dendritic cells and enhance differentiation of B cells into antibody-secreting plasma cells. This project aims to investigate mechanisms of response and resistance to a novel clinical trial testing neoadjuvant immunotherapy with intra-tumoral CMP- 001 and nivolumab in high-risk resectable melanoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Healthy brain aging is key to extend the healthspan and glia play an important role but the molecular pathways involved are poorly understood. We have discovered that changes in social status in Harpegnathos ants induce an expansion in neuroprotective phagocytic glia, which is linked to a 5-fold extension of lifespan. Here, I will define the molecular pathways that regulate these remarkable events of glia plasticity and how they impact healthy brain aging and longevity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Evidence suggests a role for pro-angiogenic macrophages in neovascular age-related macular degeneration pathogenesis, which is the leading cause of vision loss in the developed world. Our preliminary data demonstrates that macrophages are heterogeneous in experimental choroidal neovascularization (CNV) and that interleukin-7 receptor (IL7R) expressing macrophages are pro- angiogenic. In this proposal, we will determine the origin and function of IL7R+ macrophages during experimental CNV; these experiments will set the stage for potential cell-based therapies to simultaneously target multiple pro-angiogenic pathways via inhibiting IL7R+ macrophages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Large chromosomal deletions are a hallmark of the cancer genome, but the role of such lesions in tumorigenesis has been significantly understudied due to the challenge of generating mouse models that accurately mimic such deletions. Our proposed work boldly aims to overcome this obstacle, and will contribute greatly to the implementation of precision oncology research, open new opportunities for modelling human diseases associated with large chromosomal deletions, and lead to novel insights into the biology of cancer-associated large deletions in prostate cancer, which will facilitate the identification of deletion-specific vulnerabilities that can be exploited for cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PIs: Ash Alizadeh, M.D./Ph.D. & Maximilian Diehn, M.D./Ph.D. In this study, we will use liquid biopsy to identify genetic subtypes in classical Hodgkin lymphoma. We will combine serial liquid biopsy measurements and imaging methods to refine prediction of how patients with classical Hodgkin lymphoma will respond to treatment. This work is relevant to public health because precision medicine has the potential to improve clinical outcomes of cancer patients and reduce sequelae.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Estrogen receptor gene (ESR1) plays a major role in development, tissue homeostasis, and human cancer. The main goal of this proposal is to investigate the functional cross talk between ESR1 and the Hippo pathway, which is known to play a major role in organ size control and tumorigenesis. Completion of this project will not only address fundamental questions in ESR1 gene regulation and its role in Hippo biology, but also provide scientific basis for therapeutic intervention of the Hippo pathway for ESR1 expressing cancers, such as breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance Chronic respiratory disease is a leading cause of death in the U.S. and worldwide and the morbidity and mortality are closely linked to excess production of airway mucus. Despite the scope of this problem, there are no specific and effective therapies for prevention or reversal of this abnormality. The proposed studies aim to define and control the pathways leading to airway disease and thereby address a previously unmet need for treatment of a major public health problem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In FY16, with clinical trials being an integral part of MDACC’s mission, we were able to treat more than 9,000 patients on approximately 1,000 interventional trials making significate contributions to the National Clinical Trial Network (NCTN). Not only were we able to enroll > 215 patients per year, but we were also able to provide robust trial enrollment, scientific and administrative leadership, and mentorship of early career faculty to participate in these important national trials. With the newly proposed NCTN LAPS UG1 grant, we will continue working towards our mission of eliminating cancer in Texas, nationally, and globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narratives The pathogenesis of nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), a leading cause of cirrhosis and liver cancer, is poorly understood. Our recent study found that AMPK regulates caspase-6 activity to control NASH-associated liver injury. The proposed study will investigate the regulation and functions of a novel AMPK-caspase-6-BID axis in the development of NASH and dissect the underlying molecular mechanism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Loss of all or part of chromosome 7 is among the most common chromosomal abnormalities in high-risk myeloid diseases, yet the precise genetic and mechanistic contributions of these deletions remain unknown. There are many purported myeloid regulators and tumor suppressor genes on 7q, suggesting 7q may be a contiguous gene syndrome region in which the loss of multiple neighboring genes contributes to disease. This proposal aims to leverage CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing to model 7q deletions in vivo and identify combinatorial gene deficiencies that drive myeloid disease, and define the mechanisms by which dosage imbalances contribute to disease development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Vasopressin is a hormone that regulates water balance, blood pressure and contributes to progression of non-diabetic, diabetic, and polycystic kidney disease (PKD), through mechanisms that are still unclear. Vasopressin production was thought to be limited to the brain, but we have evidence that it is also made in the kidney. This project aims to understand the role that kidney-derived vasopressin plays in health and disease using cells and transgenic mouse models with a targeted deletion of vasopressin in the kidney.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE In glaucoma, retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) slowly and progressively degenerate leading to visual impairment. We have shown hypoacetylation, decline in neurotrophic factors, and an increase in DNA methylation in ocular hypertensive animals. These changes were reversed by δ-opioid-receptor activation and subsequently provides RGCs neuroprotection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Pregnancy conditions such as prediabetes, obesity, and gestational diabetes mellitus can exacerbate maternal insulin levels causing changes in placental function, altering nutrient availability to fetal metabolic tissues and predisposing the offspring to metabolic disease in childhood and adulthood. Yet, very little information is known about the role of insulin signaling in placental function and the mechanistic link between maternal hyperinsulinemia and the programming of metabolic disease in the offspring. We expect that the results from the proposed work will ultimately lead to new understanding of the effects of high maternal insulin during pregnancy on placental nutrient delivery to the fetus that may cause programming of metabolic disease, and this new knowledge could improve clinical management of patients, and thus improve women's reproductive health and pregnancy outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent theoretical models and empirical studies have highlighted glutamate as a key neurotransmitter in the pathophysiology of depression that may be an important target for novel fast-acting antidepressants. However, given the dynamic nature of the metabolism of glutamate (which can be metabolized as part of the Krebs cycle in neurons or converted to glutamine in astrocytes via mitochondrial enzymes), it is critical to develop novel imaging methods that will clarify which aspects of glutamatergic metabolism is altered by depression. Thus, the goal of the present study is to establish the reliable detection of dynamic glutamate metabolism in depressed individuals using proton and deuterium magnetic resonance spectroscopy at ultrahigh magnetic fields (7 Tesla) combined with oral intake of deuterated glucose and to develop novel metabolic metrics that will provide insight into this debilitating condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alkylation damage is one of the most commonly encountered types of DNA damage induced by environmental agents as well as by cancer chemotherapeutics. Our group recently discovered a new signaling pathway by which human cells sense such damage. We now have evidence that the cell senses alkylation damage initially on RNA, which in turn is used to activate a signal to promote DNA repair. This proposal seeks to understand this novel paradigm in maintaining genomic integrity and its role in cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kidney disease is a growing health problem worldwide, but the development of new treatments to stop or reverse kidney damage has remained limited. The present application uses patient-derived, adult kidney organoids to enable a new way to study kidney disease in the laboratory, in particular how different cells in the kidney interact with one another. This approach will enhance our understanding of kidney diseases and enable the creation of new targeted therapies to treat them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed research is relevant to public health because patients with tetralogy of Fallot, the most common cyanotic congenital heart disease affecting ~1:2500 babies, have increased risk of heart failure and premature death despite excellent initial surgery. Development of non-invasive, easily obtained, and rapidly implemented metrics of ventricular mechanics are needed to improve prediction of death and allow optimization of pulmonary valve replacement timing. This project is relevant to the NHLBI’s mission because the tools developed here, and the skills learned, could then be applied to other forms of congenital and structural heart disease, and promote longer and more fulfilling lives for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative In modern sanitary conditions, humans (and laboratory rodents) no longer encounter entire classes of environmental and commensal microorganisms that can shape effective and appropriate immunoregulatory circuits. This reduction in microbial input may drive development of hyperactive pathological neuroinflammatory responses and associated behavioral deficits (cognitive impairments, depression, etc.). Here we will reveal in rats whether a microbial-based treatment strategy, that is approved for use in humans (Mycobacterium vaccae immunotherapy; NCTC 11659), prevents age-associated neuroinflammation and postoperative cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With recent advances in disease modeling and therapeutic genome editing, there is now the opportunity to tackle two distinct but interrelated challenges in cardiovascular care. First, how to interpret clinical sequencing data to better determine who is at risk for cardiovascular diseases. Second, how to prevent vulnerable patients from developing these diseases. My laboratory is seeking to address both of these challenges in the coming years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Astroviruses are a global cause of gastroenteritis, commonly known as stomach flu, but currently there are no vaccines or treatments available to protect against these viruses. Cytotoxic T cells are immune cells important for killing infected cells and preventing future infections, and while these cells are critical to combat astroviruses, little is known about how they specifically engage astrovirus-infected cells. Understanding the specific aspects of the virus that T cells target and characterizing how protective T cell responses develop are both critical to advance astrovirus vaccines and therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding how tumors respond to radiotherapy is critical to producing new molecularly targeted treatments that overcome radiation resistance and improve survival for cancer patients. Based on our preliminary data, we predict that p21 activated kinases cause resistance to radiotherapy and that by targeting these kinases we can sensitize tumors to radiotherapy. In this proposal, we will investigate the mechanisms though which p21 activated kinases produce resistance to radiotherapy which will allow us to develop biomarker driven treatment approaches to increase radiotherapy's ability to destroy tumors while decreasing side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Long-acting injectable medications for both HIV and Opioid Use Disorder have the potential to dramatically improve adherence by eliminating the need for daily pill-taking. While treating these two conditions concurrently with long-acting injectables holds promise, currently little is known about whether offering this integrated treatment approach is feasible, acceptable, or effective for this population. This study seeks to address this limitation by developing and pilot testing a clinical protocol to guide the delivery of combined long-acting injectable treatment for HIV and Opioid Use Disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study examines the function of MYCT1, a gene that is dysregulated in cultured human HSCs, in the control of endocytosis, a crucial regulatory step that multiple signaling pathways need to execute cell fate decisions. Our work will illuminate the mechanisms by which MYCT1 controls stemness and cell fate in HSCs by integrating extracellular signaling cues, which will provide new insight to the culture- associated HSC dysfunction. These studies may provide new strategies to restore compromised transplantability of ex vivo expanded human HSCs, and ultimately help expand clinical applications of human HSCs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Toxoplasma gondii is the causative agent of toxoplasmosis, a debilitating disease in immunocompromised individuals, and current treatments have been shown to have severe side effects. Development of assays against new targets will help advance the discovery of new and effective therapies for this deadly disease. The purpose of our application is to develop low-cost assays for the Toxoplasma gondii kinome and chemical probes to inform upon the biology of the parasite.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Plasminogen activator inhibitor type 1 (PAI-1/ SerpinE1) and type 2 (PAI-2/ SerpinB2) are serine protease inhibitors of tissue plasminogen activator and urokinase. In contrast to well-known pathologic role of PAI-1 in metabolic syndrome, our preliminary data indicate that PAI-2/ SerpinB2 plays a protective role in obesity- induced insulin resistance. Understanding the mechanisms involved in maintaining glucose tolerance by PAI-2/ SerpinB2 will significantly improve our knowledge on drug development to treat insulin resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inverse hemodynamic response (IHR), an inappropriate reduction of cerebral blood flow in response to increased neuronal activity, is a shared pathological event in seizure, traumatic brain injury, and other neurological disorders, and is an emerging significant contributor to the pathophysiology of these neurological diseases. Using combined pharmacological and genetic approaches, this project will test a novel hypothesis that the seizure-induced IHR is mediated by the NPYR1-TRPC3-ET1 signaling axis in cerebrovascular endothelial cells, and demonstrate that disruption of this signaling axis can reduce the susceptibility to seizures and their deleterious consequences. Results from this study will reveal new mechanistic insights regarding IHR and may lead to new treatments for epilepsy and other neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARARATIVE Many tumors have been sequenced, providing lists of mutations that commonly occur and likely drive disease. However, the precise role of most mutations is unknown, and some may play different roles according to the cell type they occur in or the presence of other mutations. We present BEAT-seq, a technology for engineering many mutations in parallel into cells and observing how gene expression is altered in response. Their effects can therefore be compared, for example enabling function to be assigned to mutations with unknown roles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ENgaging in Advance Care planning Talks (ENACT) Group Visits intervention is a theory-based and practical primary care model that uses the strengths of group visits to promote advance care planning discussions and documentation. This effectiveness study will provide evidence for use of this advance care planning intervention among older adults with and without early Alzheimer's dementia. Specifically, ENACT Group Visits intervention may improve patient-centered care by increasing advance care planning documentation, advance care planning readiness, decision self-efficacy, and quality of communication related to decision making about care preferences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) shunt treatments for hydrocephalus malfunction at an unacceptably high rate, and Cellular/tissue catheter obstruction is the leading cause of this failure. Therefore, we are developing a unique bioreactor system with the incorporation of ventricular zone (VZ) cells and Choroid plexus (ChP) cultures that mimic the cytopathology, CSF flow, and intracranial pressure (ICP) linked to hydrocephalus. Thus, our approach is the only system considering ICP, CSF flow, VZ glial activation, and the adhesion and proliferation of ChP to mimic the clinical conditions associated with shunt obstruction reliably.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: We propose to test a neuroplasticity-based computerized cognitive remediation intervention (nCCR) (a non-invasive form of targeted brain training) against an active control intervention to improve cognitive control deficits (CCD) in patients with late life major depression (LLD) who have not responded to antidepressant treatment (SSRI/SNRI). CCD are indicative of abnormalities in the cognitive control network (CCN), a brain network whose degeneration is associated with poor clinical outcomes in LLD including, poor response to SSRI/SNRI antidepressants, severe course, relapse, disability, suicide and all-cause mortality. If successful at improving CCD and related cognitive deficits in LLD, nCCR has the potential to improve mood and cognitive impairments, and increase the number of LLD patients who are able to attain and sustain remission. nCCR is designed to be cost effective and easily disseminated and thus could reduce public health costs and have a wide-spread impact on disability and suffering in a group at high risk poor clinical outcomes

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health in its focus on improving supportive behaviors of care partners of older adults with type 1 diabetes using continuous glucose monitoring with data sharing to achieve glycemic goals. The Share plus study will be a significant step in the science of data sharing and care partner interventions to prevent age-related diabetes complications. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to diabetes management in the growing population of older adults with type 1 diabetes and includes integrating a wealth of research in dyadic coping and innovative diabetes technology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it combines computational methods for defining noncoding driver mutations in whole cancer genomes with genome editing experiments to identify their biological role in tumor development. The functional characterization of these driver events will pave the way for the development of new cancer therapies and genomic markers to select the right therapy for each patient. Hence, this project will have immediate impact on the clinical interpretation of patient sequencing data and is relevant to the NIH's mission to improve the clinical care and survival of cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Using genetic mouse models, we have identified POU6F2 as a genetic link between central corneal thickness and glaucoma. Our central hypothesis is that POU6F2 is a necessary part of a transcriptional network in novel RGC subtypes that are uniquely susceptible to glaucomatous insult. We will define the role of POU6F2 in the response of retinal ganglion cells to glaucoma and will also identify the molecular cascades associated with irreversible early death of ganglion cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The major goal of this application is to implement a novel chemical genetics approach to target prioritized host chromatin regulators to assess their roles in HIV-1 proviral latency maintenance and reactivation towards efforts for a functional HIV-1 cure. We will first endogenously tag these factors in CD4+ T cell models of latency that recapitulate the biology of viral persistence in patients. We will then prioritize candidates for cross-validation in primary CD4+ T cell models of latency and aviremic patient samples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Changes in the human brain following early blindness have been widely documented, but our understanding of the mechanisms underlying this remarkable neuroplasticity is very limited. My goal is to examine the anatomical, neural, and computational constraints that allows blind individuals to meet the extraordinary challenge of learning to navigate and interact with the environment using remaining senses. This will not only facilitate the development of targeted rehabilitation programs for blind individuals, but will also help us understand the processes underlying acquisition of specialized skills (including reading and arithmetic) during development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE As ligand-regulated transcription factors, nuclear receptors evolved to respond to natural small molecules, such as vitamins and lipids, translating endocrine and metabolic signals into changes in gene expression. Our data, that ligand-dependent REV-ERB activity regulates TH17 cell pathogenicity, suggests that the REV-ERBs natural endogenous ligand, heme, may function as a REV-ERB-dependent signaling molecule in TH17 cells. The proposed studies will address fundamental questions regarding ligand-dependent REV-ERBa activity, insights which will be particularly valuable in understanding TH17-mediated inflammation and may inform on future pharmaceutical approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative More than four decades of work on how rod photoreceptors detect single photons has made the rod phototransduction the best understood of the many G-protein cascades in biological systems. The broader goal of this research is to bring a similar clarity to our understanding of the generation of cone signals in the fovea. Determining the molecular factors involved in phototransduction that make foveal cones so unique will identify potential substrates for therapy in disease conditions such as macular degeneration. By providing the first detailed insight into cone photoreceptor function in the fovea and across primate retina we will provide a benchmark to evaluate cellular function in stem cell - derived retinas which will be an important step in devising targeted interventions for millions of people with deficits in their central vision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The overall objective of the USC UG1 Center is to provide the appropriate local infrastructure, governance, and support for the design, development, and conduct of innovative NCI-sponsored clinical trials within the NCTN. USC is uniquely positioned to play a leadership role because of its large and diverse patient population, its long history of active participation and scientific leadership in the national cooperative groups, especially SWOG, its scientific base and strengths in biomarker development, drug development, and identification of novel drugs targets and novel technologies essential for successful molecular diagnostics and monitoring.
